fields.Org Description: The Harvard Humanitarian Initiative (HHI) is a university-wide academic and research center in humanitarian crisis and leadership. Our mission is to create new knowledge and advance evidence-based leadership in disasters and humanitarian crisis. Our work focuses on two main areas: the Humanitarian Academy at Harvard and Research & Translation.

fields.Agency/Department Name: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

fields.Project Description: Humanitarian Geoanalytics integrates spatial data analysis, mapping, and field-based research to support humanitarian operations. It focuses on conflict dynamics, displacement, and vulnerability assessments using geospatial methods.

The Signal Program explores how emerging technologies—such as remote sensing and data analytics—can support protection in humanitarian emergencies. It develops tools, ethical frameworks, and applied research for crisis contexts.

KoboToolbox is a free and open-source tool designed for mobile data collection in humanitarian crises. It is utilized by UN agencies, NGOs, and governments, offering features such as offline surveys, real-time dashboards, and collaborative field assessments.

HHI Conferences is an academic and applied research center dedicated to advancing humanitarian response through evidence-based practice, data science, and technology. The center serves as a bridge between academia, practitioners, and policy stakeholders.

title_narrative: The Gendered Impacts of Employment on Domestic Violence and Pyschosocial Wellbeing
description_narrative: This study seeks to generate evidence on the relationship between the experience of employment – as distinct from cash transfers alone – and intimate partner violence, intra-household bargaining power, and gendered perceptions of self-worth vis-à-vis one’s family and the community at large. We do so in the context of the Rohingya refugee camps, the largest refugee camps in the world, and a setting in which pervasive unemployment, strong gender norms, and high rates of domestic violence mark daily refugee experience. We hope the findings of this work may inform the design of social protection policies for the world’s forcibly displaced and long-term unemployed in the developing world. The Harvard Center for International Development offers sponsored research administration services to its HKS affiliated faculty which focus on promoting and amplifying faculty research.
reporting_org_narrative: Harvard Global Research and Support Services, Inc.

title_narrative: Directorate for Research and Innovation Hub on Technology for Education (EdTech Hub)
description_narrative: The aim of the EDTech Hub programme is to “empower people by giving them the evidence they need to  make  decisions  about  technology  in  education  as  part  of  a  global  non-profit  partnership  focusing  on  research, innovation and engagement.”Specifically, this research study evaluates the impact of introducing education technology (edtech), such as school management apps and digital learning tools, to public schools in Pakistan. Previous work by Asim Khwaja and co-authors, funded through the Research on Improving Systems of Education (RISE), has shown that schools in Pakistan lack access to quality-enhancing education support services, including edtech. Yet, there is strong evidence that addressing the current learning crisis through technology-supported personalized learning can massively improve learning outcomes. This is particularly relevant when children have fallen even further behind on learning due to COVID-19 related school closures. This intervention tests how we can use technology to quickly and cheaply gather information about a student’s current learning levels, such as which concepts of third grade math they understand and which they struggle with, and provide parents and teachers with this information as well as suggestions on what to do to improve their child’s learning. This intervention will include student testing, communicating with teachers and parents through mobile phones, as well as student and parent surveys. This study builds on an ongoing Targeted Instruction intervention led by Dr. Tahir Andrabi in conjunction with federal and provincial Ministries of Education in Pakistan. The Harvard Center for International Development offers sponsored research administration services to its HKS affiliated faculty which focus on promoting and amplifying faculty research.
reporting_org_narrative: Harvard Global Research and Support Services, Inc.
recipient_country_narrative: Payment to in-country partner for personnel, field expenses, and equipment.

title_narrative: Building on “What Works” for Improving Education Quality in Pakistan using a Systems Model
description_narrative: Throughout the inception period of this grant, HG will support the inception activities for all three studies. Main Study 1: Targeted Instruction and the Take-Up and Diffusion of Innovation - support government engagement in Pakistan, contribute to the research design, and advise on any preliminary field activities. Main Study 2: Accountability Gaps: Experimental Evidence on Improving Public Service Delivery - lead the final research design, advise on field activities including data collection, and support any research/academic paper writing that may emerge from Main Study 3: Linking Foundational Learning, Long-Term Outcomes, and Policymaker Preferences using LEAPS Longitudinal Data during the inception period.
reporting_org_narrative: Harvard Global Research and Support Services, Inc.

title_narrative: NAMASTE : Global Health Research Unit on Neurodevelopment and AutisM in South ASia Treatment and Evidence
description_narrative: The NAMASTE study aims to bridge the gap in early detection and delivery of evidence-based interventions to support young children with neurodevelopmental disabilities, especially autism.
reporting_org_narrative: Harvard Global Research and Support Services, Inc.

name: HeiGIT: Heidelberg Institute for Geoinformation Technology

fields.Org Full Name: HeiGIT: Heidelberg Institute for Geoinformation Technology
fields.Org Description:
HeiGIT (Heidelberg Institute for Geoinformation Technology) advances geoinformation technology for societal and environmental benefit. It bridges the gap between fundamental research in geoinformatics and practical applications by developing innovative tools and methods. Its work includes customized geodata for humanitarian missions and intelligent routing for disaster response and climate action.

Using advances in spatial data processing and machine learning, it enriches and analyzes geodata such as OpenStreetMap, providing free tools and insights to researchers, public authorities, and non-profit organizations.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Federal Agency for Cartography and Geodesy (BKG)

fields.Project Description: The Climate Action Navigator delivers climate action indicators tailored to specific cities. Using a framework of high-resolution spatial indicators, it provides actionable insights through data, maps, and reports co-developed with our partners. The dashboard integrates multiple data sources, including OpenStreetMap (OSM), openrouteservice (ORS), satellite imagery, and scientific research, ensuring comprehensive and reliable insights for decision-makers.

The ohsome dashboard enables users to analyze OSM’s full-history data without programming skills. It generates accurate statistics and plots them directly in the dashboard, allowing for customizable filtering and grouping of tags and types across any region or time period. The ohsome quality API (OQAPI) provides access to OSM data quality information for specific regions and use-cases which might benefit i.e. humanitarian organizations and public administration.

Openrouteservice is an open-source platform leveraging OpenStreetMap data to provide advanced mobility and accessibility analysis. Surrounding the core engine is a vibrant ecosystem of services and tools, enabling seamless integration into diverse projects. We are committed to transparency, making our tools and research freely accessible. Our interactive map client highlights the platform’s capabilities and is available for anyone to explore.

In the face of growing humanitarian challenges, HeiGIT positions geoinformation as a central tool for enhancing crisis response, supporting environmental sustainability, and strengthening community resilience. By leveraging data and digital technologies, it assists humanitarian organizations in identifying vulnerabilities and hazards through risk assessments, integrating local knowledge to ensure context-specific and inclusive solutions. Through its geospatial expertise, HeiGIT pursues faster, smarter, and more effective humanitarian responses.

fields.Org Description: The Barcelona School of Economics (BSE) was founded in 2006 by Andreu Mas-Colell as an institution for scientific cooperation between four academic units: two university departments and two research centers with a long tradition of collaboration and a history of leadership in the field of Economics.

fields.Project Description: Conflict Forecast specializes in conflict forecasting, prevention, and decision support. The forecasting methodology is explicitly designed to detect new, subtle signals of conflict risk in countries not currently at war. Detecting these risks is extremely difficult and requires accepting false positives. These predictions are then integrated into a novel policy evaluation tool to assess the tradeoff between the benefits of preventive action and the costs of acting on false-positive signals.

fields.Org Description: UNICEF’s Data Team is the global go-to for data on children. It leads the collection, validation, analysis, use and communication of the most statistically sound, internationally comparable data on the situation of children and women around the world.

fields.Project Description: Since the mid-1990s, more than 120 countries have conducted one or more Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), generating data on key indicators related to the well-being of children and supporting the development of policies aimed at improving their lives.

fields.Project/Product Name: The State of the World’s Children Report
fields.Project Description: Published annually by UNICEF, The State of the World’s Children report is a flagship global publication that presents comprehensive data and analysis on issues affecting children’s well-being. Each edition focuses on a specific theme—such as nutrition, mental health, or education—and includes rigorous data from household surveys, administrative sources, and UNICEF’s global monitoring systems. The report serves as a key advocacy and programming resource for policymakers and humanitarian actors, offering evidence-based recommendations grounded in global and regional trends.

fields.Project/Product Name: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP)
fields.Project Description: Tracks access to water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) using global indicators and household survey data accessible under open access licenses.

UNICEF is recognized as the world’s leading source of data on children and maintains databases containing hundreds of internationally valid and comparable indicators. With this extensive wealth of information, the UNICEF Data Warehouse is designed to provide easy access to these indicators across a wide range of countries, with some datasets extending back several decades.

name: WFP: United Nations World Food Programme

fields.Org Full Name: WFP: United Nations World Food Programme
fields.Org Description: We work to enhance nutrition in women and children, support smallholder farmers in improving productivity and reducing losses, help countries and communities prepare for and cope with climate-related shocks, and boost human capital through school feeding programmes.

fields.Project Description: This dataset contains dekadal rainfall indicators computed from Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation satellite imagery combined with in situ station data (CHIRPS) version 2. The data is aggregated by subnational administrative units for the asset Rainfall Indicators.

HungerMapLIVE is the World Food Programme (WFP)’s global hunger monitoring system. It combines key metrics from various data sources—such as food security information, weather, population size, conflict, hazards, nutrition information, and macro-economic data—to help assess, monitor, and predict the magnitude and severity of hunger in near real-time. The resulting analysis is displayed on an interactive map that enables WFP staff, key decision makers, and the broader humanitarian community to make more informed and timely decisions relating to food security.

fields.Project/Product Name: Platform for Real-Time Impact and Situation Monitoring (PRISM)
fields.Project Description: PRISM is a climate risk monitoring system that integrates geospatial data on hazards such as droughts, floods, tropical storms, and earthquakes, along with socioeconomic vulnerability information. It provides decision-makers with interactive maps and charts to support disaster risk reduction and social assistance programs for the asset Platform for Real-Time Impact and Situation Monitoring (PRISM).

This dataset contains information on countries, commodities, and markets, sourced from the World Food Programme Price Database. Due to the large volume of data, the actual food prices are provided in country-level datasets. The World Food Programme Price Database includes data on foods such as maize, rice, beans, fish, and sugar, covering 98 countries and approximately 3,000 markets. The database is updated weekly, though much of the data is reported on a monthly basis. Historical data is available as far back as 1992 for a few countries, while many others began reporting from 2003 or later.

The WFP Innovation Forum is a global platform that showcases groundbreaking solutions to address food insecurity and humanitarian challenges. Bringing together innovators, humanitarian actors, private sector leaders, and policymakers, the forum highlights cutting-edge technologies, from AI-powered disaster response to sustainable agriculture, that are transforming the way hunger and crises are tackled around the world.

The Multi-Sectoral Needs Assessment (MSNA) is a standardized, country-level data collection initiative designed to capture comprehensive multi-sectoral needs among crisis-affected populations. Implemented by IMPACT Initiatives through its REACH Initiative, the MSNA collects statistically representative, household-level data on sectors such as food security, health, shelter, WASH, education, and protection. While the initiative is closely coordinated with OCHA and humanitarian clusters in country-led responses, the technical design, survey implementation, and analysis are primarily led by REACH/IMPACT, with operational support from agencies like IOM , WFP or IMMAP.

fields.Org Description: The Netherlands Red Cross‘ data and digital unit 510 aims to help every National Red Cross and Red Crescent Society in need anywhere. It is named after the total surface area of the earth (510 million square kilometres). 510 started in 2016 with a core team of 3 and never stopped growing. Currently, 510 has more than 100 team members, of whom 70+ are professional volunteers and academic students.

fields.Project Description: A new generation risk data initiative is shining a light on where climate, conflict, and displacement risks collide across sub-Saharan Africa, North Africa, and the Middle East (MENA). By integrating these drivers into one analytical stream, it delivers actionable insights tailored to conflict-affected and climate-vulnerable populations, filling critical gaps and enabling anticipatory action. Led by the Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre, together with the Netherlands Red Cross’ 510 Initiative and the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), the risk data supports more informed and anticipatory decision-making across the humanitarian system.

Each year, disasters around the world kill nearly 100,000 people and affect or displace 200 million more. Many of the locations where these disasters occur are not represented on open and accessible maps, leaving first responders without the critical information needed to make informed decisions about relief efforts. Missing Maps is an open, collaborative project designed to map areas where humanitarian organizations are working to address the needs of people living at risk of disasters and crises. This initiative enables volunteers to contribute to mapping efforts, helping to ensure that vulnerable communities are visible and better supported during emergencies.

The 510 Data Team supports innovation by implementing data science projects focused on disaster preparedness, local early warning systems, and the development of big data tools throughout the Red Cross network.

The support provided is flexible and demand driven. It also follows a human centered process, ensuring that client needs and the local context drive the definition of NLRC's support. The identified needs must be realistic in scope, must be within the ability of the NLRC to answer and finally, there must be a clear commitment from the recipient NS to engage proactively with NLRC throughout the project. The countries that will ultimately receive support through this project have not yet been determined but are expected to primarily be in the MENA (Middle East and Northern Africa) regions. Based on the knowledge collected and the changing dynamic of the pandemic, we anticipate that recipient national societies will request data and digital support in the following (generic) areas:
1.	Continuation of crucial data & digital support for NS for emergency support products
2.	Support NS data and digital support for Covid vaccination campaign. 
3.	Compounding disasters:  disaster response complicated by to the Covid pandemic
4.	Cash IM support

Through the 510 Data & Digital Team NLRC assists 19 RCRC National Societies in their short-term preparedness and response to COVID-19 and supported their operational continuity, through data and digital. This support was made possible through a 12-month block funded project that started implementation on 1 April 2020. At the time of writing (2 months before the end of the project) several countries are encountering a renewed increase of infections. New uncertainties are introduced by the virus mutations, underlining that the Covid response phase is far from over. With the approval of several vaccines and the start of vaccination campaigns in countries around the world, the focus is beginning to shift from response to recovery. The road however remains long and based on the achievements of the 2020 global COVID program and the feedback received the added value of continued data and digital support beyond the current project's end date, 31 March 2021, is clear.

NLRC, through its 510 initiative provides remote technical assistance to RCRC national societies. IFRC will be involved to coordinate the support provided to countries in the MENA region and will itself also receive data & digital support from NLRC/510.

The goal is to plan and implement demonstration of the concepts developed within S(P)EEDKITS. The project develops concepts for e.g. health care and sanitation solutions, infrastructural solutions, and shelter units.

The S(P)EEDKIT concept offers rapid humanitarian solutions – rapid deployment of shelters, facilities and medical care resources following major disasters - for self-recovery of communities. Currently, several developments have resulted in early field testing and deployment. The Netherlands Red Cross (NLRC), Médecins sans Frontières (MSF) and the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), all partners within S(P)EEDKITS, have on-going field operations. Selected solutions can be tested in these humanitarian operations, usually in situations where infrastructure is poor and skilled labour scarce.

The focus will be on different levels of demonstration, focusing on key developments of S(P)EEDKITS at the different packaging levels (container, pallet, and bag), demonstration of rapid deployment, field testing of selected kits. The selected kits are shelter units, wash solutions (sanitation-, water -, and add-on kits), and infrastructural solutions. The aim is to demonstrate transportability and rapid deployment of the kits in an operational field context.

Partners in the S(p)eedkit project are: Médecins sans Frontières (MSF), The Netherlands Red Cross (NLRC), the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies Shelter Research Unit (IFRC-SRU) and the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC).
Globally: the conditions for actual field deployment can vary rapidly.

fields.Project Description: The Rapid Assessment Data project accelerates the reporting of conflict-related violence in fragile settings by automating data gathering from open and established sources and integrating Machine Learning (ML) driven analysis. The project’s impacts include enhanced risk assessment, more targeted interventions, and the empowerment of at-risk populations to advocate for protective measures.

name: CRED: Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters

fields.Org Full Name: CRED: Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters
fields.Org Description: The Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters (CRED  has been active for over 50 years and is recognized as a reference institution in the field of disasters and emergency situations: CRED promotes research, training, and technical expertise in humanitarian emergencies, particularly in public health and epidemiology. Its main research topic is natural disasters. By providing a wealth of data related to health, the centre aims to improve disasters preparedness and response. CRED is managing the EM-DAT database, quantifying the occurrence, human and economic impacts associated with natural and technological disasters.

fields.Agency/Department Name: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

fields.Project Description: EM-DAT compiles free, searchable global records of natural and technological disasters dating back to 1900. It provides standardized event-level data that is extensively used in disaster risk research, policy analysis, and early warning modeling.

fields.Project Description: UNFPA, the United Nations Population Fund, works globally to ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health, prevent and respond to gender-based violence, collect and use population data, and promote gender equality and the empowerment of women and youth across the humanitarian and development continuum.

The Population Data Portal serves as UNFPA’s comprehensive data source and tracker for population and development statistics. It brings together the latest data on topics such as sexual and reproductive health and rights, family planning, maternal health, and gender-based violence, collected from a variety of sources. The portal provides users with reliable, up-to-date information to support research, policy-making, and program development in the field of population and development.

fields.Project/Product Name: GRID3: Geo-Referenced Infrastructure and Demographic Data for Development
fields.Project Description: GRID3 provides high-resolution geospatial data, including population estimates, infrastructure mapping, and administrative boundaries, to support governments and organizations in planning, monitoring, and delivering services effectively.

The World Population Dashboard presents comprehensive global population data, including statistics on fertility rates, gender parity in school enrolment, and information related to sexual and reproductive health, among other key indicators. These data collectively provide insight into the health and rights of populations worldwide, with a particular focus on women and young people. The figures are sourced from UNFPA and other United Nations agencies, and are updated on an annual basis.

fields.Project Description: The Transformative Outcomes project deploys an interactive web platform and standardized analysis toolkit to deliver high-quality crisis data for vulnerable populations in conflict-affected settings. This promotes evidence-based planning, targeted interventions, and capacity building among local actors, humanitarian agencies, and policymakers. CRAF’d funding supports data collection in six pilot countries, platform development, and training, catalyzing scalable, accessible data as a global public good.

armed groups. Led by the University of Denver in

UN Women’s strategy for change, Women Count, seeks to bring about a radical shift in how gender statistics are used, created, and promoted. The initiative aims to transform the landscape of gender data by improving the production, accessibility, and utilization of gender statistics. Women Count works to ensure that reliable and comprehensive gender data informs policies, programs, and decision-making processes, ultimately advancing gender equality and empowering women and girls globally.

fields.Org Description: The US Geological Survey maintains extensive data services and conducts numerous data-related projects across various fields, including mapping mineral resources, analyzing global supply chains, and conducting environmental monitoring and research. Projects often involve collaborations with other governmental agencies, universities, and private companies. For example, USGS offers technical assistance internationally, with expertise in areas like seismic monitoring and water resource assessment. Their Community for Data Integration (CDI) supports data-driven research by funding projects that enhance data analysis tools, such as the Terrestrial Remote Sensing Data Ingestion with PyHAT, which facilitates the use of multiple terrestrial datasets for machine learning analysis.

fields.Project Description: USGS systems offer real-time search and visualization of earthquake data, global hazards, and geophysical datasets. These systems support crisis response and scientific analysis through open APIs. The Earthquakes Maps asset provides users with interactive tools to explore recent seismic activity, access detailed event information, and analyze geophysical trends, facilitating informed decision-making and research.

name: UNODA: United Nations Office for Disarmament Affairs

fields.Org Full Name: UNODA: United Nations Office for Disarmament Affairs
fields.Org Description: UNODA provides substantive and organizational support for norm-setting in the area of disarmament through the work of the General Assembly and its First Committee, the Disarmament Commission, the Conference on Disarmament and other bodies. It fosters disarmament measures through dialogue, transparency and confidence-building on military matters, and encourages regional disarmament efforts; these include the United Nations Register of Conventional Arms and regional forums.

fields.Project Description: The UN General Assembly established the UN Register of Conventional Arms (UNROCA) in 1991 through resolution 46/36 L to promote transparency in armaments. Through the UNROCA instrument, Member States are requested, on an annual basis, to report their international transfers of seven categories of major conventional arms, as well as small arms and light weapons. They may also provide additional background information, such as data on military holdings and procurement through national production. To date, 175 Member States have reported to the UNROCA instrument at least once. In light of relatively consistent reporting by the world’s largest arms exporters, it is estimated that the Register captures around 90 percent of the volume of the global arms trade.

fields.Project/Product Name: United Nations Report on Military Expenditures (UNMilEx)
fields.Project Description: UNODA publishes annual data on military spending from Member States, informing arms control and global transparency through structured datasets.

fields.Org Description: Global Pulse is an initiative of the United Nations focused on harnessing big data, artificial intelligence, and emerging technologies to support sustainable development and humanitarian action. The organization collaborates with UN agencies, governments, and partners worldwide to analyze real-time data and generate insights that inform decision-making. By leveraging advanced analytics, Global Pulse aims to improve crisis response, monitor global trends, and promote data-driven policies.

fields.Project Description: Data Insights for Social & Humanitarian Action, also known as DISHA, is a multi-partner initiative led by UN Global Pulse, the Secretary-General’s Innovation Lab. The initiative aims to accelerate ethical and responsible access to data and artificial intelligence (AI) solutions in order to unlock social impact at scale.

fields.Org Description: The University of Edinburgh is a public research university based in Edinburgh, Scotland. Founded by the town council under the authority of a royal charter from King James VI in 1582 and officially opened in 1583, it is one of Scotland's four ancient universities and the sixth-oldest university in continuous operation in the English-speaking world.

fields.Project Description: PeaceRep distributes the PA-X Tracker, an innovative digital tool designed to provide data-driven insights that support peace and transition processes. The suite of PeaceTech tools within the PA-X Tracker enables users to track and monitor the progress and implementation of peace and transition initiatives. The Tracker offers a comprehensive understanding of how peace processes are unfolding, identifies the stakeholders involved, and assesses the impact of these processes across a range of institutional, political, economic, humanitarian, and security indicators.

fields.Org Description: Humanitarian Outcomes is an independent research organisation providing evidence and policy advice to inform better humanitarian action.

fields.Project Description: GDHO is a global compendium of organisations that provide aid in humanitarian crises. The database includes basic organisational and operational information on these humanitarian providers, which include international non-governmental organisations (grouped by federation), national NGOs that deliver aid within their own borders, UN humanitarian agencies, and the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement.

CORE is the latest data-driven initiative by Humanitarian Outcomes to provide quantifiable measures on the size of the humanitarian sector as well as its capacity and reach in crisis-affected countries.

The Aid Worker Security Database (AWSD) records major incidents of violence against aid workers, with incident reports spanning from 1997 to the present. Initiated in 2005, the AWSD remains the sole comprehensive global source of these data, providing the evidence base for analysis of the changing security environment for civilian aid operations.

fields.Org Description: The University of Stirling builds its academic identity around research-informed social science, environmental studies, and behavioral science, integrating interdisciplinary approaches with a campus designed to support empirical fieldwork, sports science development, and public policy analysis.

fields.Project Description: PeaceRep distributes the PA-X Tracker, an innovative digital tool designed to provide data-driven insights that support peace and transition processes. The suite of PeaceTech tools within the PA-X Tracker enables users to track and monitor the progress and implementation of peace and transition initiatives. The Tracker offers a comprehensive understanding of how peace processes are unfolding, identifies the stakeholders involved, and assesses the impact of these processes across a range of institutional, political, economic, humanitarian, and security indicators.

fields.Org Description: UNDP works in about 170 countries and territories, helping to eradicate poverty, reduce inequalities and exclusion, and build resilience so countries can sustain progress. As the UN’s development agency, UNDP plays a critical role in helping countries achieve the Sustainable Development Goals.

fields.Project Description: The Risk Anticipation Data Hub, a project of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), is a transformative open-access data platform. This comprehensive data warehouse contains over 15,000 indicators, integrating processed and cleaned public datasets that cover a wide range of risk factors. Utilizing advanced technology, including a generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) interface and real-time analytics, the Data Hub provides ecosystem partners with essential data and insights. These resources support improved crisis anticipation, prevention, and response, enabling more informed decision-making and effective action.

INFORM Warning is a state-of-the-art, innovative global risk monitoring tool designed to anticipate complex risks up to a year in advance, directly linked to crisis funding instruments. It transcends traditional methods by presenting multi-hazard information from diverse sources. Its unique analysis offers insights into risk trends, forecasts, scenarios, and potential events leading to crisis impact.

The Data Futures Exchange is an open-source platform designed to serve as a central hub for data innovation, with a particular emphasis on development impact. The platform is aligned with the thematic priorities of the United Nations Development Programme and utilizes a systemic approach combined with advanced analytics to identify actions that accelerate sustainable development on a global scale.

title_narrative: Promoting Local Development in Cabo Verde
description_narrative: This project strengthens local development in Cabo Verde by addressing gaps in social and financial service delivery and leveraging local and regional potential. It focuses on three key outcomes:1. Increased local revenue to support development agendas;2. Enhanced capacity of local and national actors to improve development outcomes and impact;3. Reinforced local development through improved planning and targeted projects across all 22 municipalities.

description_narrative: Le projet consiste dans un appui à: 1-   la création des POS et des outils relatifs à l’anticipation, la préparation et la réponse aux crises extérieures potentielles ;2-  le développement de la plateforme d’alerte précoce ;3-   la mise en place d’un plan de renforcement des capacités du personnel du MAECNE, qui inclurait une visite d’immersion dans un centre opérationnel spécialisé en gestion de crises au profit de cadres, en fonction des nécessités pédagogiques et techniques du module.

title_narrative: Development of digital gender smart public services
description_narrative: Development of digital gender smart public services. The project aims build on the existing experience and develop and automate digital public services for population and businesses.

The overall purpose of the proposal is to respond to the Governments need for a technical assistance in preparation for and development of a viable and large-scale intervention on creation of multi-hazard early warning system (MHEWS). The MHEWS will integrate risks from natural disasters and climate change induced risks, including droughts, sand and salty dust storms, floods, mudslides, gusty winds, heatwaves, extreme cold and ice phenomena, among others to inform the population and key sectors of national economy for timely prevention, adaptation and decision-making process.

title_narrative: Acceleration of digital transformation in Turkmenistan
description_narrative: Turkmenistan stands at a critical juncture in its digital transformation, with the Government demonstrating a clear strategic commitment to economic diversification and digital innovation through its key policy frameworks. However, unlocking the full potential of digital technologies requires overcoming persistent structural challenges. These include gaps in digital infrastructure, an evolving policy environment, limited investments in systemic reforms, and the need for stronger institutional capacity to integrate advanced technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) and digital platforms. Addressing these constraints is essential to accelerating inclusive growth, enhancing global competitiveness, and positioning Turkmenistan as a regional leader in the digital economy. Gender-specific challenges and leveraging opportunities for women and marginalized groups is critical to ensuring an inclusive and equitable digital transformation.

title_narrative: ENGMT HDR Evidencebased insight to support SDG in B
description_narrative: Develop evidence-based subsidies (data platform, methodologies/tools, educational activities and studies /research, making use of advanced technologies and innovation) to enhance PNUD – CO in support to national and subnational governments capacity to formulate, monitor and evaluate public policies ,programmes and projects (including the ones developed in partnership with UNDP), as well as provide relevant inputs and tools for enhanced analytical capacity and decision-making by academia/think tanks, private sector and other national players and stakeholders, supporting national, regional and local development towards the SDGs.

title_narrative: Brazil’s G20 Finance Track readiness support
description_narrative: Founded in 1999 after the Asian crisis, the G20 brings together finance ministers and central bank governors to discuss global economic and financial issues. It is recognized as the leading forum for international economic cooperation with a focus on shaping and strengthening global architecture and governance on all major international economic issues. Composed of Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, China, France, Germany, India, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Mexico, Russia, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, Turkey, the United Kingdom, the United States and the European Union, the group will have Brazil as the hostess country in 2024 (from December 1, 2023 to November 30, 2024). One of the characteristics of the G20 is the existence of the so-called Sherpa and Finance tracks, with thematic sub-groups that meet regularly throughout the year, in dozens of face-to-face meetings in the country hosting the presidency.In particular, the Finance track is made up of the finance ministers or their equivalent and the presidents of the central banks of the member countries. These representatives discuss global economic and financial issues, such as fiscal policies, international trade, financial stability, and international financial architecture. Considering the urgency of time - the presidency begins in December 2023 - and the need to carry out short-term preparatory activities until the project is signed, it is considered opportune for UNDP to provide support in this preparatory phase.

title_narrative: UNDP's readiness support to Brazil's presidency G20
description_narrative: The purpose of this project is to provide support to Brazilian Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the preparatory activities for the G20 track.

title_narrative: Accelerating clean energy access to reduce inequality
description_narrative: The solar-powered water system for Atauro Island is being rehabilitated to deliver clean, reliable water to its 1,259 residents in Suco Beloi and Suco Biqueli. The original system failed because it couldn’t handle the island’s steep terrain and hydrology, which ranges from 8 meters at Adara Aldea to 328 meters at the main water source
In the UNDP’s portfolio of value-based economic models, UNDP is adopting an exploratory and experimental approach to introduce, test schemes toward value-based economy in the State of Palestine.
PAPP’s engagement facility provides a rapid and flexible response mechanism to support upstream policy results, crisis responses and the testing of innovations with scale-up potential.

fields.Org Description: The Centre for Humanitarian Data is focused on increasing the use and impact of data in the humanitarian sector. It is managed by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). As part of OCHA’s Information Management Branch, the Centre’s role is to enable the organization to deliver on its ambition to be more data-driven and analytical, and to ensure a responsible approach to technology and data management.

fields.Project Description: HXL is a simple standard designed for messy data. It uses HXL hashtags to accelerate data processing and enable interoperability across various data sources.

The Humanitarian Data Forum provides an opportunity for members of the data community to reconnect and collaborate. The inaugural Forum, held in The Hague, brought together over 160 participants from 42 countries to help shape the future of humanitarian data. Attendees represented a diverse range of organizations, including UN agencies, local and global NGOs, governments, the private sector, and academia.

Managed by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) is a centralized platform for sharing humanitarian data. It offers access to over 20,000 datasets from more than 300 organizations, covering themes such as population, conflict, health, and displacement. HDX includes the Data Grid and the COVID-19 Data Explorer, and it plays a crucial role in promoting data transparency, interoperability, and informed decision-making in humanitarian settings.

The initial scope of HDX HAPI was aligned with that of the HDX Data Grids, focusing on providing the foundational data required to understand humanitarian contexts. Over time, the scope of HDX HAPI has expanded beyond the original Data Grids to encompass a broader range of data. A live dashboard is available to monitor data availability by country.

HDX Signals is a product and service provided by the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) that monitors key datasets and generates automated notifications via email when significant, negative changes are detected. The system is designed to support timely decision-making by alerting users to important shifts in humanitarian data.

description_narrative: The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) opened its branch in Côte d'Ivoire in 2011 in response to the post-election crisis. This crisis, which shook the country between November 2010 and May 2011, affected more than two million people, causing the displacement of more than 600,000 people inside the country and more than 180,000 new Ivorian refugees to countries of the sub-region. Since 2011, the situation in Côte d'Ivoire has improved significantly in political, security and socio-economic terms. Most internally displaced persons (IDPs) have returned to their villages of origin and humanitarian actors continue to support the gradual and voluntary return and sustainable reintegration of refugees and IDPs. OCHA's expertise continues to be sought in the context of emergency preparedness, to develop inter-agency contingency plans in the face of the various climate risks that threaten the country. The transition from emergency to development, which began in 2013, first resulted in the transfer of responsibility for strategic humanitarian coordination to the government, through the establishment of the Extended Coordination Committee (CCE) which brings together government officials with humanitarian actors and development partners. In support of government efforts, OCHA supports and coordinates the development of preparedness and response plans (disaster risk reduction, Ebola, evictions from classified forests, etc.) and facilitates training related to emergency preparedness. OCHA is also very active in establishing an innovative and sustainable partnership between the authorities, humanitarian actors and the private sector in Côte d'Ivoire.

Le Bureau de la coordination des affaires humanitaires (OCHA) des Nations Unies a ouvert son antenne en Côte d’Ivoire en 2011 en réponse à la crise post-électorale. Cette crise, qui a secoué le pays entre novembre 2010 et mai 2011, a affecté plus de deux millions de personnes, provoquant le déplacement de plus de 600 000 personnes à l’intérieur du pays et de plus de 180 000 nouveaux réfugiés ivoiriens vers les pays de la sous-région. Depuis 2011, la situation de la Côte d’Ivoire s’est nettement améliorée sur les plans politique, sécuritaire et socio-économique. La plupart des personnes déplacées internes (PDI) sont retournées dans leurs villages d’origine et les acteurs humanitaires continuent de soutenir le retour progressif et volontaire et la réintégration durable des réfugiés et des PDI. L'expertise d'OCHA continue d’être sollicitée dans le cadre de la préparation à l'urgence, pour développer les plans de contingence inter-agences face aux différents risques climatiques qui menacent le pays. La transition de l’urgence au développement, amorcée en 2013, s’est d’abord traduite par la passation de la responsabilité de la coordination humanitaire stratégique au gouvernement, à travers la mise en place du Comité de Coordination Elargi (CCE) qui réunit les représentants du gouvernement avec les acteurs humanitaires et les partenaires au développement.En soutien aux efforts du gouvernement, OCHA appui et coordonne le développement des plans de préparation et de réponse (réduction des risques des catastrophes, Ebola, déguerpissements des forêts classées, etc.) et facilite des formations liées à la préparation à l'urgence. OCHA est en outre très actif pour établir un partenariat innovant et durable entre les autorités, les acteurs humanitaires et le secteur privé en Côte d’Ivoire.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) public and private advocacy raises awareness of forgotten crises, promotes respect for international humanitarian law (IHL), brings the voices of crisis-affected people to the forefront, and helps people obtain access to humanitarian assistance. To OCHA, advocacy means communicating the right messages to the right people at the right time. These people include humanitarian agencies, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), community-based organizations, national governments, local and international media, parties to conflict, companies, donors, regional bodies, communities affected by emergencies and the general public. The aim is that they increase urgent funding or support, change their policies or keep to their commitments.

title_narrative: OCHA Headquarter, Information Management, Front Office
description_narrative: OCHA provides information management services to the humanitarian community to inform a rapid, effective, and principled response. It gathers, shares, and uses data and information, underpinning coordination, decision-making, and advocacy. OCHA’s role in information management is unique, differing from the role of other UN agencies or humanitarian actors because it is responsible for consolidating and publishing information across the whole spectrum of humanitarian response so that local and international actors can use the information to make life-saving policy and operational decisions.

title_narrative: OCHA Field activities, Caucasus and Central Asia (regional)
OCHA Field activities, Caucasus and Central Asia (regional)
description_narrative: The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Regional Office for the Caucasus and Central Asia (ROCCA) was based in Almaty, Kazakhstan. The office has been closed since 2018 and integrated in OCHA ROAP. During its mandate, OCHA ROCCA improved levels of preparedness in the region through early warning and contingency planning, ensuring the inclusion of all relevant key partners. OCHA ROCCA made sure that Governments, civil society and international actors are well prepared, so that in the face of slow- or sudden-onset emergencies, the entire humanitarian community joins efforts to assist affected people. In slow- or sudden-onset disasters or crises, OCHA ROCCA provided specialized support to country offices and partners within its areas of expertise, including surge teams, emergency response coordination, information management, advocacy and resource mobilization.

Региональный офис Управления по координации гуманитарных вопросов (УКГВ) для Кавказа и Центральной Азии (РОКЦА) базировался в Алматы, Казахстан. Офис был закрыт в 2018 году и интегрирован в Гуманитарную консультативную группу УКГВ в Таджикистане. В течение своей работы УКГВ РОКЦА повысил уровень готовности в регионе за счет раннего предупреждения и планирования на случай непредвиденных обстоятельств, обеспечив привлечение всех соответствующих ключевых партнеров. УКГВ РОКЦА позаботился о том, чтобы правительства, гражданское общество и международные организации были хорошо подготовлены, и чтобы перед лицом медленно наступающих или внезапных чрезвычайных ситуаций все гуманитарное сообщество объединяло усилия для оказания помощи пострадавшим. В случае медленно наступающих или внезапных стихийных бедствий или кризисов, УКГВ РОКЦА оказывал специализированную поддержку страновым отделениям и партнерам в областях своей компетенции, включая экстренные группы поддержки, координацию реагирования на чрезвычайные ситуации, управление информацией, пропаганду и мобилизацию ресурсов

description_narrative: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) involvement in Pakistan began in 1987, when an office was set up in Peshawar to support the organization’s Afghanistan operations. This office was moved to Afghanistan in 2003. In 2005, an office was officially established in Pakistan to respond to the devastating earthquake in the north. OCHA’s presence was scaled back in the ensuing years, but the organization re-established an office in 2009 to assist over 3 million people displaced by insecurity in the north-west. OCHA provides comprehensive support to the humanitarian community in activities related to coordinating emergency preparedness planning, humanitarian response, disaster risk reductionand resilience. OCHA also ensures coordination with national and international NGOs through their umbrella groups. These include the Pakistan Humanitarian Forum, which is an alliance of 57 INGOs, and the National Humanitarian Network, which is a consortium of more than 180 national NGOs. Through knowledge sharing and training, OCHA also helps strengthen the capacity of national and international stakeholders to respond to emergencies. Given the likely recurrence of natural disasters and crises in Pakistan, OCHA continues to work closely with the government and humanitarian partners to ensure an effective response to future crises.

description_narrative: The Philippines is one of the most disaster prone countries in the world. Annually, an average of 22 tropical cyclones enter the Philippine Area of Responsibility of which around 6 to 7 cause significant damage. Conflicts in Mindanao also cause intermittent cycles of forced displacement. In 2007, Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) established a presence in Manila to complement the Government’s response to natural disasters and to strengthen humanitarian coordination. In September 2009, Tropical Storm Ketsana devastated Metro Manila, prompting the Emergency Relief Coordinator to appoint the Resident Coordinator as also the Humanitarian Coordinator. OCHA’s presence in the Philippines was upgraded to a country office in 2010, with a dual focus: emergency response preparedness and response to sudden onset emergencies and the protracted conflict situation in Mindanao.

description_narrative: The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Country Office in Eritrea was established in 2000 following the 1998-2000 border conflict with Ethiopia. Since that date, programmes and projects of an urgent or humanitarian nature have been built into the United Nations Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF) and, since 2013, the joint UN-GoSE Strategic Partnership Cooperation Framework (SPCF). OCHA has been coordinating humanitarian response on an annual basis, which constitutes part of the five-year development cooperation framework. Working closely with the UN Country Team (UNCT) in Eritrea, the OCHA Country Office coordinates humanitarian analysis, prioritization and response through the projects of UN agencies which work closely with their Government implementing partners, and in the absence of INGOs. OCHA’s presence in Eritrea ensures that urgent and humanitarian issues are integrated into wider development processes. In coordination with the UNCT and the RCO, OCHA also facilitates the UNCT’s preparedness and contingency planning processes. Furthermore, OCHA expertise in information management ensures production of regular resource mobilization data, snapshots and analysis on behalf of the UNCT, as well as assisting UN agencies and partners with visualization, GIS and mapping services. OCHA Eritrea supports the resource mobilization efforts of the UNCT, with particular focus on urgent response and basic services. This is done through OCHA’s own engagements with donors, as well as support to the Resident Coordinator /Humanitarian Coordinator and UNCT in their resource mobilization efforts. OCHA maintains close and regular contacts with both resident and non-resident embassies and donor partners, providing regular updates and briefings. OCHA also coordinates CERF applications and processes in support of allocations for Eritrea.

Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) does not have country offices in the region but has a Humanitarian Advisory Team in Madagascar since OCHA Southern Africa has been integrated in OCHA Regional Office for Southern and Eastern Africa (ROSEA). OCHA ROSEA works to strengthen collaboration on emergency preparedness and response with regional bodies, such as the Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) in Southern Africa.

OCHA also promotes and advances the normative framework for international humanitarian action while developing, strengthening and advancing this framework. Policy development aims to support effective and principled humanitarian action, saving lives and reducing suffering

description_narrative: The Pacific is one of the most disaster-prone regions in the world. Small, vulnerable island states are isolated by vast expanses of ocean. They experience frequent and intense disasters with disproportionately high economic, social and environmental consequences. In 1999, Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) established an office for the Pacific (OP) to mobilize and coordinate effective and principled humanitarian action in partnership with national and international actors. The first responders in any emergency are disaster-affected people and their governments. OCHA’s key objective is to support national efforts to protect the lives, livelihoods and dignity of people in need. International assistance can only be mobilized when a request is made by the affected government. OCHA OP personnel can provide support in information management, reporting, mapping, media and communications, assessments, humanitarian financing and inter-cluster coordination. OCHA can deploy UNDAC teams at short notice to assist in the coordination of incoming international relief at the earliest stages of an emergency.

description_narrative: The humanitarian situation in Venezuela was the result of seven consecutive years of economic contraction, periods of hyperinflation, political polarization and institutional challenges. The pandemic deepened the needs of people due to the impact on essential services such as health care, water, gas and electricity. The food insecurity situation was also aggravated. The office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Assistance coordinated assistance to people across the country, mostly to provide health, water, sanitation, hygiene, protection and education services.  Office for the Coordination on Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) played a leading role in integrating cross-cutting issues in the response, such as gender and protection, and in strengthening accountability to affected people (AAP) and protection from sexual exploitation and abuse (PSEA). The HCT adopted the Collective AAP Framework and the protocol that defines procedures for submitting PSEA complaint.

La situación humanitaria en Venezuela es el resultado de siete años consecutivos de contracción económica, períodos de hiperinflación, polarización política y desafíos institucionales. La pandemia profundizó las necesidades de la población debido al impacto en los servicios esenciales como la atención sanitaria, el agua, el gas y la electricidad. También se agravó la situación de inseguridad alimentaria. La Oficina de Coordinación de Asuntos Humanitarios (OCHA) coordinó la asistencia a la población en todo el territorio nacional, principalmente para proporcionar servicios de salud, agua, saneamiento, higiene, protección y educación. OCHA desempeñó un papel protagónico en la integración de cuestiones transversales en la respuesta, como el género y la protección, y en el fortalecimiento de la rendición de cuentas a las personas afectadas (AAP, por su sigla en inglés) y la protección contra la explotación y el abuso sexual (PSEA, por su sigla en inglés). El EHP adoptó el Marco Colectivo de AAP y el protocolo que define los procedimientos para la presentación de denuncias sobre PSEA.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Headquarters (HQ) Central Cost Unit provides the funding for HQ rental charges, utilities and other premises costs.  It also includes other centralized corporate services such as Human Resources, Procurement and implementation of Umoja extension.

L'unité centrale des coûts du Bureau de la coordination des affaires humanitaires (OCHA) fournit le financement des frais de location du siège, des services publics et d'autres frais de locaux. Il comprend également d'autres services centraux centralisés tels que les ressources humaines, les achats et la mise en œuvre de l'extension Umoja.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: In 2021, despite decrease in number of people in need, the vulnerabilities of the population in Burundi have increased compared to previous years due to the combined effects of recurring natural disasters, frequent epidemic outbreaks, the socioeconomic impacts of COVID-19, as well as increasing refugee returns. The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in Burundi played a coordination role for the emergency response and preparedness to climate disasters, including flooding in Bujumbura province, and epidemic outbreaks. It also coordinated the health response and the socio-economic response to the Covid-19 pandemic, combining emergency and longer-term development response.

En 2021, malgré la diminution du nombre de personnes dans le besoin, les vulnérabilités de la population au Burundi ont augmenté par rapport aux années précédentes en raison des effets combinés des catastrophes naturelles récurrentes, des épidémies fréquentes, des impacts socio-économiques de la COVID-19, ainsi que de l'augmentation du retour des réfugiés. Le Bureau de la coordination des affaires humanitaires (OCHA) au Burundi a joué un rôle de coordination pour la réponse d'urgence et la préparation aux catastrophes climatiques, notamment les inondations dans la province de Bujumbura, et aux épidémies. Il a également coordonné la réponse sanitaire et la réponse socio-économique à la pandémie de Covid-19, en combinant une réponse d'urgence et de développement à plus long terme.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Despite 2016 the Peace Agreement between the Government and the FARC-EP ending decades of civil war and progress in improving economic and social conditions, Colombia continues to face numerous humanitarian challenges. In some regions of the country, hostilities and armed violence continue, with significant humanitarian impact and protection challenges. This situation is further exacerbated by the impact of natural disasters, presence of landmines and unexploded ordnance and, now, the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The latter has led to an increase in the number of food-insecure people from 3.3 million to over 10 million. So far in 2020, the humanitarian community in Colombia has provided assistance – including COVID-19 related assistance – to almost a million people. Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) currently supports a humanitarian coordination architecture consisting of around 120 partners, including UN agencies, national and international NGOs, the Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement, civil society, donors and national institutions.

A pesar de que en 2016 el Acuerdo de Paz entre el Gobierno y las FARC-EP puso fin a décadas de guerra civil y de los avances en la mejora de las condiciones económicas y sociales, Colombia sigue enfrentándose a numerosos retos humanitarios. En algunas regiones del país, las hostilidades y la violencia armada continúan, con un impacto humanitario significativo y con desafíos de protección. Esta situación se ve agravada por el impacto de los desastres de origen natural, la presencia de minas terrestres y municiones sin explotar y, ahora, el impacto de la pandemia COVID-19. Esta última ha provocado un aumento del número de personas en situación de inseguridad alimentaria de 3,3 millones a más de 10 millones. En lo que va de 2020, la comunidad humanitaria de Colombia ha prestado asistencia -incluida la relacionada con la COVID-19- a casi un millón de personas. La Oficina de Coordinación de Asuntos Humanitarios (OCHA) apoya actualmente una arquitectura de coordinación humanitaria formada por unos 120 socios, entre los que se encuentran organismos de la ONU, ONG nacionales e internacionales, el Movimiento de la Cruz Roja y la Media Luna Roja, la sociedad civil, donantes e instituciones nacionales.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Cameroon is affected by three simultaneous protection crises that are exacerbating the humanitarian situation of affected people. Increased violence in the Lake Chad Basin and in the North-West and South-West regions continues to cause internal displacement. Moreover, hundreds of refugees from the Central African Republic (CAR) have found shelter in the eastern regions of Cameroon and rely on life-saving and life-sustaining humanitarian assistance. Since 2015, humanitarian organizations have been jointly working with the Government to scale up the response in Cameroon.  Office for the Coordination on Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) supports more than 170 humanitarian organizations that are providing emergency assistance to crisis-affected people. The main focus of the humanitarian response operation will continue to be providing life-saving assistance and protection to affected populations, promoting long-term voluntary and safe durable solutions when relevant and feasible, and strengthening early recovery and community resilience.

Le Cameroun est affecté par trois crises de protection simultanées qui exacerbent la situation humanitaire des personnes affectées. L'augmentation de la violence dans le bassin du lac Tchad et dans les régions du Nord-Ouest et du Sud-Ouest continue de provoquer des déplacements internes. En outre, des centaines de réfugiés de la République Centrafricaine (RCA) ont trouvé refuge dans les régions de l'Est du Cameroun et comptent sur une aide humanitaire vitale et de survie. Depuis 2015, les organisations humanitaires travaillent conjointement avec le gouvernement pour intensifier la réponse au Cameroun.  Le Bureau de la Coordination des Affaires Humanitaires (OCHA) soutient plus de 170 organisations humanitaires qui fournissent une aide d'urgence aux personnes touchées par la crise. L'opération de réponse humanitaire continuera de se concentrer principalement sur la fourniture d'une assistance et d'une protection vitales aux populations touchées, la promotion de solutions durables volontaires et sûres à long terme lorsque cela est pertinent et faisable, et le renforcement du relèvement précoce et de la résilience des communautés.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Even before the pandemic began, 2020 was on track to be the most difficult year of the past decade for Burkina Faso. A succession of shocks linked to conflict and insecurity had driven more than 1 million people from their homes since early 2019.  And for the first time in 10 years, the country saw the re-emergence of critical food insecurity conditions in two provinces of the Sahel region.  Office for the Coordination on Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) gradually increased its capacity to support collective priorities for humanitarian coordination at the national and regional levels, securing dedicated capacity to provide leadership on humanitarian civil-military coordination, community engagement, Accountability to Affected People, Information Management and analysis, and protection from sexual exploitation and abuse (PSEA).

Avant même le début de la pandémie, 2020 semblait être l'année la plus difficile de la dernière décennie pour le Burkina Faso. Une succession de chocs liés au conflit et à l'insécurité avait poussé plus d'un million de personnes à quitter leur foyer depuis le début de 2019. Et pour la première fois en 10 ans, le pays a vu réapparaître des conditions d'insécurité alimentaire critiques dans deux provinces de la région du Sahel. Le Bureau de la Coordination des Affaires Humanitaires (OCHA) a progressivement augmenté sa capacité à soutenir les priorités collectives en matière de coordination humanitaire aux niveaux national et régional, en obtenant des capacités dédiées pour assurer le leadership en matière de coordination humanitaire civilo-militaire, d'engagement communautaire, de responsabilité envers les personnes affectées, de gestion et d'analyse de l'information, et de protection contre l'exploitation et les abus sexuels (PEAS).
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative: OCHA Field activities, Central African Republic
OCHA Field activities, Central African Republic
description_narrative: Central African Republic continues to face a serious protection crisis, with a steady increase in violations of human rights and international humanitarian law despite the signing of the Political Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in 2019. Those who suffer the most, they are the civilian populations. One in four Central Africans is displaced either within the country or to a neighboring country, and the waves of return of displaced and repatriated people have slowed considerably. Since last year, the number of people in need has increased from 2.6 million to 2.8 million (+8%). At the same time, the number of people in need of acute assistance is 12% higher than in 2020. In five years, CAR has never counted so many people in humanitarian distress. This increase is the direct consequence of the plunge in macroeconomic indicators, the advent of new pockets of violent conflict, the rise of food insecurity and the COVID-19 pandemic.

La RCA continue à faire face à une grave crise de protection, avec une augmentation constante des violations des droits humains et du droit international humanitaire malgré la signature de l'Accord Politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation en 2019. Ceux qui souffrent le plus, ce sont les populations civiles. Un Centrafricain sur quatre est déplacé soit à l'intérieur du pays ou dans un pays voisin, et les vagues de retour de personnes déplacées et rapatriées ont considérablement ralenti. Depuis l’année dernière, le nombre de personnes dans le besoin a augmenté, passant de 2,6 millions à 2,8 millions (+8%). En même temps, le nombre de personnes en besoin d’assistance aiguë est de 12% supérieur qu’en 2020. En cinq ans, jamais la RCA n’avait compté autant de personnes en situation de détresse humanitaire. Cette augmentation est la conséquence directe de la plongée des indicateurs macro-économiques, l’avènement de nouvelles poches de conflits violents, la montée de l’insécurité alimentaire et la pandémie de la COVID-19.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative: OCHA Headquarter, Humanitarian Financing, Front Office
description_narrative: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) aims to mobilize and engage the full range of financing instruments, mechanisms and partners to ensure that growing humanitarian needs are met, humanitarian leadership and coordination mechanisms are promoted at the country level, and the large array of global humanitarian financing mechanisms are complementary among themselves and coherent with development funding. OCHA works with humanitarian partners around the world to identify the most critical humanitarian needs, plan responses and determine the budgets needed to address them. OCHA also ensures more responsive, predictable and strategic humanitarian financing through its leadership of the Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) and Country-Based Pooled Funds (CBPFs) for the humanitarian system

Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) aims to mobilize and engage the full range of financing instruments, mechanisms and partners to ensure that growing humanitarian needs are met, humanitarian leadership and coordination mechanisms are promoted at the country level, and the large array of global humanitarian financing mechanisms are complementary among themselves and coherent with development funding. OCHA works with humanitarian partners around the world to identify the most critical humanitarian needs, plan responses and determine the budgets needed to address them. OCHA also ensures more responsive, predictable and strategic humanitarian financing through its leadership of the Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) and Country-Based Pooled Funds (CBPFs) for the humanitarian system
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative: OCHA Field activities, Middle East and North Africa (regional)
OCHA Field activities, Middle East and North Africa (regional)
description_narrative: The OCHA Regional Office for Middle East and North Africa (ROMENA) based in Cairo and Amman and covers 21 countries and territories spread across the region. Several countries in the Middle East and North Africa region are experiencing political, economic and social transformations which have resulted in humanitarian crises causing an increase in human suffering and vulnerability. The situation is further compounded by hazards and natural disasters such as earthquakes, drought and floods. In this regard, OCHA ROMENA works to support and strengthen humanitarian coordination and response preparedness in the region. In countries where OCHA maintains country office presence including Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, Libya, Syria, Turkey, Yemen and occupied Palestinian Territory, the regional office provides frontline surge capacity as required particularly to support escalating or sudden on-set emergencies. For countries without OCHA in-country presence, the ROMENA team aims to support national authorities, regional bodies, Resident Coordinators and UN Country Teams to strengthen emergency preparedness and response to effectively and efficiently respond to or prepare for emergency situations through physical deployment or remote support.

يقع مكتب أوتشا الإقليمي للشرق الأوسط وشمال إفريقيا في مدينتي القاهرة وعمان ويغطي 21 دولة وإقليمًا منتشرة في جميع أنحاء المنطقة. تشهد العديد من البلدان في منطقة الشرق الأوسط وشمال إفريقيا تحولات سياسية واقتصادية واجتماعية أدت إلى أزمات إنسانية تسببت في زيادة المعاناة الإنسانية والقابلية للتأثر بالكوارث. ومما يزيد الوضع تعقيدًا الأخطار والكوارث الطبيعية مثل الزلازل والجفاف والفيضانات. في هذا الصدد، يعمل مكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية في الشرق الأوسط وشمال أفريقيا على دعم وتعزيز التنسيق الإنساني والتأهب للاستجابة في المنطقة. أما في البلدان التي يحتفظ فيها مكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية بوجود مكتب قطري، بما في ذلك العراق والأردن ولبنان وليبيا وسوريا وتركيا واليمن والأراضي الفلسطينية المحتلة، فيوفر المكتب الإقليمي قدرة احتياطية على الخطوط الأمامية وفقًا للطلب خاصة لدعم حالات الطوارئ المتصاعدة أو المفاجئة. بالنسبة للبلدان التي ليس هناك تواجد لمكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية بها، يهدف فريق المكتب الإقليمي للشرق الاوسط وشمال أفريقيا إلى دعم السلطات الوطنية والهيئات الإقليمية والمنسقين المقيمين وفرق الأمم المتحدة القطرية لتعزيز التأهب والاستجابة لحالات الطوارئ وذلك للاستجابة بفعّالية وكفاءة لحالات الطوارئ أو الاستعداد لها من خلال نشر الفرق أو تقديم الدعم عن بعد.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: The humanitarian crisis in Borno, Adamawa and Yobe states in Nigeria’s north-east, that has spilled over into the Lake Chad region, remains among the most severe humanitarian crises in the world today. As Nigeria faces the unprecedented challenge of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, the humanitarian community is stepping up action to prevent the spread of the virus among communities already affected by conflict, chronic diseases and climate shocks.  Access constraints, congestion in IDP camps, and poor health and sanitation infrastructure are becoming even more challenging in the context of COVID-19. Along with the Nigerian authorities, humanitarian actors are taking action to continue delivering life-saving humanitarian assistance while maintaining prevention measures. Insecurity due to ongoing hostilities and military operations have led to waves of mass displacement and continue to impact humanitarian operations. Vast swaths of Borno State are considered high or very high risk for international humanitarian actors, often constraining access to desperately vulnerable communities.

The humanitarian crisis in Borno, Adamawa and Yobe states in Nigeria’s north-east, that has spilled over into the Lake Chad region, remains among the most severe humanitarian crises in the world today.
