reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: The current crisis in Libya is the result of conflict, political instability and a vacuum of effective governance, resulting in a further breakdown of functioning systems with considerable security, rule of law, social and economic consequences. Hundreds of thousands of people across the country are living in unsafe conditions and in volatile conflict areas, with little or no access to basic household goods and essential commodities, and with limited access to functioning basic services and utilities. This includes people exposed to violence and unable to access life-saving medical assistance, essential medicines, food, safe drinking water and sanitation, shelter and education
"تقوم أوتشا بتنسيق الاستجابة العالميةالطارئة لإنقاذ حياة الأشخاص وحمايةالناس أثناء الأزمات الإنسانيّة.نحن نناصر العمل الإنساني المبدئيوالفعّال مبادئ الذي يقوم به الجميعمن أجل الجميع."
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative: OCHA Jordan, support the response to the Syria crisis
OCHA Jordan, support the response to the Syria crisis
description_narrative: Office for the Coordination on Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Jordan coordinates the strategic planning of the Humanitarian Partnership Forum, on which UN agencies, development partners, international and local NGOs are represented. Increasingly, humanitarian and development goals are being pursued, beyond the refugee sphere, through complementary initiatives under the Humanitarian and Development Partners Group. The country office plays a core role in coordination with other humanitarian and development actors to define and implement the ‘Triple Nexus’ approach and localization agenda for Jordan. OCHA’s work in Jordan focuses on assisting the most vulnerable by coordinating the delivery of effective humanitarian aid and principled humanitarian action. To this end, OCHA contributes to humanitarian action in Jordan, focusing on three priority areas: humanitarian Coordination; humanitarian Financing; readiness/early Warning.

يقوم مكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية (أوتشا) في الأردن بتنسيق التخطيط الاستراتيجي لمنتدى الشراكة الإنسانية، الذي يمثّل فيه وكالات الأمم المتحدة وشركاء التنمية والمنظمات غير الحكومية الدولية والمحلية. ويتزايد السعي وراء الأهداف الإنسانية والإنمائية، ليتخطى نطاق اللاجئين، من خلال مبادرات تكميلية في إطار مجموعة شركاء التنمية والعمل الإنساني. كما يلعب المكتب القطري دورًا أساسيًا بالتنسيق مع الجهات الفاعلة الإنسانية والإنمائية الأخرى لتحديد وتنفيذ نهج "الترابط الثلاثي" وجدول أعمال التوطين للأردن. يركز عمل مكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية في الأردن على مساعدة الفئات الأكثر ضعفًا من خلال تنسيق إيصال المساعدات الإنسانية الفعّالة والعمل الإنساني القائم على المبادئ. وتحقيقًا لهذا الهدف، يساهم مكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية في العمل الإنساني في الأردن، مع التركيز على ثلاثة مجالات ذات الأولوية، وهي: التنسيق الإنساني؛ التمويل الإنساني؛ التأهب/الإنذار المبكّر.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) coordinates the global emergency response to save lives and protect people in humanitarian crises. We advocate for effective and principled humanitarian action by all, for all. With its partners, OCHA contributes to principled and effective humanitarian response through coordination, advocacy, policy, information management and humanitarian financing tools and services. OCHA’s country and regional offices are responsible for delivering the core functions in the field by leveraging functional expertise throughout the organization.

Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) coordinates the global emergency response to save lives and protect people in humanitarian crises. We advocate for effective and principled humanitarian action by all, for all. With its partners, OCHA contributes to principled and effective humanitarian response through coordination, advocacy, policy, information management and humanitarian financing tools and services. OCHA’s country and regional offices are responsible for delivering the core functions in the field by leveraging functional expertise throughout the organization.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative: OCHA Field activities, Latin America and the Caribbean (regional)
OCHA Field activities, Latin America and the Caribbean (regional)
description_narrative: El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras, countries that make up the North of Central America (NCA), bring together a series of humanitarian needs driven by shared conditions of high poverty, recurrent climate shocks, chronic violence, limited access to health services and migratory flows from and to within their countries, among other factors. The different needs produced by these long-standing conditions have formed a complex fabric of vulnerabilities that humanitarian action has sought to address with intersectoral approaches for several years. Despite achievements in providing holistic responses to multidimensional needs in the NCA, humanitarian action in these countries was forced to drastically reconfigure in 2020 in the face of the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic and seasonal most active hurricane ever recorded.

El Salvador, Guatemala y Honduras, países que conforman el Norte de Centroamérica (NCA), reúnen una serie de necesidades humanitarias impulsadas por condiciones compartidas de pobreza elevada, choques climáticos recurrentes, violencia crónica, acceso limitado a servicios de salud y flujos migratorios desde y dentro de sus países, entre otros factores. Las distintas necesidades producidas por estas condiciones de larga data han formado un tejido complejo de vulnerabilidades que la acción humanitaria ha buscado atender con abordajes intersectoriales desde hace varios años. Pese a los logros en brindar respuestas holísticas a las necesidades multidimensionales en el NCA, la acción humanitaria en estos países se vio obligada a reconfigurarse, de manera drástica, en el 2020 ante los impactos de la pandemia de la COVID-19 y de la temporada de huracanes más activa jamás registrada.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: OCHA's mission is to coordinate the global emergency response to save lives and protect people in humanitarian crises advocating for effective and principled humanitarian action by all, for all. OCHA coordinates humanitarian response to expand the reach of humanitarian action, improve prioritization and reduce duplication, ensuring that assistance and protection reach the people who need it most. OCHA plays a key role in operational coordination in crisis situations. This includes assessing situations and needs; agreeing common priorities; developing common strategies to address issues such as negotiating access, mobilizing funding and other resources; clarifying consistent public messaging; and monitoring progress.

La mission du Bureau de la coordination des affaires humanitaires (BCAH) est de coordonner la réponse d'urgence mondiale pour sauver des vies et protéger les personnes dans les crises humanitaires en plaidant pour une action humanitaire efficace et fondée sur des principes par tous, pour tous. OCHA coordonne la réponse humanitaire pour étendre la portée de l'action humanitaire, améliorer la hiérarchisation et réduire les doubles emplois, en veillant à ce que l'assistance et la protection parviennent aux personnes qui en ont le plus besoin. OCHA joue un rôle clé dans la coordination opérationnelle dans les situations de crise. Cela comprend l'évaluation des situations et des besoins; convenir de priorités communes; l'élaboration de stratégies communes pour résoudre des problèmes tels que la négociation de l'accès, la mobilisation de financements et d'autres ressources ; clarifier les messages publics cohérents ; et le suivi des progrès.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative: OCHA regional support to the Syria crisis
OCHA regional support to the Syria crisis
description_narrative: Jordan is a key strategic partner for the UN and the international community. An island of stability in a troubled region, it has been a generous host to refugees throughout its history. Since the onset of the Syrian crisis in 2011, over one million Syrians have fled into Jordan, of which 662,000 are registered refugees.  Office for the Coordination on Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) regional support to the Syria crisis continued to provide support in policy, planning, operational coordination and administrative services to humanitarian organizations across the response. It brings together humanitarian organizations working from within and outside Syria to develop a shared analysis, common objectives and a collective focus on results. The regional support focuses on enhancing its engagement and coordination with key regional stakeholders in the response, namely UN Regional Directors, international NGOs, Member States and donors.

الأردن شريك استراتيجي رئيسي للأمم المتحدة والمجتمع الدولي. فهي بمثابة جزيرة الاستقرار داخل منطقة مضطربة، وكانت على مدار تاريخها، مضيفة سخية للاجئين. منذ اندلاع الأزمة السورية في عام 2011، حيث فرّ أكثر من مليون سوري إلى الأردن، منهم 662 ألف لاجئ مسجّل. واستمر الدعم الإقليمي لمكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية (أوتشا) للأزمة السورية من خلال تقديم الدعم في مجالات السياسة والتخطيط والتنسيق التشغيلي والخدمات الإدارية للمنظمات الإنسانية عبر الاستجابة. فيجمع المكتب المنظمات الإنسانية العاملة من داخل سوريا وخارجها لتطوير تحليل مشترك وأهداف مشتركة والتركيز الجماعي على النتائج. ويركز الدعم الإقليمي على تعزيز مشاركته مع أصحاب المصلحة الإقليميين الرئيسيين في الاستجابة والتنسيق لها، ولا سيما مع المديرين الإقليميين للأمم المتحدة والمنظمات غير الحكومية الدولية والدول الأعضاء والجهات المانحة.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) was established in September 2004 in Chad by the United Nations Emergency Relief Coordinator (ERC) to provide a large-scale humanitarian response to nearly 200,000 people from Sudan neighbor (Darfur) between 2003 and 2004. The OCHA team in Chad works closely with the entire humanitarian community, which includes government entities at the national and provincial levels, 11 UN agencies, 48 ??international NGOs and 67 national NGOs. On the strength of the excellent collaboration resulting from these partnerships, OCHA plays an important role in coordinating the response to the various crises by setting up, whenever necessary, While working to ensure the maintenance of humanitarian space, OCHA is also working to strengthen the capacities of partners and to achieve greater coherence between humanitarian, development and peacebuilding activities through effective collaboration with all actors and by seeking the involvement of all, from the planning stage to the identification of priorities for humanitarian action in Chad. This active and inclusive partnership makes it possible to address, in a coordinated manner, the humanitarian consequences caused by the recurrent crises linked in particular to food insecurity and malnutrition, population movements, health emergencies, and the negative effects of climate change (floods and drought) and at the same time strengthen the resilience of populations.

Le Bureau de la Coordination des Affaires Humanitaires (OCHA) a été établi en septembre 2004 au Tchad par le Coordonnateur des Secours d'Urgence des Nations Unies (ERC) pour apporter une réponse humanitaire d’envergure à près de 200 000 personnes venues du Soudan voisin (Darfour) entre 2003 et 2004. L'équipe OCHA au Tchad travaille en étroite collaboration avec l'ensemble de la communauté humanitaire, qui comprend des entités gouvernementales aux niveaux national et provincial, 11 agences des Nations Unies, 48 ONG internationales et 67 ONG nationales. Fort d’une excellente collaboration issue de ces partenariats, OCHA joue un rôle important dans la coordination de la réponse aux différentes crises en mettant en place, chaque fois que nécessaire, des mécanismes de coordination de l’assistance humanitaire internationale adaptés au contexte et en appui au gouvernement pour apporter secours et assistance aux populations locales affectées. Tout en œuvrant pour assurer le maintien de l’espace humanitaire, OCHA travaille par ailleurs au renforcement des capacités des partenaires et à une plus grande cohérence entre les activités humanitaires, de développement et de consolidation de la paix à travers une collaboration efficace avec tous les acteurs et en recherchant l’implication de tous, depuis le stade de la planification à l’indentification des priorités de l’action humanitaire au Tchad. Ce partenariat actif et inclusif permet d’adresser de façon coordonnée, les conséquences humanitaires engendrées par les crises récurrentes liées notamment à l'insécurité alimentaire et à la malnutrition, aux mouvements de populations, aux urgences sanitaires, et aux effets négatifs du changement climatique (inondations et sécheresse) et de renforcer concomitamment la résilience des populations.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has been present in Niger since 2005, a year particularly marked by a serious food crisis. Since then, OCHA Niger, in support of the Humanitarian Coordinator and the Government, coordinates emergency assistance to populations affected by multiple crises. OCHA Niger works in close collaboration with all State structures both in the field and in Niamey, highlighting, whenever possible, the leadership of national structures, while ensuring respect for humanitarian and operational principles. Niger faces a complex humanitarian emergency marked by continued insecurity and violence against civilians perpetrated by elements of armed groups, endemic poverty, the effects of climate change, including seasonal flooding and pockets of drought. The humanitarian situation is further aggravated by the COVID-19 pandemic which is leading to an exponential increase in needs.

Le Bureau de la Coordination des Affaires Humanitaires (OCHA) est présent au Niger depuis 2005, une année particulièrement marquée par une grave crise alimentaire. Depuis lors, OCHA Niger en appui au Coordonnateur Humanitaire et au Gouvernement assure la coordination de l’assistance d’urgence aux populations affectées par des crises multiples. OCHA Niger travaille en étroite collaboration avec toutes les structures de l’État tant sur le terrain qu’au niveau de Niamey en mettant en évidence, chaque fois que possible, le leadership des structures nationales, tout en veillant au respect des principes humanitaires et opérationnels. Le Niger est confronté à une urgence humanitaire complexe marquée par l'insécurité et la violence continues contre les civils perpétrées par des éléments des groupes armés, la pauvreté endémique, les effets du changement climatique, y compris les inondations saisonnières et les poches de sécheresse. La situation humanitaire est encore aggravée par la pandémie de la COVID-19 qui entraîne une augmentation exponentielle des besoins.

name: FSNWG: Food Security and Nutrition Working Group

fields.Org Full Name: FSNWG: Food Security and Nutrition Working Group
fields.Org Description: The Food Security and Nutrition Working Group (FSNWG) is a regional platform, currently co-chaired by ICPAC and FAO. It’s goal is two-fold: to provide an up-to-date food security and nutrition situation analysis (early warning) and to offer a forum to build consensus on critical issues facing policy and interventions. The FNSWG has served regional governments, donors, and non-governmental agencies since the early 2000’s. Current membership includes approximately 80 organisations (IGAD, UN agencies, NGOs, donors, and research institutions) who contribute to the operation of the working group, and its nutrition, markets, food security information, livestock and pastoralist sub-groups.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Global Affairs Canada (GAC) / Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development
fields.Agency Data Portal: Project Browser  International assistance projects funded by Global Affairs Canada https://w05.international.gc.ca/projectbrowser-banqueprojets/

fields.Project Description: FNWG Alerts and Early Warning provides timely notifications and early warnings regarding potential risks and emerging threats relevant to the asset. The service delivers clear, concise, and actionable information to support informed decision-making and proactive risk management. All alerts are presented in a neutral and descriptive manner, ensuring that stakeholders receive accurate and objective updates.

The Global Seismic Risk Map  poster comprises three global maps, and a ranking of the top 15 countries according to five risk metrics. The main map presents the geographic distribution of average annual loss (AAL) of the built-up area due to ground shaking in the residential, commercial and industrial building stock. It does not consider the effects of tsunamis, liquefaction, landslides, and fires following earthquakes.

The Food Security and Nutrition Working Group (FSNWG) is a regional platform, currently co-chaired by ICPAC and FAO. name: UNOSAT: The United Nations Satellite Centre

fields.Org Full Name: UNOSAT: The United Nations Satellite Centre
fields.Org Description: The United Nations Satellite Centre (UNOSAT), part of UNITAR, delivers satellite analysis, training, and capacity development to UN entities and Member States. We leverage geospatial technologies to support humanitarian response, sustainable development, and resilience building worldwide.

fields.Project Description: UNOSAT provides geospatial analysis and satellite imagery to support disaster response, humanitarian aid, and sustainable development. It offers on-demand and open-access mapping services through interactive portals, data hubs, and geospatial APIs.

fields.Project/Product Name: Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS)
fields.Project Description: The Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS) is a cooperation framework between the United Nations, the European Commission, and disaster managers worldwide. Its purpose is to improve alerts, facilitate information exchange, and enhance coordination during the initial phase following major sudden-onset disasters.

fields.Org Description: Pacific Disaster Center (PDC) is a leading scientific innovator of global risk reduction science and technology. As a University of Hawai’i applied science and research center, our work intersects with a variety of government, community, academic, and scientific organizations at home and around the world to build resilience to natural and man-made hazards, assess risk, and enhance the capacity to quickly and accurately anticipate and prepare for new and emerging threats.

fields.Project Description: PDC’s National Disaster Preparedness Baseline Assessment is more than an assessment. It is a long-term program designed to help countries evaluate risk and disaster management capacity and apply these insights to early warning, disaster preparedness, policy and planning, sustainable development, and resilience-building initiatives. The national baseline assessment is the only U.S. program recognized by the United Nations to assist countries in operationalizing the goals of the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction. It provides an evidence-based foundation for actions to be taken and investments to be made in achieving long-term resilience and strengthening national disaster preparedness.

DisasterAWARE is a global platform that provides real-time hazard alerts, dashboards, and geospatial tools to support disaster preparedness and early warning. The platform integrates predictive models and hazard tracking using data from global datasets, enabling comprehensive monitoring and response to potential disasters.

PDC’s advanced natural language processing and generative AI are being leveraged to greatly reduce the manual labor and time involved with finding, analyzing, and curating global hazard content. This enables PDC to provide more comprehensive coverage of hazard events worldwide through its DisasterAWARE Pro risk intelligence and early warning platform. These repetitive and time-consuming tasks are now performed by AI Hazard Finder with greater speed and accuracy than previously possible.

PDC’s Multi-hazard Risk Score combines multi-hazard exposure, vulnerability (susceptibility to impact), and coping capacity (the relative ability to absorb negative disaster impacts). This score provides a comprehensive measure of how each country may be affected by hazards and disasters as a whole over time.

Learn the basics and progress to becoming an advanced user in DisasterAWARE software. On-site, instructor-led classroom training is available at either the client’s location or the provider’s facilities. Support is offered to help achieve nearly any training objective.

fields.Org Description: Uppsala University is the oldest Nordic university, founded in 1477. Today we are a comprehensive research university with a clear mission: to pursue top-quality research and education and to interact constructively with society, thus contributing to a better world.

fields.Project Description: The Violence & Impacts Early-Warning System (VIEWS) is an academic research consortium and conflict prediction system jointly led by Uppsala University and the Peace Research Institute Oslo. The VIEWS consortium brings together a suite of interrelated projects dedicated to exploring state-of-the-art approaches for studying and predicting the risk of violent conflicts and their impacts on society and human development.
UCDP offers conflict datasets, battle event data, and fatalities statistics to support academic and policy research on global violence trends.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Ministry of Education and Research / Swedish Research Council (VR)

name: SIPRI: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute

fields.Org Full Name: SIPRI: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute
fields.Org Description: SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources, to policymakers, researchers, media and the interested public. Based in Stockholm, SIPRI is regularly ranked among the most respected think tanks worldwide.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands (BZ / MFA)
Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs (MEAE)

fields.Project Description: An open library of global arms production data, featuring company listings, production volumes, and export trends for use in disarmament analysis and policy design.
Offers historical data on military spending by country, allowing trend analysis and budget comparisons for global peace research.
This database tracks country participation in UN and regional peace operations, including details on troop numbers, funding, and deployment dates.

fields.Project/Product Name: Stockholm Forum on Peace and Development
fields.Project Description: Held annually, the Stockholm Forum on Peace and Development is a dialogue-driven event that offers a neutral platform for interdisciplinary exchange among members of international communities working in development, humanitarian, peacebuilding, and security sectors. The event is recognized for its discussion-led roundtable sessions, which are developed in collaboration with partner organizations and encourage active participation from stakeholders at all levels.
Provides publicly available datasets on the legal transfers of major conventional weapons between countries. The database is widely used in security and disarmament monitoring.

fields.Project/Product Name: SIPRI Mapping ATT-Relevant Cooperation and Assistance Activities Database
fields.Project Description: Tracks international arms transfer assistance and cooperation initiatives. It supports transparency and reporting under the Arms Trade Treaty through searchable data.

The SIPRI National Budget Archive provides government spending data from multiple countries, facilitating transparent comparisons of military and civilian budget priorities. This resource supports analysis related to disarmament and peacebuilding by offering comprehensive and accessible budget information.

name: UNMAS: United Nations Mine Action Service

fields.Org Full Name: UNMAS: United Nations Mine Action Service
fields.Org Description: UNMAS (United Nations Mine Action Service) utilizes data to inform and manage mine action programs globally, coordinating with other UN entities and partners. They maintain an Interactive Dashboard of the UN Mine Action Strategy, which presents data on program outcomes, outputs, targeted populations, and funding. UNMAS also collaborates on data-related projects, including a machine learning initiative to detect development indicators in cleared areas of Afghanistan using satellite imagery, which informs their efforts to eliminate the threat of mines and explosives.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs, Defence, Development Cooperation and Foreign Trade
United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

fields.Org Description: Flowminder also co-founded, in partnership with UNFPA, WorldPop at the University of Southampton, and CIESIN at Columbia University the GRID3 programme. GRID3 was an international partnership programme funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the United Kingdom’s Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office to map a path to sustainable development for everyone with geospatial data solutions.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO)
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

fields.Project Description: Flowminder strengthens the capacity of governments, UN agencies, mobile operators, private companies, and NGOs to maximize the benefits of new analytic techniques and data sources. Through expertise in geospatial and mobile operator data analytics, Flowminder collaborates with in-country partners to enhance data use among decision makers and to develop sustainable, long-lasting solutions.

To provide decision makers with precise and accurate estimates of population changes and movements, and thereby support interventions in sectors such as health and disaster management, state-of-the-art methods have been developed for estimating population distribution and human mobility using mobile phone usage data, specifically Call Detail Records (CDRs), as well as survey, census, and geospatial data. CDRs are datasets automatically generated by mobile operators for billing purposes, regardless of phone type, and represent an attractive data source for estimating internal migration and displacement, particularly in low- and middle-income countries where data on human mobility are often scarce. These methods enable a more comprehensive understanding of population dynamics, supporting evidence-based decision making in critical sectors.

To maximise the use of public and private sites and services, such as schools, health facilities, vaccination sites, or mobile money agents, these facilities need to be located where they can reach the largest possible share of the population. Today, detailed data on population distributions, roads and river networks, population mobility patterns, and a range of other geospatial data are available, enabling decision makers to better identify service allocation issues. Using these data, Flowminder has developed a new methodology to support decision makers in identifying optimal locations for their services and to facilitate data-driven decision making.

FlowKit is an open-source suite for the secure processing of de-identified mobile network data, designed to bridge the gap between mobile operators and humanitarian or development actors. By providing operator-controlled, audited access to mobility metrics via a dedicated API, FlowKit reduces technical barriers, safeguards privacy, and enables the scalable use of mobile data for crisis response, planning, and public-good analytics.

fields.Project/Product Name: GRID3: Geo-Referenced Infrastructure and Demographic Data for Development
fields.Project Description: GRID3 provides high-resolution geospatial data, including population estimates, infrastructure mapping, and administrative boundaries, to support governments and organizations in planning, monitoring, and delivering services effectively.

name: OCHA: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

fields.Org Full Name: OCHA: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
fields.Org Description: Support humanitarian organizations to respond effectively to the needs of people caught in crises, to understand and analyse their needs, and to mobilize international assistance. We provide tools and services to help humanitarian organizations ensure that no one affected by a crisis is left behind.
fields.Org IATI Name: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

fields.Agency/Department Name: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands (BZ / MFA)
Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs, Defence, Development Cooperation and Foreign Trade

fields.Project Description: Common Operational Datasets (CODs) are authoritative reference datasets utilized by humanitarian organizations to support response efforts and inform decision-making. They offer a consistent and standardized data framework that enables all actors involved in a crisis to coordinate effectively.

OCHA’s Common Operational Data Administrative Boundaries (COD‑AB) is a curated, harmonized global dataset aligned with OCHA’s COD standard. It is designed to support mapping, analysis, and coordination in humanitarian operations.

fields.Project/Product Name: Global Humanitarian Operational Presence Who, What, Where (3W) Portal
fields.Project Description: The 3W data is sourced from OCHA country and regional offices around the world and compiled by the Field Information Services (FIS) Section of OCHA. The data are as provided, and organization names and acronyms are not standardized. The frequency of 3W data collection varies across offices, and the compiled database includes what is available up to the date of publishing. This information supports the asset Global Humanitarian Operational Presence Who, What, Where (3W) Portal.

fields.Project/Product Name: Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS)
fields.Project Description: The Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS) is a cooperation framework between the United Nations, the European Commission, and disaster managers worldwide. Its purpose is to improve alerts, facilitate information exchange, and enhance coordination during the initial phase following major sudden-onset disasters.

OCHA’s Financial Tracking Service (FTS) collects, standardizes, and publishes real-time humanitarian funding data globally. It provides dashboards and downloadable datasets that track donor and recipient transactions during emergencies, ensuring transparency across funding flows.

The Multi-Sectoral Needs Assessment (MSNA) is a standardized, country-level data collection initiative designed to capture comprehensive multi-sectoral needs among crisis-affected populations. Implemented by IMPACT Initiatives through its REACH Initiative, the MSNA collects statistically representative, household-level data on sectors such as food security, health, shelter, WASH, education, and protection. While the initiative is closely coordinated with OCHA and humanitarian clusters in country-led responses, the technical design, survey implementation, and analysis are primarily led by REACH/IMPACT, with operational support from agencies like IOM , WFP or IMMAP.

iati_data.org_name: OCHA: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) opened its branch in Côte d'Ivoire in 2011 in response to the post-election crisis. This crisis, which shook the country between November 2010 and May 2011, affected more than two million people, causing the displacement of more than 600,000 people inside the country and more than 180,000 new Ivorian refugees to countries of the sub-region. Since 2011, the situation in Côte d'Ivoire has improved significantly in political, security and socio-economic terms. Most internally displaced persons (IDPs) have returned to their villages of origin and humanitarian actors continue to support the gradual and voluntary return and sustainable reintegration of refugees and IDPs. OCHA's expertise continues to be sought in the context of emergency preparedness, to develop inter-agency contingency plans in the face of the various climate risks that threaten the country. The transition from emergency to development, which began in 2013, first resulted in the transfer of responsibility for strategic humanitarian coordination to the government, through the establishment of the Extended Coordination Committee (CCE) which brings together government officials with humanitarian actors and development partners. In support of government efforts, OCHA supports and coordinates the development of preparedness and response plans (disaster risk reduction, Ebola, evictions from classified forests, etc.) and facilitates training related to emergency preparedness. OCHA is also very active in establishing an innovative and sustainable partnership between the authorities, humanitarian actors and the private sector in Côte d'Ivoire.

Le Bureau de la coordination des affaires humanitaires (OCHA) des Nations Unies a ouvert son antenne en Côte d’Ivoire en 2011 en réponse à la crise post-électorale. Cette crise, qui a secoué le pays entre novembre 2010 et mai 2011, a affecté plus de deux millions de personnes, provoquant le déplacement de plus de 600 000 personnes à l’intérieur du pays et de plus de 180 000 nouveaux réfugiés ivoiriens vers les pays de la sous-région. Depuis 2011, la situation de la Côte d’Ivoire s’est nettement améliorée sur les plans politique, sécuritaire et socio-économique. La plupart des personnes déplacées internes (PDI) sont retournées dans leurs villages d’origine et les acteurs humanitaires continuent de soutenir le retour progressif et volontaire et la réintégration durable des réfugiés et des PDI. L'expertise d'OCHA continue d’être sollicitée dans le cadre de la préparation à l'urgence, pour développer les plans de contingence inter-agences face aux différents risques climatiques qui menacent le pays. La transition de l’urgence au développement, amorcée en 2013, s’est d’abord traduite par la passation de la responsabilité de la coordination humanitaire stratégique au gouvernement, à travers la mise en place du Comité de Coordination Elargi (CCE) qui réunit les représentants du gouvernement avec les acteurs humanitaires et les partenaires au développement.En soutien aux efforts du gouvernement, OCHA appui et coordonne le développement des plans de préparation et de réponse (réduction des risques des catastrophes, Ebola, déguerpissements des forêts classées, etc.) et facilite des formations liées à la préparation à l'urgence. OCHA est en outre très actif pour établir un partenariat innovant et durable entre les autorités, les acteurs humanitaires et le secteur privé en Côte d’Ivoire.

description_narrative: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) public and private advocacy raises awareness of forgotten crises, promotes respect for international humanitarian law (IHL), brings the voices of crisis-affected people to the forefront, and helps people obtain access to humanitarian assistance. To OCHA, advocacy means communicating the right messages to the right people at the right time. These people include humanitarian agencies, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), community-based organizations, national governments, local and international media, parties to conflict, companies, donors, regional bodies, communities affected by emergencies and the general public. The aim is that they increase urgent funding or support, change their policies or keep to their commitments.

title_narrative: OCHA Headquarter, Information Management, Front Office
description_narrative: OCHA provides information management services to the humanitarian community to inform a rapid, effective, and principled response. It gathers, shares, and uses data and information, underpinning coordination, decision-making, and advocacy. OCHA’s role in information management is unique, differing from the role of other UN agencies or humanitarian actors because it is responsible for consolidating and publishing information across the whole spectrum of humanitarian response so that local and international actors can use the information to make life-saving policy and operational decisions.

title_narrative: OCHA Field activities, Caucasus and Central Asia (regional)
OCHA Field activities, Caucasus and Central Asia (regional)
description_narrative: The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Regional Office for the Caucasus and Central Asia (ROCCA) was based in Almaty, Kazakhstan. The office has been closed since 2018 and integrated in OCHA ROAP. During its mandate, OCHA ROCCA improved levels of preparedness in the region through early warning and contingency planning, ensuring the inclusion of all relevant key partners. OCHA ROCCA made sure that Governments, civil society and international actors are well prepared, so that in the face of slow- or sudden-onset emergencies, the entire humanitarian community joins efforts to assist affected people. In slow- or sudden-onset disasters or crises, OCHA ROCCA provided specialized support to country offices and partners within its areas of expertise, including surge teams, emergency response coordination, information management, advocacy and resource mobilization.

Региональный офис Управления по координации гуманитарных вопросов (УКГВ) для Кавказа и Центральной Азии (РОКЦА) базировался в Алматы, Казахстан. Офис был закрыт в 2018 году и интегрирован в Гуманитарную консультативную группу УКГВ в Таджикистане. В течение своей работы УКГВ РОКЦА повысил уровень готовности в регионе за счет раннего предупреждения и планирования на случай непредвиденных обстоятельств, обеспечив привлечение всех соответствующих ключевых партнеров. УКГВ РОКЦА позаботился о том, чтобы правительства, гражданское общество и международные организации были хорошо подготовлены, и чтобы перед лицом медленно наступающих или внезапных чрезвычайных ситуаций все гуманитарное сообщество объединяло усилия для оказания помощи пострадавшим. В случае медленно наступающих или внезапных стихийных бедствий или кризисов, УКГВ РОКЦА оказывал специализированную поддержку страновым отделениям и партнерам в областях своей компетенции, включая экстренные группы поддержки, координацию реагирования на чрезвычайные ситуации, управление информацией, пропаганду и мобилизацию ресурсов

OCHA Headquarter, Humanitarian Partnerships for the Middle East and Central Asia
description_narrative: OCHA’s partnerships also helped key actors fulfil theirWorld Humanitarian Summit commitments, such as theMiddle East and North Africa Youth capacity-building inHumanitarian Action by Reach Out to Asia.

Le BCAH coordonne les interventions d’urgence au niveau mondial pour sauver des vies et protéger les populations en cas de crise humanitaire. Nous plaidons pour une action humanitaire efficace et raisonnée, par tous et pour tous
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) involvement in Pakistan began in 1987, when an office was set up in Peshawar to support the organization’s Afghanistan operations. This office was moved to Afghanistan in 2003. In 2005, an office was officially established in Pakistan to respond to the devastating earthquake in the north. OCHA’s presence was scaled back in the ensuing years, but the organization re-established an office in 2009 to assist over 3 million people displaced by insecurity in the north-west. OCHA provides comprehensive support to the humanitarian community in activities related to coordinating emergency preparedness planning, humanitarian response, disaster risk reductionand resilience. OCHA also ensures coordination with national and international NGOs through their umbrella groups. These include the Pakistan Humanitarian Forum, which is an alliance of 57 INGOs, and the National Humanitarian Network, which is a consortium of more than 180 national NGOs. Through knowledge sharing and training, OCHA also helps strengthen the capacity of national and international stakeholders to respond to emergencies. Given the likely recurrence of natural disasters and crises in Pakistan, OCHA continues to work closely with the government and humanitarian partners to ensure an effective response to future crises.

description_narrative: The Philippines is one of the most disaster prone countries in the world. Annually, an average of 22 tropical cyclones enter the Philippine Area of Responsibility of which around 6 to 7 cause significant damage. Conflicts in Mindanao also cause intermittent cycles of forced displacement. In 2007, Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) established a presence in Manila to complement the Government’s response to natural disasters and to strengthen humanitarian coordination. In September 2009, Tropical Storm Ketsana devastated Metro Manila, prompting the Emergency Relief Coordinator to appoint the Resident Coordinator as also the Humanitarian Coordinator. OCHA’s presence in the Philippines was upgraded to a country office in 2010, with a dual focus: emergency response preparedness and response to sudden onset emergencies and the protracted conflict situation in Mindanao.

description_narrative: The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Country Office in Eritrea was established in 2000 following the 1998-2000 border conflict with Ethiopia. Since that date, programmes and projects of an urgent or humanitarian nature have been built into the United Nations Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF) and, since 2013, the joint UN-GoSE Strategic Partnership Cooperation Framework (SPCF). OCHA has been coordinating humanitarian response on an annual basis, which constitutes part of the five-year development cooperation framework. Working closely with the UN Country Team (UNCT) in Eritrea, the OCHA Country Office coordinates humanitarian analysis, prioritization and response through the projects of UN agencies which work closely with their Government implementing partners, and in the absence of INGOs. OCHA’s presence in Eritrea ensures that urgent and humanitarian issues are integrated into wider development processes. In coordination with the UNCT and the RCO, OCHA also facilitates the UNCT’s preparedness and contingency planning processes. Furthermore, OCHA expertise in information management ensures production of regular resource mobilization data, snapshots and analysis on behalf of the UNCT, as well as assisting UN agencies and partners with visualization, GIS and mapping services. OCHA Eritrea supports the resource mobilization efforts of the UNCT, with particular focus on urgent response and basic services. This is done through OCHA’s own engagements with donors, as well as support to the Resident Coordinator /Humanitarian Coordinator and UNCT in their resource mobilization efforts. OCHA maintains close and regular contacts with both resident and non-resident embassies and donor partners, providing regular updates and briefings. OCHA also coordinates CERF applications and processes in support of allocations for Eritrea.

description_narrative: OCHA’s public and private advocacy raises awareness of forgotten crises, promotes respect for international humanitarian law (IHL), brings the voices of crisis-affected people to the forefront, and helps people obtain access to humanitarian assistance.

description_narrative: The Southern Africa region has fewer protracted humanitarian crises, but is prone to drought, floods and cyclones. Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) does not have country offices in the region but has a Humanitarian Advisory Team in Madagascar since OCHA Southern Africa has been integrated in OCHA Regional Office for Southern and Eastern Africa (ROSEA). OCHA ROSEA works to strengthen collaboration on emergency preparedness and response with regional bodies, such as the Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) in Southern Africa.

description_narrative: Through leadership in developing humanitarian policy, OCHA helps set the agenda for humanitarian sector reform and effectiveness in response to a shifting global landscape, new global frameworks, and increased capacities of national Governments and local actors. OCHA also promotes and advances the normative framework for international humanitarian action while developing, strengthening and advancing this framework. Policy development aims to support effective and principled humanitarian action, saving lives and reducing suffering

description_narrative: The Pacific is one of the most disaster-prone regions in the world. Small, vulnerable island states are isolated by vast expanses of ocean. They experience frequent and intense disasters with disproportionately high economic, social and environmental consequences. In 1999, Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) established an office for the Pacific (OP) to mobilize and coordinate effective and principled humanitarian action in partnership with national and international actors. The first responders in any emergency are disaster-affected people and their governments. OCHA’s key objective is to support national efforts to protect the lives, livelihoods and dignity of people in need. International assistance can only be mobilized when a request is made by the affected government. OCHA OP personnel can provide support in information management, reporting, mapping, media and communications, assessments, humanitarian financing and inter-cluster coordination. OCHA can deploy UNDAC teams at short notice to assist in the coordination of incoming international relief at the earliest stages of an emergency.

description_narrative: The humanitarian situation in Venezuela was the result of seven consecutive years of economic contraction, periods of hyperinflation, political polarization and institutional challenges. The pandemic deepened the needs of people due to the impact on essential services such as health care, water, gas and electricity. The food insecurity situation was also aggravated. The office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Assistance coordinated assistance to people across the country, mostly to provide health, water, sanitation, hygiene, protection and education services.  Office for the Coordination on Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) played a leading role in integrating cross-cutting issues in the response, such as gender and protection, and in strengthening accountability to affected people (AAP) and protection from sexual exploitation and abuse (PSEA). The HCT adopted the Collective AAP Framework and the protocol that defines procedures for submitting PSEA complaint.

La situación humanitaria en Venezuela es el resultado de siete años consecutivos de contracción económica, períodos de hiperinflación, polarización política y desafíos institucionales. La pandemia profundizó las necesidades de la población debido al impacto en los servicios esenciales como la atención sanitaria, el agua, el gas y la electricidad. También se agravó la situación de inseguridad alimentaria. La Oficina de Coordinación de Asuntos Humanitarios (OCHA) coordinó la asistencia a la población en todo el territorio nacional, principalmente para proporcionar servicios de salud, agua, saneamiento, higiene, protección y educación. OCHA desempeñó un papel protagónico en la integración de cuestiones transversales en la respuesta, como el género y la protección, y en el fortalecimiento de la rendición de cuentas a las personas afectadas (AAP, por su sigla en inglés) y la protección contra la explotación y el abuso sexual (PSEA, por su sigla en inglés). El EHP adoptó el Marco Colectivo de AAP y el protocolo que define los procedimientos para la presentación de denuncias sobre PSEA.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Headquarters (HQ) Central Cost Unit provides the funding for HQ rental charges, utilities and other premises costs.  It also includes other centralized corporate services such as Human Resources, Procurement and implementation of Umoja extension.

L'unité centrale des coûts du Bureau de la coordination des affaires humanitaires (OCHA) fournit le financement des frais de location du siège, des services publics et d'autres frais de locaux. Il comprend également d'autres services centraux centralisés tels que les ressources humaines, les achats et la mise en œuvre de l'extension Umoja.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: In 2021, despite decrease in number of people in need, the vulnerabilities of the population in Burundi have increased compared to previous years due to the combined effects of recurring natural disasters, frequent epidemic outbreaks, the socioeconomic impacts of COVID-19, as well as increasing refugee returns. The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in Burundi played a coordination role for the emergency response and preparedness to climate disasters, including flooding in Bujumbura province, and epidemic outbreaks. It also coordinated the health response and the socio-economic response to the Covid-19 pandemic, combining emergency and longer-term development response.

En 2021, malgré la diminution du nombre de personnes dans le besoin, les vulnérabilités de la population au Burundi ont augmenté par rapport aux années précédentes en raison des effets combinés des catastrophes naturelles récurrentes, des épidémies fréquentes, des impacts socio-économiques de la COVID-19, ainsi que de l'augmentation du retour des réfugiés. Le Bureau de la coordination des affaires humanitaires (OCHA) au Burundi a joué un rôle de coordination pour la réponse d'urgence et la préparation aux catastrophes climatiques, notamment les inondations dans la province de Bujumbura, et aux épidémies. Il a également coordonné la réponse sanitaire et la réponse socio-économique à la pandémie de Covid-19, en combinant une réponse d'urgence et de développement à plus long terme.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Despite 2016 the Peace Agreement between the Government and the FARC-EP ending decades of civil war and progress in improving economic and social conditions, Colombia continues to face numerous humanitarian challenges. In some regions of the country, hostilities and armed violence continue, with significant humanitarian impact and protection challenges. This situation is further exacerbated by the impact of natural disasters, presence of landmines and unexploded ordnance and, now, the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The latter has led to an increase in the number of food-insecure people from 3.3 million to over 10 million. So far in 2020, the humanitarian community in Colombia has provided assistance – including COVID-19 related assistance – to almost a million people. Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) currently supports a humanitarian coordination architecture consisting of around 120 partners, including UN agencies, national and international NGOs, the Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement, civil society, donors and national institutions.

A pesar de que en 2016 el Acuerdo de Paz entre el Gobierno y las FARC-EP puso fin a décadas de guerra civil y de los avances en la mejora de las condiciones económicas y sociales, Colombia sigue enfrentándose a numerosos retos humanitarios. En algunas regiones del país, las hostilidades y la violencia armada continúan, con un impacto humanitario significativo y con desafíos de protección. Esta situación se ve agravada por el impacto de los desastres de origen natural, la presencia de minas terrestres y municiones sin explotar y, ahora, el impacto de la pandemia COVID-19. Esta última ha provocado un aumento del número de personas en situación de inseguridad alimentaria de 3,3 millones a más de 10 millones. En lo que va de 2020, la comunidad humanitaria de Colombia ha prestado asistencia -incluida la relacionada con la COVID-19- a casi un millón de personas. La Oficina de Coordinación de Asuntos Humanitarios (OCHA) apoya actualmente una arquitectura de coordinación humanitaria formada por unos 120 socios, entre los que se encuentran organismos de la ONU, ONG nacionales e internacionales, el Movimiento de la Cruz Roja y la Media Luna Roja, la sociedad civil, donantes e instituciones nacionales.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Cameroon is affected by three simultaneous protection crises that are exacerbating the humanitarian situation of affected people. Increased violence in the Lake Chad Basin and in the North-West and South-West regions continues to cause internal displacement. Moreover, hundreds of refugees from the Central African Republic (CAR) have found shelter in the eastern regions of Cameroon and rely on life-saving and life-sustaining humanitarian assistance. Since 2015, humanitarian organizations have been jointly working with the Government to scale up the response in Cameroon.  Office for the Coordination on Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) supports more than 170 humanitarian organizations that are providing emergency assistance to crisis-affected people. The main focus of the humanitarian response operation will continue to be providing life-saving assistance and protection to affected populations, promoting long-term voluntary and safe durable solutions when relevant and feasible, and strengthening early recovery and community resilience.

Le Cameroun est affecté par trois crises de protection simultanées qui exacerbent la situation humanitaire des personnes affectées. L'augmentation de la violence dans le bassin du lac Tchad et dans les régions du Nord-Ouest et du Sud-Ouest continue de provoquer des déplacements internes. En outre, des centaines de réfugiés de la République Centrafricaine (RCA) ont trouvé refuge dans les régions de l'Est du Cameroun et comptent sur une aide humanitaire vitale et de survie. Depuis 2015, les organisations humanitaires travaillent conjointement avec le gouvernement pour intensifier la réponse au Cameroun.  Le Bureau de la Coordination des Affaires Humanitaires (OCHA) soutient plus de 170 organisations humanitaires qui fournissent une aide d'urgence aux personnes touchées par la crise. L'opération de réponse humanitaire continuera de se concentrer principalement sur la fourniture d'une assistance et d'une protection vitales aux populations touchées, la promotion de solutions durables volontaires et sûres à long terme lorsque cela est pertinent et faisable, et le renforcement du relèvement précoce et de la résilience des communautés.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Even before the pandemic began, 2020 was on track to be the most difficult year of the past decade for Burkina Faso. A succession of shocks linked to conflict and insecurity had driven more than 1 million people from their homes since early 2019.  And for the first time in 10 years, the country saw the re-emergence of critical food insecurity conditions in two provinces of the Sahel region.  Office for the Coordination on Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) gradually increased its capacity to support collective priorities for humanitarian coordination at the national and regional levels, securing dedicated capacity to provide leadership on humanitarian civil-military coordination, community engagement, Accountability to Affected People, Information Management and analysis, and protection from sexual exploitation and abuse (PSEA).

Avant même le début de la pandémie, 2020 semblait être l'année la plus difficile de la dernière décennie pour le Burkina Faso. Une succession de chocs liés au conflit et à l'insécurité avait poussé plus d'un million de personnes à quitter leur foyer depuis le début de 2019. Et pour la première fois en 10 ans, le pays a vu réapparaître des conditions d'insécurité alimentaire critiques dans deux provinces de la région du Sahel. Le Bureau de la Coordination des Affaires Humanitaires (OCHA) a progressivement augmenté sa capacité à soutenir les priorités collectives en matière de coordination humanitaire aux niveaux national et régional, en obtenant des capacités dédiées pour assurer le leadership en matière de coordination humanitaire civilo-militaire, d'engagement communautaire, de responsabilité envers les personnes affectées, de gestion et d'analyse de l'information, et de protection contre l'exploitation et les abus sexuels (PEAS).
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative: OCHA Field activities, Central African Republic
OCHA Field activities, Central African Republic
description_narrative: Central African Republic continues to face a serious protection crisis, with a steady increase in violations of human rights and international humanitarian law despite the signing of the Political Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in 2019. Those who suffer the most, they are the civilian populations. One in four Central Africans is displaced either within the country or to a neighboring country, and the waves of return of displaced and repatriated people have slowed considerably. Since last year, the number of people in need has increased from 2.6 million to 2.8 million (+8%). At the same time, the number of people in need of acute assistance is 12% higher than in 2020. In five years, CAR has never counted so many people in humanitarian distress. This increase is the direct consequence of the plunge in macroeconomic indicators, the advent of new pockets of violent conflict, the rise of food insecurity and the COVID-19 pandemic.

La RCA continue à faire face à une grave crise de protection, avec une augmentation constante des violations des droits humains et du droit international humanitaire malgré la signature de l'Accord Politique pour la Paix et la Réconciliation en 2019. Ceux qui souffrent le plus, ce sont les populations civiles. Un Centrafricain sur quatre est déplacé soit à l'intérieur du pays ou dans un pays voisin, et les vagues de retour de personnes déplacées et rapatriées ont considérablement ralenti. Depuis l’année dernière, le nombre de personnes dans le besoin a augmenté, passant de 2,6 millions à 2,8 millions (+8%). En même temps, le nombre de personnes en besoin d’assistance aiguë est de 12% supérieur qu’en 2020. En cinq ans, jamais la RCA n’avait compté autant de personnes en situation de détresse humanitaire. Cette augmentation est la conséquence directe de la plongée des indicateurs macro-économiques, l’avènement de nouvelles poches de conflits violents, la montée de l’insécurité alimentaire et la pandémie de la COVID-19.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative: OCHA Headquarter, Humanitarian Financing, Front Office
description_narrative: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) aims to mobilize and engage the full range of financing instruments, mechanisms and partners to ensure that growing humanitarian needs are met, humanitarian leadership and coordination mechanisms are promoted at the country level, and the large array of global humanitarian financing mechanisms are complementary among themselves and coherent with development funding. OCHA works with humanitarian partners around the world to identify the most critical humanitarian needs, plan responses and determine the budgets needed to address them. OCHA also ensures more responsive, predictable and strategic humanitarian financing through its leadership of the Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) and Country-Based Pooled Funds (CBPFs) for the humanitarian system

Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) aims to mobilize and engage the full range of financing instruments, mechanisms and partners to ensure that growing humanitarian needs are met, humanitarian leadership and coordination mechanisms are promoted at the country level, and the large array of global humanitarian financing mechanisms are complementary among themselves and coherent with development funding. OCHA works with humanitarian partners around the world to identify the most critical humanitarian needs, plan responses and determine the budgets needed to address them. OCHA also ensures more responsive, predictable and strategic humanitarian financing through its leadership of the Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) and Country-Based Pooled Funds (CBPFs) for the humanitarian system

title_narrative: OCHA Field activities, Middle East and North Africa (regional)
OCHA Field activities, Middle East and North Africa (regional)
description_narrative: The OCHA Regional Office for Middle East and North Africa (ROMENA) based in Cairo and Amman and covers 21 countries and territories spread across the region. Several countries in the Middle East and North Africa region are experiencing political, economic and social transformations which have resulted in humanitarian crises causing an increase in human suffering and vulnerability. The situation is further compounded by hazards and natural disasters such as earthquakes, drought and floods. In this regard, OCHA ROMENA works to support and strengthen humanitarian coordination and response preparedness in the region. In countries where OCHA maintains country office presence including Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, Libya, Syria, Turkey, Yemen and occupied Palestinian Territory, the regional office provides frontline surge capacity as required particularly to support escalating or sudden on-set emergencies. For countries without OCHA in-country presence, the ROMENA team aims to support national authorities, regional bodies, Resident Coordinators and UN Country Teams to strengthen emergency preparedness and response to effectively and efficiently respond to or prepare for emergency situations through physical deployment or remote support.

يقع مكتب أوتشا الإقليمي للشرق الأوسط وشمال إفريقيا في مدينتي القاهرة وعمان ويغطي 21 دولة وإقليمًا منتشرة في جميع أنحاء المنطقة. تشهد العديد من البلدان في منطقة الشرق الأوسط وشمال إفريقيا تحولات سياسية واقتصادية واجتماعية أدت إلى أزمات إنسانية تسببت في زيادة المعاناة الإنسانية والقابلية للتأثر بالكوارث. ومما يزيد الوضع تعقيدًا الأخطار والكوارث الطبيعية مثل الزلازل والجفاف والفيضانات. في هذا الصدد، يعمل مكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية في الشرق الأوسط وشمال أفريقيا على دعم وتعزيز التنسيق الإنساني والتأهب للاستجابة في المنطقة. أما في البلدان التي يحتفظ فيها مكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية بوجود مكتب قطري، بما في ذلك العراق والأردن ولبنان وليبيا وسوريا وتركيا واليمن والأراضي الفلسطينية المحتلة، فيوفر المكتب الإقليمي قدرة احتياطية على الخطوط الأمامية وفقًا للطلب خاصة لدعم حالات الطوارئ المتصاعدة أو المفاجئة. بالنسبة للبلدان التي ليس هناك تواجد لمكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية بها، يهدف فريق المكتب الإقليمي للشرق الاوسط وشمال أفريقيا إلى دعم السلطات الوطنية والهيئات الإقليمية والمنسقين المقيمين وفرق الأمم المتحدة القطرية لتعزيز التأهب والاستجابة لحالات الطوارئ وذلك للاستجابة بفعّالية وكفاءة لحالات الطوارئ أو الاستعداد لها من خلال نشر الفرق أو تقديم الدعم عن بعد.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: The humanitarian crisis in Borno, Adamawa and Yobe states in Nigeria’s north-east, that has spilled over into the Lake Chad region, remains among the most severe humanitarian crises in the world today. As Nigeria faces the unprecedented challenge of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, the humanitarian community is stepping up action to prevent the spread of the virus among communities already affected by conflict, chronic diseases and climate shocks.  Access constraints, congestion in IDP camps, and poor health and sanitation infrastructure are becoming even more challenging in the context of COVID-19. Along with the Nigerian authorities, humanitarian actors are taking action to continue delivering life-saving humanitarian assistance while maintaining prevention measures. Insecurity due to ongoing hostilities and military operations have led to waves of mass displacement and continue to impact humanitarian operations. Vast swaths of Borno State are considered high or very high risk for international humanitarian actors, often constraining access to desperately vulnerable communities.

description_narrative: The current crisis in Libya is the result of conflict, political instability and a vacuum of effective governance, resulting in a further breakdown of functioning systems with considerable security, rule of law, social and economic consequences. Hundreds of thousands of people across the country are living in unsafe conditions and in volatile conflict areas, with little or no access to basic household goods and essential commodities, and with limited access to functioning basic services and utilities. This includes people exposed to violence and unable to access life-saving medical assistance, essential medicines, food, safe drinking water and sanitation, shelter and education

title_narrative: OCHA Jordan, support the response to the Syria crisis
OCHA Jordan, support the response to the Syria crisis
description_narrative: Office for the Coordination on Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Jordan coordinates the strategic planning of the Humanitarian Partnership Forum, on which UN agencies, development partners, international and local NGOs are represented. Increasingly, humanitarian and development goals are being pursued, beyond the refugee sphere, through complementary initiatives under the Humanitarian and Development Partners Group. The country office plays a core role in coordination with other humanitarian and development actors to define and implement the ‘Triple Nexus’ approach and localization agenda for Jordan. OCHA’s work in Jordan focuses on assisting the most vulnerable by coordinating the delivery of effective humanitarian aid and principled humanitarian action. To this end, OCHA contributes to humanitarian action in Jordan, focusing on three priority areas: humanitarian Coordination; humanitarian Financing; readiness/early Warning.

يقوم مكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية (أوتشا) في الأردن بتنسيق التخطيط الاستراتيجي لمنتدى الشراكة الإنسانية، الذي يمثّل فيه وكالات الأمم المتحدة وشركاء التنمية والمنظمات غير الحكومية الدولية والمحلية. ويتزايد السعي وراء الأهداف الإنسانية والإنمائية، ليتخطى نطاق اللاجئين، من خلال مبادرات تكميلية في إطار مجموعة شركاء التنمية والعمل الإنساني. كما يلعب المكتب القطري دورًا أساسيًا بالتنسيق مع الجهات الفاعلة الإنسانية والإنمائية الأخرى لتحديد وتنفيذ نهج "الترابط الثلاثي" وجدول أعمال التوطين للأردن. يركز عمل مكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية في الأردن على مساعدة الفئات الأكثر ضعفًا من خلال تنسيق إيصال المساعدات الإنسانية الفعّالة والعمل الإنساني القائم على المبادئ. وتحقيقًا لهذا الهدف، يساهم مكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية في العمل الإنساني في الأردن، مع التركيز على ثلاثة مجالات ذات الأولوية، وهي: التنسيق الإنساني؛ التمويل الإنساني؛ التأهب/الإنذار المبكّر.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) coordinates the global emergency response to save lives and protect people in humanitarian crises. We advocate for effective and principled humanitarian action by all, for all. With its partners, OCHA contributes to principled and effective humanitarian response through coordination, advocacy, policy, information management and humanitarian financing tools and services. OCHA’s country and regional offices are responsible for delivering the core functions in the field by leveraging functional expertise throughout the organization.
