title_narrative: OCHA Field activities, Latin America and the Caribbean (regional)
OCHA Field activities, Latin America and the Caribbean (regional)
description_narrative: El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras, countries that make up the North of Central America (NCA), bring together a series of humanitarian needs driven by shared conditions of high poverty, recurrent climate shocks, chronic violence, limited access to health services and migratory flows from and to within their countries, among other factors. The different needs produced by these long-standing conditions have formed a complex fabric of vulnerabilities that humanitarian action has sought to address with intersectoral approaches for several years. Despite achievements in providing holistic responses to multidimensional needs in the NCA, humanitarian action in these countries was forced to drastically reconfigure in 2020 in the face of the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic and seasonal most active hurricane ever recorded.

El Salvador, Guatemala y Honduras, países que conforman el Norte de Centroamérica (NCA), reúnen una serie de necesidades humanitarias impulsadas por condiciones compartidas de pobreza elevada, choques climáticos recurrentes, violencia crónica, acceso limitado a servicios de salud y flujos migratorios desde y dentro de sus países, entre otros factores. Las distintas necesidades producidas por estas condiciones de larga data han formado un tejido complejo de vulnerabilidades que la acción humanitaria ha buscado atender con abordajes intersectoriales desde hace varios años. Pese a los logros en brindar respuestas holísticas a las necesidades multidimensionales en el NCA, la acción humanitaria en estos países se vio obligada a reconfigurarse, de manera drástica, en el 2020 ante los impactos de la pandemia de la COVID-19 y de la temporada de huracanes más activa jamás registrada.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: OCHA's mission is to coordinate the global emergency response to save lives and protect people in humanitarian crises advocating for effective and principled humanitarian action by all, for all. OCHA coordinates humanitarian response to expand the reach of humanitarian action, improve prioritization and reduce duplication, ensuring that assistance and protection reach the people who need it most. OCHA plays a key role in operational coordination in crisis situations. This includes assessing situations and needs; agreeing common priorities; developing common strategies to address issues such as negotiating access, mobilizing funding and other resources; clarifying consistent public messaging; and monitoring progress.

La mission du Bureau de la coordination des affaires humanitaires (BCAH) est de coordonner la réponse d'urgence mondiale pour sauver des vies et protéger les personnes dans les crises humanitaires en plaidant pour une action humanitaire efficace et fondée sur des principes par tous, pour tous. OCHA coordonne la réponse humanitaire pour étendre la portée de l'action humanitaire, améliorer la hiérarchisation et réduire les doubles emplois, en veillant à ce que l'assistance et la protection parviennent aux personnes qui en ont le plus besoin. OCHA joue un rôle clé dans la coordination opérationnelle dans les situations de crise. Cela comprend l'évaluation des situations et des besoins; convenir de priorités communes; l'élaboration de stratégies communes pour résoudre des problèmes tels que la négociation de l'accès, la mobilisation de financements et d'autres ressources ; clarifier les messages publics cohérents ; et le suivi des progrès.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative: OCHA regional support to the Syria crisis
OCHA regional support to the Syria crisis
description_narrative: Jordan is a key strategic partner for the UN and the international community. An island of stability in a troubled region, it has been a generous host to refugees throughout its history. Since the onset of the Syrian crisis in 2011, over one million Syrians have fled into Jordan, of which 662,000 are registered refugees.  Office for the Coordination on Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) regional support to the Syria crisis continued to provide support in policy, planning, operational coordination and administrative services to humanitarian organizations across the response. It brings together humanitarian organizations working from within and outside Syria to develop a shared analysis, common objectives and a collective focus on results. The regional support focuses on enhancing its engagement and coordination with key regional stakeholders in the response, namely UN Regional Directors, international NGOs, Member States and donors.

الأردن شريك استراتيجي رئيسي للأمم المتحدة والمجتمع الدولي. فهي بمثابة جزيرة الاستقرار داخل منطقة مضطربة، وكانت على مدار تاريخها، مضيفة سخية للاجئين. منذ اندلاع الأزمة السورية في عام 2011، حيث فرّ أكثر من مليون سوري إلى الأردن، منهم 662 ألف لاجئ مسجّل. واستمر الدعم الإقليمي لمكتب تنسيق الشؤون الإنسانية (أوتشا) للأزمة السورية من خلال تقديم الدعم في مجالات السياسة والتخطيط والتنسيق التشغيلي والخدمات الإدارية للمنظمات الإنسانية عبر الاستجابة. فيجمع المكتب المنظمات الإنسانية العاملة من داخل سوريا وخارجها لتطوير تحليل مشترك وأهداف مشتركة والتركيز الجماعي على النتائج. ويركز الدعم الإقليمي على تعزيز مشاركته مع أصحاب المصلحة الإقليميين الرئيسيين في الاستجابة والتنسيق لها، ولا سيما مع المديرين الإقليميين للأمم المتحدة والمنظمات غير الحكومية الدولية والدول الأعضاء والجهات المانحة.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) was established in September 2004 in Chad by the United Nations Emergency Relief Coordinator (ERC) to provide a large-scale humanitarian response to nearly 200,000 people from Sudan neighbor (Darfur) between 2003 and 2004. The OCHA team in Chad works closely with the entire humanitarian community, which includes government entities at the national and provincial levels, 11 UN agencies, 48 ??international NGOs and 67 national NGOs. On the strength of the excellent collaboration resulting from these partnerships, OCHA plays an important role in coordinating the response to the various crises by setting up, whenever necessary, While working to ensure the maintenance of humanitarian space, OCHA is also working to strengthen the capacities of partners and to achieve greater coherence between humanitarian, development and peacebuilding activities through effective collaboration with all actors and by seeking the involvement of all, from the planning stage to the identification of priorities for humanitarian action in Chad. This active and inclusive partnership makes it possible to address, in a coordinated manner, the humanitarian consequences caused by the recurrent crises linked in particular to food insecurity and malnutrition, population movements, health emergencies, and the negative effects of climate change (floods and drought) and at the same time strengthen the resilience of populations.

Le Bureau de la Coordination des Affaires Humanitaires (OCHA) a été établi en septembre 2004 au Tchad par le Coordonnateur des Secours d'Urgence des Nations Unies (ERC) pour apporter une réponse humanitaire d’envergure à près de 200 000 personnes venues du Soudan voisin (Darfour) entre 2003 et 2004. L'équipe OCHA au Tchad travaille en étroite collaboration avec l'ensemble de la communauté humanitaire, qui comprend des entités gouvernementales aux niveaux national et provincial, 11 agences des Nations Unies, 48 ONG internationales et 67 ONG nationales. Fort d’une excellente collaboration issue de ces partenariats, OCHA joue un rôle important dans la coordination de la réponse aux différentes crises en mettant en place, chaque fois que nécessaire, des mécanismes de coordination de l’assistance humanitaire internationale adaptés au contexte et en appui au gouvernement pour apporter secours et assistance aux populations locales affectées. Tout en œuvrant pour assurer le maintien de l’espace humanitaire, OCHA travaille par ailleurs au renforcement des capacités des partenaires et à une plus grande cohérence entre les activités humanitaires, de développement et de consolidation de la paix à travers une collaboration efficace avec tous les acteurs et en recherchant l’implication de tous, depuis le stade de la planification à l’indentification des priorités de l’action humanitaire au Tchad. Ce partenariat actif et inclusif permet d’adresser de façon coordonnée, les conséquences humanitaires engendrées par les crises récurrentes liées notamment à l'insécurité alimentaire et à la malnutrition, aux mouvements de populations, aux urgences sanitaires, et aux effets négatifs du changement climatique (inondations et sécheresse) et de renforcer concomitamment la résilience des populations.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description_narrative: The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has been present in Niger since 2005, a year particularly marked by a serious food crisis. Since then, OCHA Niger, in support of the Humanitarian Coordinator and the Government, coordinates emergency assistance to populations affected by multiple crises. OCHA Niger works in close collaboration with all State structures both in the field and in Niamey, highlighting, whenever possible, the leadership of national structures, while ensuring respect for humanitarian and operational principles. Niger faces a complex humanitarian emergency marked by continued insecurity and violence against civilians perpetrated by elements of armed groups, endemic poverty, the effects of climate change, including seasonal flooding and pockets of drought. The humanitarian situation is further aggravated by the COVID-19 pandemic which is leading to an exponential increase in needs.

Le Bureau de la Coordination des Affaires Humanitaires (OCHA) est présent au Niger depuis 2005, une année particulièrement marquée par une grave crise alimentaire. Depuis lors, OCHA Niger en appui au Coordonnateur Humanitaire et au Gouvernement assure la coordination de l’assistance d’urgence aux populations affectées par des crises multiples. OCHA Niger travaille en étroite collaboration avec toutes les structures de l’État tant sur le terrain qu’au niveau de Niamey en mettant en évidence, chaque fois que possible, le leadership des structures nationales, tout en veillant au respect des principes humanitaires et opérationnels. Le Niger est confronté à une urgence humanitaire complexe marquée par l'insécurité et la violence continues contre les civils perpétrées par des éléments des groupes armés, la pauvreté endémique, les effets du changement climatique, y compris les inondations saisonnières et les poches de sécheresse. La situation humanitaire est encore aggravée par la pandémie de la COVID-19 qui entraîne une augmentation exponentielle des besoins.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

fields.Org Description: The Peace Research Institute Oslo (PRIO) conducts research on the conditions for peaceful relations between states, groups and people.

fields.Project Description: The Violence & Impacts Early-Warning System (VIEWS) is an academic research consortium and conflict prediction system jointly led by Uppsala University and the Peace Research Institute Oslo. The VIEWS consortium brings together a suite of interrelated projects dedicated to exploring state-of-the-art approaches for studying and predicting the risk of violent conflicts and their impacts on society and human development.

Since the end of World War II, the practice of peace mediation was restricted to diplomatic circles and international organizations, such as the United Nations. In recent decades, however, the field has witnessed the emergence of a new group of non-governmental actors known as Peace Facilitation Organizations (PFOs). PFOs are defined as independent organizations whose work consists of facilitating, advising, supporting, or implementing peace mediation or dialogue initiatives. The PFOs mapping dataset documents the PFOs that currently operate worldwide and provides information on their background, structure, approach, modus operandi, funding model, and other characteristics. The mapping aims to shed light on this field and identify these organizations, primarily from Western countries, that have professionalized peace mediation and contributed a certain degree of dexterity and standardization to peace processes.
UCDP offers conflict datasets, battle event data, and fatalities statistics to support academic and policy research on global violence trends.

fields.Project/Product Name: EMPOW: Women’s Empowerment in Peace Processes
fields.Project Description: EMPOW will address the data gap on Women, Peace and Security (WPS) by creating interoperable datasets: EMPOW Agency and EMPOW Reform. The objective is to generate and harmonize data on women's empowerment across all peace process phases—from pre-negotiations to post-war peacebuilding—and ensure compatibility with leading crisis data, such as the Uppsala Conflict Data Program.

fields.Project/Product Name: NYU + VIEWS: Data for Peace Conference
fields.Project Description: The Data for Peace Conference gathers national and international stakeholders for a multi-day hybrid programme focused on leveraging data, analytics, and emerging technologies for peacebuilding and prevention. Through panels, workshops, pitches, and networking sessions, the event strengthens collaboration across the humanitarian–development–peace and climate sectors and promotes practical capacity building for the global data-for-peace community.

Since 2013, Data-Pop Alliance has worked to apply cutting edge data science to solve the world’s most pressing problems. As the 2030 deadline for the UN sustainable development goals approaches, we believe novel approaches are needed to enhance the efficacy of the global development sector and reach those most in need.

fields.Project Description: The Data, Technology & Innovation (DTI) Initiative applies data science, AI, and scalable platform development to create ethical, sustainable digital tools for social impact. Combining dashboards, AI platforms, and applied ML research, it transforms complex datasets into actionable insights that strengthen decision-making for organizations and communities globally.

Data-Pop Alliance Capacity & Training Services build data literacy at scale by integrating technical, policy, and ethical perspectives into a global learning ecosystem. Through workshops, technical courses, and the Open Learning Hub, the initiative enables professionals to navigate opportunities and challenges, apply data science methods to non-traditional data sources, and advance equitable, evidence-driven decision-making across development and humanitarian contexts.

description_narrative:
INSO is a unique global humanitarian NGO established in 2011 and solely dedicated to enabling 
humanitarian safety and access in high-risk contexts. INSO was born from a need to establish a 
community resource and to promote good practice in the sector. The need for INSO field 
operations is self-identified by NGOs operating in each context. INSO makes its data and 
evidence-based findings available to registered partners and also uses them directly within its 
own public engagement to influence global discourse, systems and policies.

title_narrative: Improved protection of relief personnel and improved  effectiveness of humanitarian action Mozambique
description_narrative:
Humanitarian organisations in Mozambique have access to timely, 
reliable, and high-quality safety services that help them plan, operate, 
and deliver aid more safely. 
Result 1: Information, Analysis and Advice – NGOs are provided with 
objective, credible, reliable, and high-quality security information 
analysis, and advice in a timely and appropriate manner.
Result 2: Security Management, Preparedness and Capacity 
Development – NGOs are supported in developing their security and 
crisis management preparedness and capacity through direct support 
and training.

sector_narrative: INSO provides a range of support services to non-profit humanitarian organisations including crisis support and coordination, capacity building, training information management, analysis advice, etc.
description_narrative: A 45-month project with a budget of 5.000.000 EUR from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands for the project titled 'Supporting Humanitarian Safety III' under Policy Objective 1 of the programme grant 'Strengthening the Humanitarian Sector 2024-2027': More effective application of humanitarian principles and international humanitarian law, enabling more humanitarian responders to do their work safely and access populations in need. To contribute to this policy objective, INSO will i) provide access to adaptive NGO safety and access platforms via field-based, remote and mobile interventions, ii) establish a common operating picture by expanding the Conflict and Humanitarian Data Centre's coverage and its application, iii) develop operational advocacy, research and coordination.

sector_narrative: INSO provides free safety and security services to NGOs working for the benefit of the world’s most vulnerable people. This includes analysis and reporting, training, crisis coordination, safety and security alerts.
description_narrative:
The overall objectives of the Core Activities are:  

a) the relief and development of people in need anywhere in the world who are the victims of conflict, natural disaster, insecurity or crisis. 

b) the welfare and safety of people involved in the provision of humanitarian and development aid anywhere in the world.  

These objectives will be accomplished by:  a) providing dedicated safety & security services to organisations working to achieve the relief and development of people in need. b) promoting and facilitating a wider understanding of conflict and its impact on humanitarian and development safety. This mandates supporting activities such as policy support, advocacy, research and communications.

title_narrative: NGO Safety Programme- Provision of Security Information to NGO's
description_narrative: This activity NGO Safety Programme- Provision of Security Information to NGO's  is a component of Somalia Humanitarian and Resilience Programme (SHARP) 2018-2022 reported by FCDO with a funding type of 111 - Not for profit organisation and a budget of £1,125,000. It works in the following sector(s): Relief co-ordination and support services, Disaster prevention and preparedness.

The programme will contribute to making humanitarian responses by FCDO and the international humanitarian system more effective as a core priority of the UK Government’s International Development Strategy (IDS). It will support specialised enabling services which are aligned to the three priorities of the Humanitarian Framework: independent data collection and analysis (prioritise); contributing to improved access and inclusion of vulnerable groups (protect); and strengthening early warning and risk management (prevent). The programme will deploy enabling services in rapid onset and protracted crises; complementing and informing the FCDO’s response and providing “global public goods” that multiply the impact of others.

To provide life-saving assistance to around six million crisis-affected and vulnerable people across five Sahelian countries, Mali, Niger, Chad, Mauritania and Burkina Faso. This support includes food and cash assistance for those suffering from food insecurity, therapeutic food and early detection of severe acute malnutrition, basic support to livelihoods through the provision of seeds and tools, animal food and animal vaccinations, improved access to safe water and hygiene, and emergency health and medicine. Research will be commissioned to build the evidence base for integrated nutrition assistance and to improve the understanding of required nutritional interventions in the Sahel.

This programme will provide funding to a small number of leading international response organisations in the fields of safety, security, early warning, advice and risk analysis. This network of specialists provide global public goods which improve the overall effectiveness of humanitarian response to both rapid and slow onset humanitarian crises.

HARP will enhance overall effectiveness of the UN-led humanitarian response, including a focus on building Nigerian ownership.

title_narrative: Sahel Humanitarian Assistance and Protection Programme 2021-2028
description_narrative: The SHAPP will provide assistance and protection for the most vulnerable in geographic hotspots of most acute need in the Sahel. Hotspots are found across the region where consequences of conflict, including violations of international humanitarian and human rights law, are making pre-existing food insecurity and malnutrition worse. The SHAPP will address as many basic needs as possible of the most vulnerable including child protection, support to victims or survivors of gender based violence, food, nutrition, water and sanitation. Human rights and international humanitarian law will remain at the centre of the new programme by informing and driving SHAPP design and priorities.

fields.Org Description: GEM is a non-profit, scientific, public-private partnership that fosters global collaboration, developing transparent earthquake risk assessment resources for worldwide risk management.

fields.Project Description: The Global Exposure Database (GED) is a spatial dataset developed by GEM that quantifies the exposure of buildings and infrastructure to natural hazards across countries. It encompasses structural typologies, occupancy data, and geographic distributions, allowing users to estimate potential losses from earthquakes and other disasters. GED is openly available and is widely utilized alongside hazard models to inform national disaster risk management strategies and to support resilience in urban development planning.

Territory Seismic Risk Profiles offer consolidated snapshots of seismic hazard and risk through social indicators, exposure and loss metrics, building class information, historical earthquake impacts, and mapped distributions of hazard and vulnerability. Based on 100,000-year simulated event models, they support risk management across residential, commercial, and industrial sectors.

Developed by the Global Earthquake Model (GEM) Foundation, the OpenQuake Platform is an open-source tool for seismic hazard and risk assessment. It provides researchers, engineers, and governments with models, tools, and databases to simulate earthquake impacts, assess vulnerability, and inform urban planning and disaster preparedness strategies. OpenQuake integrates data on seismicity, exposure, and building fragility, and is widely used in both academic research and national risk management initiatives.

The Global Vulnerability Model consists of a set of functions that estimate the consequences of earthquakes of a given intensity to different building typologies. The database is separated by region-country/territory and considers functions for over 3500 building typologies identified in the Global Exposure Model developed, curated and maintained by the GEM Foundation. The fragility functions are derived analytically, using non-linear time-history analyses on equivalent single-degree-of-freedom oscillators and a large set of ground motion records representing several tectonic environments.

The Global Seismic Risk Map  poster comprises three global maps, and a ranking of the top 15 countries according to five risk metrics. The main map presents the geographic distribution of average annual loss (AAL) of the built-up area due to ground shaking in the residential, commercial and industrial building stock. It does not consider the effects of tsunamis, liquefaction, landslides, and fires following earthquakes.

The Global Seismic Hazard Map (GSHM), developed under the auspices of the Global Earthquake Model (GEM), provides probabilistic assessments of earthquake hazards worldwide. It combines global seismicity data, geological models, and ground motion prediction equations to estimate the likelihood of earthquake-induced ground shaking. The GSHM supports disaster risk reduction, urban planning, and insurance risk modeling by offering a harmonized and peer-reviewed reference for national and regional seismic hazard assessments.

fields.Org Description: Fields Data focusses on having data ready before the occurrence of a disaster, thereby saving lives through preparedness and efficient response.

fields.Project Description: In the daily whirlwind, the data avalanche generated is often underestimated. However, there is a significant opportunity in standardizing and organizing this information. Doing so unlocks valuable lessons from the past, enhances efficiency, and supports informed, strategic decision-making.

At the heart of every humanitarian mission lies the critical 3Ws: identifying who is doing what and where. This approach ensures effective coordination, resource allocation, and response by providing a clear overview of the actors involved, their activities, and their locations. The 3W & Connections asset supports humanitarian efforts by mapping these essential elements, enabling organizations to collaborate efficiently and address needs on the ground.

The ROOTS Portal provides a comprehensive dataset on local organizations, featuring a 3W map (Who does What, Where) that outlines the operational presence of both national and international organizations. This platform enables users to access detailed information about the activities and locations of various organizations, supporting coordination and informed decision-making.

Embracing a grassroots ethos, the team forges vital connections on the frontline. Before initiating data collection, they thoroughly explore the digital landscape to identify existing efforts and avoid redundancy. These online insights are then integrated with raw field data, gathered through collaboration with trusted local partners.

fields.Org Description: MapSwipe is a humanitarian crowdsourcing app where volunteers swipe through satellite images to help map vulnerable areas that aid organizations rely on.

fields.Project Description: Each year, disasters around the world kill nearly 100,000 people and affect or displace 200 million more. Many of the locations where these disasters occur are not represented on open and accessible maps, leaving first responders without the critical information needed to make informed decisions about relief efforts. Missing Maps is an open, collaborative project designed to map areas where humanitarian organizations are working to address the needs of people living at risk of disasters and crises. This initiative enables volunteers to contribute to mapping efforts, helping to ensure that vulnerable communities are visible and better supported during emergencies.

MapSwipe coordinates volunteer mapping of satellite imagery to create open building and infrastructure datasets in underserved areas. It supports crisis mapping, response planning, and humanitarian targeting.

fields.Org Description: Founded in 1956, the Danish Refugee Council (DRC) is Denmark’s largest international NGO, with a specific expertise in forced displacement. DRC is present in close to 40 countries. DRC advocates for the rights of and solutions for displacement-affected communities, and provides assistance during all stages of displacement: In acute crisis, in exile, when settling and integrating in a new place, or upon return. DRC supports displaced persons in becoming self-reliant and included into hosting societies. DRC works with civil society and responsible authorities to promote protection of rights and inclusion.

title_narrative: DANIDA SPA 2023 Top-up Turkey Earthquake II
description_narrative: A massive earthquake (magnitude 7.8) with its epicentre near Gaziantep affected southern Turkey and northern Syria in the early hours of 6th February 2023. A series of aftershocks and subsequent earthquakes continue to cause large scale damage, loss of life and severe damage to infrastructure in the area. The areas in southern Türkiye host some of the largest populations of Syrian refugees – estimated to be approximately 3.7million in total across the country.Emergency services are still carrying out search and rescue operations (6th February, 1530h) in the affected areas, but initial reports indicate massive damage to housing stock, coming in the midst of extreme winter conditions in the area, and compounding existing severe economic and protection challenges being faced by both refugee and host populations.DRC’s Türkiye operation is headquartered in the city of Hatay – one of the worst affected areas, with its own field offices and bases, and partner presence across some of the areas most impacted by the earthquake – Kilis, Kahramanmarash, Sanliurfa and Antakya.While damage and need assessments are yet to be carried out, DRC has initiated response measures aimed at responding to what are likely to be most high priority needs. This is based on initial reports from the area and past experiences of responses to earthquakes. These include:

Syrian Regional Response- Vulnerable populations linked to the Syrian crisis have improved access to rights and entitlements through legal aid and specialised protection services   Psychosocial Support (PSS) and case management services provided to conflict- and displacement-affected children and their caregivers- Improved self-reliance and resilience for host and Syrian refugee populations in the Middle East region through enhanced access to markets, and decent sustainable livelihoods in both urban and rural settings- In the Middle East, local civil society have stronger capacity to coordinate, articulate, and advocate for durable solutions for those displaced by the Syrian crisis- People in the Middle East benefit from programmes more aligned with existing institutions, markets and state support systems, including safety nets and social protection systems, based on evidence for more effective sustainable solutions across the humanitarian development nexus

Emerging Shocks and Stresses in Lebanon- Children, women at risk and PWSNs are empowered to prevent risk factors related to their health and protection, while promoting positive health and protection outcomes- Children, women at risk and PWSN’s protection have been enhanced through access to specialized quality protection and economic recovery services

fields.Org Description: REACH is a leading humanitarian initiative providing granular data, timely information and in-depth analysis from contexts of crisis, disaster and displacement. The work of REACH directly feeds into aid response and decision-making by providing accessible and precise information on the humanitarian situation of crisis-affected populations.

fields.Project Description: The Multi-Sectoral Needs Assessment (MSNA) is a standardized, country-level data collection initiative designed to capture comprehensive multi-sectoral needs among crisis-affected populations. Implemented by IMPACT Initiatives through its REACH Initiative, the MSNA collects statistically representative, household-level data on sectors such as food security, health, shelter, WASH, education, and protection. While the initiative is closely coordinated with OCHA and humanitarian clusters in country-led responses, the technical design, survey implementation, and analysis are primarily led by REACH/IMPACT, with operational support from agencies like IOM , WFP or IMMAP.

title_narrative: Joint Needs assessment for life saving assistance and evaluation of UK Aid
description_narrative:
The specific objectives of the multi-year WoAA are:	--- To develop an inter-sectoral evidence base which identifies priority areas and population groups with inter-sectoral, overlapping needs in order to facilitate an evidence-based integrated humanitarian response and to identify Cluster-pairings that can address multi-facetted needs effectively.
- To provide consolidated information about people in need and establish needs severity across the Whole of Afghanistan, supporting the annual People in Need calculations at sector and cross-sector level.
-To complement existent sector-specific information in terms of required indicators, geographical coverage, or both.
-To rationalise divergent approaches to identifying and categorising needs; a jointly agreed-upon process through the HCAWG. 
-	To identify sector-specific geographical and population group priorities through evidence-based severity ranking.
recipient_country_narrative:
With over 18 years of conflict, the effects of a devastating drought, and limited access to basic services, Afghanistan is entrenched in widespread poverty, displacement and great volatility. Therefore, unmet needs and vulnerability are exceedingly high, with a predicted 6.3 million people in need of humanitarian assistance across the country in 2019. 

Despite substantial improvements in the availability and quality of assessment data in Afghanistan, important gaps in terms of coordinating, analysing, and using this data - to inform the humanitarian response - remain

In 2018, the humanitarian community recognised the need for comprehensive, comparative and representative data, to appropriately respond to Afghanistan’s complex needs. This resulted in the first Whole of Afghanistan Assessment (WoAA). The WoAA was designed to increase humanitarian organisations’ understanding of the multi-sector needs and vulnerabilities of different population groups across Afghanistan by providing multi-sector baseline information for the 2019 Humanitarian Needs Overview (HNO) and for any subsequent adjustments in programming required to the current Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) (2018-2021). This assessment took substantial steps to ‘Improve Joint and Impartial Needs Assessments’, as outlined in the Grand Bargain Agenda, by strengthening last year’s evidence-base used by the humanitarian community, which previously depended upon heavily localised and not statistically sound data, resulting in the limited capacity of findings to determine priorities and guide planning

title_narrative: Independent Third Party Monitoring to support and maximise UK aid delivery in North East Nigeria
sector_narrative:
The ongoing humanitarian response has predominantly focused on relatively secure and accessible locations such as Maiduguri and other Local Government Area (LGA) capitals (e.g. Monguno, Bama, Gwoza, Mubi). However, almost 1 million people are believed to reside in inaccessible areas outside these towns, where persistent insecurity makes consistent humanitarian access challenging (HRP 2018). 
Years of conflict have disrupted agricultural activity, market functionality, and supply routes, leading to dire nutrition and food security conditions - an estimated 3.7 million and 3.5 million people to be in need of food and supplementary nutrition assistance, respectively. Borno State faces a particularly challenging food security situation, where 36% of the population are projected to face crisis or emergency phases of food and nutrition security from June-August 2018 (Cadre Harmonise, October 2017).
Displaced, non-displaced and returnee populations also face a deeply difficult protection situation, with the 2018 HRP estimating 5.8 million people in need of assistance. Protection concerns are wide-ranging, including conflict-related violence, gender-based violence, family separation, forced marriage, child marriage, forced displacement, arbitrary detention, seizure of belongings, and abduction. The protection threats facing populations are likely to be most acute in inaccessible rural areas with significant Armed Opposition Group (AOG) presence. A February 2018 REACH assessment focussing on recent displacement into the town of Pulka (Gwoza LGA, Borno State) found that, prior to escaping, civilians had been forcibly held captive in their villages for months by AOGs, who threatened them with beatings or execution if they tried to escape and frequently seized their harvests.
description_narrative: IMPACT Initiatives, with operational support from its global partner ACTED, in Consortium with Ground Truth Solutions as a sub-contracted partner, propose to conduct a Third Party Monitoring of the DFID-funded North East Nigeria Transition to Development (NENTAD) programme to provide an objective, external verification of aid delivery and ensured clear monitoring, accountability and analysis of good practices
recipient_country_narrative: Adamawa, Borno and Yobe States of North East Nigeria

title_narrative: Independent Monitoring, Evaluation and Data Analysis
description_narrative: In the context of Yemen, where data collection and analysis processes face extensive barriers, REACH has identified humanitarian coordination actors – primarily the Cluster system – as the most effective means to build capacity and unblock administrative barriers to these processes. By working within the Cluster system, REACH is able to directly liaise with dozens of NNGO, INGO, and UN partners to enhance and harmonize data collection, analysis, and utilization processes, in line with Goal 5 of the Grand Bargain. In working with a wide variety of partners within a recognized coordination structure, REACH ensures a broad impact across the humanitarian response, building the capacity of partners to collect and utilize data. In addition, enhancing the capacity of coordination partners to facilitate data collection and analysis creates a higher level of buy-in from Cluster and Working Group partners, ensuring increased levels of collaboration. In this way, REACH seeks to achieve long-term, sustainable change within the Yemen humanitarian system, and ensure robust, evidence-based planning at all levels of the response.

title_narrative: Regional strengthening of multi sector needs and analysis and drought response (24AWX)
description_narrative:
Objective 1 Improving access to and quality of information on the impact of drought on the population and their humanitarian needs for informed, evidence-based policy- and decision- making at county and community levels  

Objective 2 Provision of Remote Sensing and regional style analysis across the drought affected areas in the Horn of Africa Region (Kenya, Somalia, and Ethiopia).
recipient_country_narrative: Against the backdrop of an unprecedented drought, sharp price increases for commodities, reduced donor funding and a related slow humanitarian response across the region, vulnerable communities in the Arid lands in Kenya, South and Central Somalia, conflict- and drought-affected regions of Ethiopia are all facing potentially dire situations. REACH proposes a multi-pronged approach to fill information management gaps and enhance the response and prioritisation of humanitarian and government actors in all three drought affected countries. In Kenya REACH will conduct an assessment in Turkana and Marsabit counties, which are hard-hit by the drought and considered to be candidates to potentially deteriorate into IPC Phase 4 levels of food insecurity. REACH will provide a multi-sectoral lens to the National Drought Management Authority’s (NDMA) food security findings, to encourage implementing actors to take an integrated approach to humanitarian activities to minimise the risk of excess mortality. Under the proposed project’s second objective, REACH will strengthen the analysis and remote sensing capacity of its existing activities, to provide granular data culminating in an analysis output that highlights most vulnerable populations across all three countries.

title_narrative: Humanitarian Information Systems, Strengthening evidence-based decision making in South Sudan: HARISS Programme
description_narrative: The humanitarian response is South Sudan is faced with two central issues in terms of information management: 1) ability to regularly monitor humanitarian needs due to accessibility and security issues, inhibiting humanitarian planning and linked to this 2) the ability to effectively prioritise humanitarian assistance, which is becoming ever more urgent in the context of humanitarian needs increasing in severity and in geographic scale. To fill these identified information management gaps, REACH has been collaborating closely and feeding information into the humanitarian architecture in South Sudan to support in tracking of humanitarian needs. Primarily this has been conducted through its AoK remote monitoring (please see Section 4.5) and subsequent information sharing and collaboration with the clusters, the Inter-Cluster Working Group (ICWG) and the Integrated Phase Classification Technical Working Group (IPC TWG). To support improvements in the emergency response prioritization process, in early 2018, REACH played a central role in pushing for shifts in the humanitarian architecture to improve real-time analysis and evidence-based decision making through the set up and co-chairing of the Needs Analysis Working Group (NAWG), tasked with supporting ICWG in emergency response prioritization, and the development of the Integrated Needs Tracking System (INT), tasked by the FSL, WASH, Health and Nutrition clusters to develop an integrated needs monitoring system to support the clusters in prioritizing emergency areas for famine prevention responses.
recipient_country_narrative:
In the context of a widening and deepening humanitarian crisis in South Sudan, with needs escalating both in severity and geographic scale, effective aid prioritization has become an urgent priority. The IPC from October 2018 estimated 59% of South Sudan’s population to face crisis, emergency and catastrophic food insecurity, which makes evidence-based targeting of existing funds a critical necessity to save lives potentially at risk. 

At the same time, the dynamic and multi-faceted nature of the South Sudan crisis has created significant challenges for humanitarian information management. Accessibility and security issues within South Sudan have impeded systematic direct data collection efforts – limiting the ability to monitor needs and therefore provide timely information for effective targeting inside the country. As a result, it is becoming increasingly important to adopt adaptive and innovative approaches to filling information gaps in a systematic manner to promote more effective humanitarian response and planning.

title_narrative: REACH: Evidence-gathering on community perceptions, priority needs and preferences in Sri Lanka
description_narrative: accountability to affected population
recipient_country_narrative:
As of July 2022, Sri Lanka is facing an economic crisis rooted in high inflation, fuel shortages and low foreign exchange reserves. The UN Humanitarian Needs and Priorities (HNP) Plan (launched 09 June) estimated 5.7 people in need.   
While many, including WFP and FAO , expect a deterioration of the situation, there is still an absence of critical sources of information on community priorities in terms of humanitarian assistance as well as perceptions of ongoing programming among affected people. Moreover, humanitarian decision makers are faced with a critical gap of information on the differential impact of the crisis on various groups of people, especially in terms of how the compounding multi-dimensional crisis is exacerbating pre-existing vulnerabilities through a loss of access to resources and reduction in access to essential services among persons with disabilities, older people, female-headed households, persons with critical illnesses and others.
To support response actors to prioritize and plan with enhanced awareness of community preferences in terms of humanitarian assistance and modalities of assistance, REACH  proposes to launch a participatory assessment focused on Accountability to Affected People. The assessment will seek community triangulation of the assumptions that underly the current humanitarian response in terms of what the drivers of the crisis are, how the crisis is impacting the lives of people in crisis-affected areas, and what solutions should be pursued and supported by humanitarian actors from the point of view of local actors and affected people. The assessment would also aim to identify geographical areas and population groups that are particularly impacted by the crisis and whose needs and priorities should be monitored more closely by the response. REACH also proposes to collaborate with OCHA / the ISCG in country to facilitate a joint analysis session once preliminary findings are available, involving both the conventional coordination and response actors, such as ISCG members and key operational agency representatives, and local civil society organizations, including women-led groups, organizations of persons with disabilities (OPD), older people’s associations (OPA), and others.
The proposed activities are based on discussions with key actors operating in the country (OCHA, WFP, NGO consortia). Activities are also based on REACH’s previous experience responding to over 30 humanitarian crises and addressing critical information gaps in similar crises to Sri Lanka, including a growing portfolio of activities focusing on amplifying community voices through community engagement, as well as accountability to affected people.

title_narrative: Independent Third Party Monitoring (TPM) of selected FCDO-funded emergency programmes to support and maximise UK Aid delivery in DRC – Year II.
description_narrative: Intersectoral TPM

To provide independent oversight by combining regular light-touch verification with in-depth   thematic analysis to provide FCDO and partners with data and action points to contribute to increased aid effectiveness, accountability and evidence-based response planning. With the overall objective of both strengthening FCDO-funded aid interventions’ and partners’ effectiveness and efficiency, IMPACT Initiatives proposes to provide third party monitoring.
recipient_country_narrative:
The Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) faces one of the world’s most complex and long-standing humanitarian crises. In 2020, the country saw COVID-19 exacerbating existing vulnerabilities alongside a resurgence in armed conflict and violence, and 27 million people are currently in dire need of protection and humanitarian assistance (Humanitarian Needs Overview, 2022) - an increase of more than 5 million, especially due to the IPC food insecurity analysis. A combination of protracted conflict in parts of the country and additional shocks, including natural disasters and epidemics, has resulted in high sustained levels of humanitarian needs and large-scale population movement, with 5.7 million people affected by population movements in DRC, according to the 2022 HNO. 
In light of this fluid context, in particular in provinces in eastern DRC, where new shocks regularly lead to shifting needs and population movement, emergency programming including through rapid response mechanisms, such as those funded by FCDO. An FCDO-funded ODI publication identified an increasing trend of cash and voucher programming in the DRC humanitarian response. There is a lack of independent verification of large-scale humanitarian interventions to ensure quality, appropriate design, and impact on affected communities. Moreover, humanitarian assistance delivered to vulnerable populations in DRC, including through rapid response mechanisms and cash modalities, suffered from various aid integrity risks, as found in the Humanitarian Country Team and Joint Anti‐Fraud Taskforce-commissioned Operational Review, published in July 2020. Aid integrity has been found to be a significant issue within the DRC humanitarian response, with exposure of fraud and sexual exploitation cases. Despite efforts made by humanitarian actors, the review outlines a number of gaps and measures that would decrease the occurrence of fraudulent systems. 
Third Party Monitoring (TPM) is referenced in the review as one of the potential avenues mitigating the challenges of monitoring and evaluating programme implementation in high risk contexts. For the year to March 2022, IMPACT Initiatives has been delivering a Third Party Monitoring (TPM) pilot of selected FCDO-funded humanitarian interventions of the World Food Programme (WFP) and two partners under the SAFER (Strategic Assistance for Humanitarian Response in DRC) consortium partners (Mercy Corps and Solidarités International). In line with the overall sector focus as well as the identification of risks, this TPM has focused on cash and transfer interventions, especially those taking place in harder-to-reach locations. This current TPM is set to include six visits with resulting reports including practical recommendations, as well as an overall thematic piece on Accountability to Affected Populations.

title_narrative: Market Price Monitoring and Cash Feasibility Analysis - II
description_narrative: Contract related to: Market Price Monitoring and Cash Feasibility Analysis - II - The action aims to support agricultural recovery in the regions of Ethiopia hit by natural and man-made disasters (drought, conflict), and to contribute improving domestic food production and food security in the entire country. It builds on, and extends the existing programmes with high food security impact for smallholder farmers and pastoralists with an emphasis of female-headed households. Given the multidimensional nature of the problem, the action targets in particular the security of food supply chains, notably highly nutritional commodities, and the transition to environmentally and socially sustainable food systems. The objective will be achieved through:·      The delivery of seeds of improved varieties for nutritional content and resilience to climate change;·      The domestic production of organic fertilisers;·      The restoration of the livestock assets lost and the livestock service delivery systems destroyed in conflict and drought affected parts of the country;·      The establishment of complementary activities, such as monitoring food price evolution, mainstreaming rural employment for women and youth, promoting equal access and control over resources for men and women, defining methodologies on conflict resolution, and tailoring behavioural changes on nutritios food, to improve the effectiveness of the main activities.

description_narrative: The R2HC is a globally recognised research programme focuses on maximising the potential for public health research to bring about positive change in humanitarian response and helps inform decision making in humanitarian response.
To improve health outcomes by strengthening the evidence base for public health interventions in humanitarian crises.

name: UNDPPA: United Nations Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs

fields.Org Full Name: UNDPPA: United Nations Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs
fields.Org Description: The Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs (DPPA) plays a central role in United Nations efforts to prevent and resolve conflict around the world. DPPA supports the Secretary-General’s peace initiatives, oversees mediation, political transition and peacebuilding processes, and assists UN Member States as they carry out elections.

fields.Project Description: Developed by the DPPA’s Innovation Cell in collaboration with academic partners, Geoguard is the first-ever geospatial dashboard designed for decision-makers seeking insight on environmental and conflict risks across the Middle East, Central, and West Africa. Utilizing cutting-edge technology, Geoguard aggregates millions of data points on environmental conditions and geo-coded conflict events into an intuitive dashboard, drawing from diverse data sources as well as locally collected or crowd-sourced information. The platform provides immediate insight into environmental risk factors throughout specified regions and offers snapshots in time that are linked to trends in conflict and social unrest.

fields.Org Description: The U.S. Department of State is a federal government agency responsible for leading the nation’s foreign policy and international relations. It represents the United States to other countries, negotiates treaties and agreements, and promotes American interests abroad. The Department also provides support to U.S. citizens traveling or living overseas, issues passports and visas, and works to advance global peace, security, and prosperity. As the principal diplomatic arm of the federal government, the Department of State plays a vital role in shaping and implementing the country’s foreign policy objectives.

name: HOT: Humanitarian Open Street Map Team

fields.Org Full Name: HOT: Humanitarian Open Street Map Team
fields.Org Description: HOT is an international team dedicated to humanitarian action and community development through open mapping. We work together to provide map data which revolutionises disaster management, reduces risks, and contributes to achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals.

fields.Project Description: Managed by the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team, the Field Mapping Tasking Manager (FMTM) coordinates mapping campaigns in crisis zones through volunteer contributions. It organizes tasks, quality controls labeling, and integrates open geospatial datasets into humanitarian operational platforms.

Each year, disasters around the world kill nearly 100,000 people and affect or displace 200 million more. Many of the locations where these disasters occur are not represented on open and accessible maps, leaving first responders without the critical information needed to make informed decisions about relief efforts. Missing Maps is an open, collaborative project designed to map areas where humanitarian organizations are working to address the needs of people living at risk of disasters and crises. This initiative enables volunteers to contribute to mapping efforts, helping to ensure that vulnerable communities are visible and better supported during emergencies.

HOT is an international team dedicated to humanitarian action and community development through open mapping. The team collaborates to provide map data that revolutionizes disaster management, reduces risks, and contributes to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals.

The HOT Summits are a series of conferences by the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team, that bring together people from around the world working to make open geographic data available to improve the welfare of people living in vulnerable and disaster prone areas using OpenStreetMap as a foundation.

LearnOSM offers clear, easy-to-understand, step-by-step guides designed to help users get started with contributing to OpenStreetMap and utilizing OpenStreetMap data. For those interested in organizing an OpenStreetMap workshop, LearnOSM also provides comprehensive trainer resources.

name: ACLED: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data

fields.Org Full Name: ACLED: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data
fields.Org Description: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data (ACLED) is a disaggregated data collection, analysis, and crisis mapping initiative. ACLED collects information on the dates, actors, locations, fatalities, and types of all reported political violence and protest events around the world. The ACLED team conducts analysis to describe and explore conflict trends.

fields.Project Description: ACLED is a widely used conflict dataset that tracks the locations, dates, actors, and types of political violence and protest events across the world. Updated weekly, it covers over 150 countries and includes data on battles, riots, strategic developments, and civilian targeting. ACLED’s open-access data and analytical tools are used by policymakers, researchers, and humanitarian organizations to monitor conflict dynamics, assess risk, and support early warning systems and humanitarian planning.
The ACLED Conflict Alert System (CAST) is a conflict forecasting visualization platform designed to predict political violence events up to six months in the future for every country in the world.

ACLED Trendfinder offers an array of interconnected tools for tracking patterns of political violence and protest. Using the visualization platform, users can identify important changes in political violence and protest across and within countries, situate this activity within historical contexts, and spot early warning signs.
The Conflict Monitors cover key areas and are designed to support conflict analysis, violence-prevention initiatives, and efforts to monitor emerging crisis situations.

The Conflict Exposure Calculator integrates data from ACLED with population size estimates from WorldPop to estimate the civilian impact based on proximity to an event, event type, type of violent actor or specific armed group, location, and time.

fields.Org Description: IMPACT’s PANDA initiative aims to improve the effectiveness, efficiency and efficacy of humanitarian and development interventions. PANDA supports the entire humanitarian programme cycle, including programme design, assessments, baselines, monitoring and evaluation.

fields.Project Description: IMPACT’s PANDA builds capacities of local and international actors to understand crisis dynamics through training and tools in information management, assessments, monitoring and evaluation, and GIS. The initiative enhances partners’ analytical capabilities to improve the effectiveness and responsiveness of humanitarian interventions.

IMPACT’s PANDA initiative aims to improve the effectiveness, efficiency, and efficacy of humanitarian and development interventions. PANDA supports the entire humanitarian programme cycle, including programme design, assessments, baselines, monitoring, and evaluation.

title_narrative: Third Party Monitoring (TPM) project of the Humanitarian and Resilience Programme (HARP) portfolio in Northeast Nigeria
description_narrative: CLEAR Global, in consortium with Fact Foundation (FACT) and IMPACT Initiatives (IMPACT), proposes to (1) conduct Third Party Monitoring (TPM) of the Humanitarian and Resilience Programme (HARP) to ensure HARP-funded humanitarian programming is performed effectively, compliantly, and is attuned towards the needs of affected populations, while promoting continuous learning through innovative best practises for HARP’s Implementing Partners (IPs), as well as the wider humanitarian response; and (2) gather cash recipients’ feedback on cash and voucher assistance with Ground Truth Solutions as a sub-contracted supplier.

title_narrative: Humanitarian Information Systems Strengthening evidence-based decision making in South Sudan (HARISS)
description_narrative:
(1) Increased understanding and use of crisis-affected communities’ perceptions and experience of humanitarian activities to enable a community-centred approach in humanitarian programming
(2) Increased understanding of movement barriers and displacement routes to inform humanitarian decision-making at the county and hotspot level
(3) Improved, timely sub-national monitoring of needs and shocks across South Sudan
(4) Provision of an evidence-based contextualisation of livelihood coping strategies indicators to improve food security analysis and evidence-based prioritisation of aid delivery in South Sudan
(5) Increased understanding of the magnitude and severity of malnutrition and severity need classification for evidence-based decision making in designing and implementing nutrition programs
(6) Improved and informed evidence-based decision-making around emergency prioritisation by the ICCG and clusters, and around cash and resilience programming

3. Providing Technical Coordination and Support
4. Enhancing the Use of IM Services and Products

title_narrative: Joint Needs assessment for life saving assistance and evaluation of UK Aid
description_narrative:
The specific objectives of the multi-year WoAA are:	--- To develop an inter-sectoral evidence base which identifies priority areas and population groups with inter-sectoral, overlapping needs in order to facilitate an evidence-based integrated humanitarian response and to identify Cluster-pairings that can address multi-facetted needs effectively.
- To provide consolidated information about people in need and establish needs severity across the Whole of Afghanistan, supporting the annual People in Need calculations at sector and cross-sector level.
-To complement existent sector-specific information in terms of required indicators, geographical coverage, or both.
-To rationalise divergent approaches to identifying and categorising needs; a jointly agreed-upon process through the HCAWG. 
-	To identify sector-specific geographical and population group priorities through evidence-based severity ranking.
recipient_country_narrative:
With over 18 years of conflict, the effects of a devastating drought, and limited access to basic services, Afghanistan is entrenched in widespread poverty, displacement and great volatility. Therefore, unmet needs and vulnerability are exceedingly high, with a predicted 6.3 million people in need of humanitarian assistance across the country in 2019. 

Despite substantial improvements in the availability and quality of assessment data in Afghanistan, important gaps in terms of coordinating, analysing, and using this data - to inform the humanitarian response - remain

In 2018, the humanitarian community recognised the need for comprehensive, comparative and representative data, to appropriately respond to Afghanistan’s complex needs. This resulted in the first Whole of Afghanistan Assessment (WoAA). The WoAA was designed to increase humanitarian organisations’ understanding of the multi-sector needs and vulnerabilities of different population groups across Afghanistan by providing multi-sector baseline information for the 2019 Humanitarian Needs Overview (HNO) and for any subsequent adjustments in programming required to the current Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) (2018-2021). This assessment took substantial steps to ‘Improve Joint and Impartial Needs Assessments’, as outlined in the Grand Bargain Agenda, by strengthening last year’s evidence-base used by the humanitarian community, which previously depended upon heavily localised and not statistically sound data, resulting in the limited capacity of findings to determine priorities and guide planning

title_narrative: Independent Third Party Monitoring to support and maximise UK aid delivery in North East Nigeria
sector_narrative:
The ongoing humanitarian response has predominantly focused on relatively secure and accessible locations such as Maiduguri and other Local Government Area (LGA) capitals (e.g. Monguno, Bama, Gwoza, Mubi). However, almost 1 million people are believed to reside in inaccessible areas outside these towns, where persistent insecurity makes consistent humanitarian access challenging (HRP 2018). 
Years of conflict have disrupted agricultural activity, market functionality, and supply routes, leading to dire nutrition and food security conditions - an estimated 3.7 million and 3.5 million people to be in need of food and supplementary nutrition assistance, respectively. Borno State faces a particularly challenging food security situation, where 36% of the population are projected to face crisis or emergency phases of food and nutrition security from June-August 2018 (Cadre Harmonise, October 2017).
Displaced, non-displaced and returnee populations also face a deeply difficult protection situation, with the 2018 HRP estimating 5.8 million people in need of assistance. Protection concerns are wide-ranging, including conflict-related violence, gender-based violence, family separation, forced marriage, child marriage, forced displacement, arbitrary detention, seizure of belongings, and abduction. The protection threats facing populations are likely to be most acute in inaccessible rural areas with significant Armed Opposition Group (AOG) presence. A February 2018 REACH assessment focussing on recent displacement into the town of Pulka (Gwoza LGA, Borno State) found that, prior to escaping, civilians had been forcibly held captive in their villages for months by AOGs, who threatened them with beatings or execution if they tried to escape and frequently seized their harvests.
description_narrative: IMPACT Initiatives, with operational support from its global partner ACTED, in Consortium with Ground Truth Solutions as a sub-contracted partner, propose to conduct a Third Party Monitoring of the DFID-funded North East Nigeria Transition to Development (NENTAD) programme to provide an objective, external verification of aid delivery and ensured clear monitoring, accountability and analysis of good practices
recipient_country_narrative: Adamawa, Borno and Yobe States of North East Nigeria

title_narrative: Independent Monitoring, Evaluation and Data Analysis
description_narrative: In the context of Yemen, where data collection and analysis processes face extensive barriers, REACH has identified humanitarian coordination actors – primarily the Cluster system – as the most effective means to build capacity and unblock administrative barriers to these processes. By working within the Cluster system, REACH is able to directly liaise with dozens of NNGO, INGO, and UN partners to enhance and harmonize data collection, analysis, and utilization processes, in line with Goal 5 of the Grand Bargain. In working with a wide variety of partners within a recognized coordination structure, REACH ensures a broad impact across the humanitarian response, building the capacity of partners to collect and utilize data. In addition, enhancing the capacity of coordination partners to facilitate data collection and analysis creates a higher level of buy-in from Cluster and Working Group partners, ensuring increased levels of collaboration. In this way, REACH seeks to achieve long-term, sustainable change within the Yemen humanitarian system, and ensure robust, evidence-based planning at all levels of the response.

title_narrative: Regional strengthening of multi sector needs and analysis and drought response (24AWX)
description_narrative:
Objective 1 Improving access to and quality of information on the impact of drought on the population and their humanitarian needs for informed, evidence-based policy- and decision- making at county and community levels  

Objective 2 Provision of Remote Sensing and regional style analysis across the drought affected areas in the Horn of Africa Region (Kenya, Somalia, and Ethiopia).
recipient_country_narrative: Against the backdrop of an unprecedented drought, sharp price increases for commodities, reduced donor funding and a related slow humanitarian response across the region, vulnerable communities in the Arid lands in Kenya, South and Central Somalia, conflict- and drought-affected regions of Ethiopia are all facing potentially dire situations. REACH proposes a multi-pronged approach to fill information management gaps and enhance the response and prioritisation of humanitarian and government actors in all three drought affected countries. In Kenya REACH will conduct an assessment in Turkana and Marsabit counties, which are hard-hit by the drought and considered to be candidates to potentially deteriorate into IPC Phase 4 levels of food insecurity. REACH will provide a multi-sectoral lens to the National Drought Management Authority’s (NDMA) food security findings, to encourage implementing actors to take an integrated approach to humanitarian activities to minimise the risk of excess mortality. Under the proposed project’s second objective, REACH will strengthen the analysis and remote sensing capacity of its existing activities, to provide granular data culminating in an analysis output that highlights most vulnerable populations across all three countries.

A combination of protracted conflict in parts of the country and additional shocks, including natural disasters and epidemics, has resulted in high sustained levels of humanitarian needs and large-scale population movement, with 5.7 million people affected by population movements in DRC, according to the 2022 HNO. 
In light of this fluid context, in particular in provinces in eastern DRC, where new shocks regularly lead to shifting needs and population movement, emergency programming including through rapid response mechanisms, such as those funded by FCDO. An FCDO-funded ODI publication identified an increasing trend of cash and voucher programming in the DRC humanitarian response. There is a lack of independent verification of large-scale humanitarian interventions to ensure quality, appropriate design, and impact on affected communities. Moreover, humanitarian assistance delivered to vulnerable populations in DRC, including through rapid response mechanisms and cash modalities, suffered from various aid integrity risks, as found in the Humanitarian Country Team and Joint Anti‐Fraud Taskforce-commissioned Operational Review, published in July 2020. Aid integrity has been found to be a significant issue within the DRC humanitarian response, with exposure of fraud and sexual exploitation cases. Despite efforts made by humanitarian actors, the review outlines a number of gaps and measures that would decrease the occurrence of fraudulent systems. 
Third Party Monitoring (TPM) is referenced in the review as one of the potential avenues mitigating the challenges of monitoring and evaluating programme implementation in high risk contexts. For the year to March 2022, IMPACT Initiatives has been delivering a Third Party Monitoring (TPM) pilot of selected FCDO-funded humanitarian interventions of the World Food Programme (WFP) and two partners under the SAFER (Strategic Assistance for Humanitarian Response in DRC) consortium partners (Mercy Corps and Solidarités International). In line with the overall sector focus as well as the identification of risks, this TPM has focused on cash and transfer interventions, especially those taking place in harder-to-reach locations. This current TPM is set to include six visits with resulting reports including practical recommendations, as well as an overall thematic piece on Accountability to Affected Populations.

title_narrative: Market Price Monitoring and Cash Feasibility Analysis - II
description_narrative: Contract related to: Market Price Monitoring and Cash Feasibility Analysis - II - The action aims to support agricultural recovery in the regions of Ethiopia hit by natural and man-made disasters (drought, conflict), and to contribute improving domestic food production and food security in the entire country. It builds on, and extends the existing programmes with high food security impact for smallholder farmers and pastoralists with an emphasis of female-headed households. Given the multidimensional nature of the problem, the action targets in particular the security of food supply chains, notably highly nutritional commodities, and the transition to environmentally and socially sustainable food systems. The objective will be achieved through:·      The delivery of seeds of improved varieties for nutritional content and resilience to climate change;·      The domestic production of organic fertilisers;·      The restoration of the livestock assets lost and the livestock service delivery systems destroyed in conflict and drought affected parts of the country;·      The establishment of complementary activities, such as monitoring food price evolution, mainstreaming rural employment for women and youth, promoting equal access and control over resources for men and women, defining methodologies on conflict resolution, and tailoring behavioural changes on nutritios food, to improve the effectiveness of the main activities.

name: DHS: The Demographic and Health Survey

fields.Org Full Name: DHS: The Demographic and Health Survey
fields.Org Description: The DHS Program (Demographic and Health Surveys) is a primary source of data on health and population trends in developing countries, having provided technical assistance to over 300 surveys in more than 90 countries since 1984. They collect and disseminate nationally representative data on critical areas including fertility, family planning, maternal and child health, gender, HIV/AIDS, malaria, and nutrition. Funded by USAID and other donors, and implemented by ICF International, The DHS Program plays a vital role in advancing global understanding of health and population issues.

fields.Project Description: The Service Provision Assessment (SPA) is a health facility survey designed to collect information on service availability and Quality of Care (QoC) measures within a country’s health system. The SPA addresses the urgent need for actionable monitoring data in participating countries. It assesses the availability and quality of care for a wide range of services, with a particular focus on antenatal care (ANC), family planning (FP), maternity care, and sick child services. Quality of Care measures are evaluated across two dimensions: structural quality, which includes physical and human resources, and process quality, which encompasses the provision of care and the experience of care.

The Malaria Indicator Surveys (MIS) collect data on household ownership and use of mosquito nets, malaria prevention during pregnancy, and access to effective treatment for fever in children. These surveys often include biomarker testing for malaria and anemia, enabling countries to assess progress toward malaria control targets.

The Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) provide comprehensive and nationally representative data for monitoring and evaluating population, health, and nutrition indicators. These surveys support evidence-based decision-making and program design in developing countries by collecting high-quality information on fertility, family planning, maternal and child health, and HIV/AIDS.

The Key Indicators Survey (KIS) is designed to address the monitoring and evaluation needs of programs engaged in population and health activities in developing countries. It is particularly useful for generating data for small areas, such as regions, districts, or catchment areas, which may be the focus of individual projects. However, the KIS can also be applied in nationally representative surveys. The KIS tool comprises questionnaires, interviewer’s manuals, sampling guidelines, and a tabulation plan.

fields.Org Description: Data Friendly Space (DFS) provides trustworthy digital tools and actionable data for social impact organisations to fulfil their mission. We believe that the international community holds not just the knowledge, but also the responsibility to utilise emerging technologies and data to better prepare for and respond to humanitarian needs, support the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and accelerate climate action.

fields.Project Description: GANNET is a real-time, end-to-end Generative AI platform that combines near real-time assistance, analytics, and monitoring features for humanitarian data collaboration and effective decision-making.
