fields.Org Description: Start Network is a network of aid agencies across the world, working together to revolutionise the global humanitarian system.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO)

title_narrative: Start Fund - Emergency Response to affected population in Niger
description_narrative: After a terrorist attack by Boko Haram in north-eastern Nigeria, many people have fled to neighbouring Niger. Here they are staying with relatives or camping in designated areas. With money from an emergency relief fund, Welthungerhilfe supports refugees and host communities with food vouchers. This not only helps the people who urgently need help, but also the local markets. At the same time, the opportunity is taken to provide families with hygiene measures and information on healthy nutrition for young children.

The project outlined is the first early action intervention implemented in the course of the Forecast-based Action Programme due to a trigger of the drought monitoring and trigger model.The model detected a drouth during a plant-critical growing phase which is expected to result in increased food insecurity of most vulnerable households. As a result, an early warning was issued.

In line with the previously developed Early Action Protocol, most appropriate early actions are unconditional cash transfers. These shall mitigate the impacts of the imminend food insecurity of the targeted population. The transfers will be provided in 6 installments, the 1st distributions are expected to begin before the harvest (mid may) and end before the welding period when food insecurity is expected to peak.

Objective of the early actions are the minimization of drought impacts on the most vulnerable households. Early actions identified to mitigate the impending impact of drought on food security are unconditional cash transfers to the targeted population. These early emergency measures are fit to protect the food and nutrition security of the most vulnerable households. In order to keep families above the survival threshold and reduce the adoption of negative copying strategies, the uncodnidtional cash transfers will provide food aid and protection of goods to avoid further deterioration of livelihoods.

The approach will focus on using a shock-appropriate approach to increase capacity and synergize resources, ensure the integration of different activities in medium time to address the underlying vulnerabilities and risks, by mobilizing and raising awareness of communities (nutrition, hygiene-COVID) and effective coordination at different levels between institutions (local and central), communities and other actors with ongoing programs.

The expected crop loss and increased food insecurity are expected to mainly affect the region's most vulnerable group of people, who will suffer a significant loss of income from work and a protected loss of food for self-supply.

Based on the HEA result, households in the very poor socio-economic category will be covered by this project (analysis carried out in 2018-2019) whose number is estimated at 1496 households with a size of 5 people per household (Source LIAS HEA MG 7 2018-2019).

title_narrative: Emergency response to flood affected IDPs
description_narrative: The proposed  emergency response project is designed  to respond to the priorities identified by the target community.  This proposed action will tackle the most urgent needs of 7320 flood displaced people via combining shelter and WASH needs .
To provide lifesaving shelter and WASH assistance to particularly the most vulnerable flood affected IDPs

The primary objective of the proposed action is to support extremely deprived and vulnerable flood  1220 IDP families through provision of emergency shelter and WASH solutions. Although all community members have been affected by the flood, it is mainly under five children, PLW, female/child headed households and elderly/disabled who are the most vulnerable to shocks and stresses. WHH and APDA  have  paid careful attention whilst designing the action to the different risks, needs, priorities of these groups. The action takes into consideration the vulnerability of these groups whose daily life is predominately focused on or around their shelters and WASH NFIs. Consequentially, these groups also the one  face bigger protection risks associated with not having a dignified and safe living space.

title_narrative: Emergency live-saving Multi-Sectoral Response for drought affected communities in Ethiopia
description_narrative: There is a severe drought due to shortage of Hageyya/Bega rain in the area. The expected rain in September and October is delayed resulted critical water shortage for both human and animals, shortage in livestock feed and pasture and animal death, displacement as well as disrupted and affected the socio-economic status of the pastoralist communities. More than half a million-pastoralist people are significantly affected by the drought with their livestock.

The overall goal of this intervention is to save the lives of drought affected communities and also to contribute toward resiliency of the affected community to the recurrent drought effect through the provision of multi-sectoral WASH, livestock feed and multi-sectoral cash.

The specific objectives are: Save the lives and livelihood of drought affected pastoralist community through provision of WASH, cash and livelihood support; Enhance the livelihood and self-resilience of drought hit pastoralist communities

As per the latest census data from Ethiopian Central statistical agency , the average household size is 5.7 to 6 persons and hence 2500 households (15,000 people) will benefit from animal feed and multi-purpose cash grant and and hygiene promotion as well as COVID control and prevention activities.  the targeting will consider the level of vulnerability and drought impact of each household and particularly target women, female headed households, elderly and people with disability.

title_narrative: Start Fund - Emergency Response to affected population in Niger
description_narrative: Activation of the Start Alert  - 518 was made on the 22nd of April 2021, the CO was called for a session to respond to committee questions on the same day. A full proposal was submitted on 23rd April 2021 based on recommendations from committee. Final decision made to allocate Welthungerhilfe in collaboration with Concern Worldwide a project budget of 100,000.00 pounds sterling covering a 45 day project
Overall Objective - To contribute to immediate relief for conflict affected IDPs , refugees, returnees and host communities through provision of multi-purpose CASH and WASH community sensitisation.

The project will support 800 HHs composed of IDPs, Refugees, Returnees and host community members who have been affected by the recent clashes in Damasack which caused thousands of people to flee their homes.

title_narrative: Start Network, Strengthen and support to DRF system in Pakistan
description_narrative:
WHH response objectives are to:

overall development, agreement, and management of workplans, protocols, budgets and coordination structures to ensure that activities are happening as required for the set up of a national DRF system.
Coordinate a number of different stakeholders including NGOs, Government counterparts, consultants and local civil society to ensure that the right stakeholders are able to support different parts of the project.
When funding is triggered and released, the hub will monitor and support the implementation of pre-agreed standard operating procedures, convene project selection meetings and ensure that operations are delivered in a timely manner with humanitarian principles applied throughout.

The project will be run by START network through TWG and and local organizations, as START network response depending on emergency situation in Pakistan and following would be the expected beneficiaries based on emergency project/call:

    Targeting approximately 1000 HH (for each emergency response)
    Local NGO (for each emergency minimum 2 organizations)
    Technical working groups (drought, flood and heatwave)

 

The number of beneficiaries will increase or decrease based on the nature of emergency / need

title_narrative: Projet de réponse précoce lié aux effets néfaste de l'inondation au Madagascar
description_narrative: L'absence des organismes humanitaires dans des régions eloignées fragilise la capacité des communautés se trouvant dans la région en cas d'une situation d'urgence et matérialisé par le retard d'intervention au detriment des personnes victimes. L'intervention permettra aux ménages cibles de couvrir leurs besoins en termes de nourriture pendant la durée de leur déplacement et leur permettra ainsi de se rétablir plus rapidement une fois rentrés chez eux. 6000 personnes seront ciblés comme "participants" de projet et auront un appui financier par des transferts monétaires (cfw et transferts conditionnels).

In an important rice-growing area in Madagascar, the early warning system introduced by Welthungerhilfe has struck and predicted a drought. In accordance with the protocol agreed upon in advance, highly vulnerable farming families now receive cash in advance via mobile phones distributed in advance, so that they can prepare for the lean period and do not have to sell livestock later out of necessity, for example, or buy at inflated prices or take their children out of school. With the help of this anticipatory 'damage limitation', later - then much more costly - measures can be avoided.

title_narrative: WASH response to tropical storm Ana in Zimbabwe
description_narrative: The project aims to mitigate the effects of Tropical Storm Ana in selected wards in Zimbabwe by distributing 2000 hygiene kits to targeted households and rehabilitating of 2 piped water supply systems that were destroyed by the cyclone. Hygiene education campaigns will target 18000 people and water treatment chemicals will be distributed to 4839 households to prevent diarrheal outbreaks. Food aid to 100 most vulnerable households will be distributed. Capacity of local Disaster Risk Reduction structures (ward level) will be strengthened.

title_narrative: Emergency live-saving Multi-Sectoral Response for drought affected communities in Oromia Region of Ethiopia
Projet de réponse précoce lié aux effets néfaste de l'inondation au Madagascar
description_narrative: In the cyclone region in the southeast of Madagascar, especially in January and February, the poorest suffer from the consequences of the storms. Heavy rain and flooding are so predictable that Welthungerhilfe has set up an early warning system here, following the principles of the global "START Network", through which funds can be called up quickly and easily in the immediate run-up to a cyclone. In this way, the most vulnerable households in the affected communities can be provided with cash immediately after the storm, for example, so that they do not suffer for long, but can provide for themselves.

title_narrative: Emergency WASH and Cash Distribution, Nobili
description_narrative: The proposed project is focusing on two main pillars of immediate relief activities: WASH and Multipurpose Cash Transfer 1. WASH 1.1. Water Supply: the project will ensure sufficient supply of drinking water, as this has been stated as one of the priorities by the local crisis committee, including representative of the displaced families. To achieve this objective, WHH will deploy its water pumping and purification system from Goma and run it for at least 4 weeks. The system will be installed at the nearby river and provide 45m³-60m³ of water per day and will be running within 14 days. Considering the daily need at this stage at 10ltr (average, according to SPHERE standard) per person/day, the system can supply water for 4.500 - 6.000 people per day. Further, the project will repair two water catchments sites with 15 water points in total (to be repaired within 1 week), and additional 11 emergency water points with water purification will be established at places not connected to the public system and too far from the river. With these 3 layers of water supply, we aim to cover the immediate needs of the displaced population and host communities in need for 1 month. 1.2. Sanitation facilities The project aims to install emergency latrines and/or extend existing latrines and sanitation facilities in the public spaces where people are seeking shelter. 15 sites will be identified in close cooperation with the local crisis committee. Installation will be supported with workforce by people living on the compounds. The emergency latrines & handwashing stands will bring first relief and an improvement of the sanitation situation for 1,000 HH. 2 WASH Experts will be transferred from WHH Bunia to Nobili to implement the WASH component. These experts will be supported by locals, hired by WHH to support the response. 2. Multipurpose Cash Transfer WHH will use its experience in unconditional cash transfers to provide one time distribution of 35 USD per HH for up to 6.300 registered IDP households in Nobili town. Markets show full functionality and supplies can be purchased from Uganda. The multipurpose cash transfer has been decided, as the displaced families have different priorities and mainly lack the purchasing power to buy goods of their choice in the market. With the slightly reduced amount of 35 USD it is possible to reach all 6.300 displaced families. WHH will contract a local financial service provider, potentially a bank already contracted for another project, to distribute the cash to the beneficiaries. Market Monitoring (availability and prices) and a Post-Distribution Monitoring is planned. 1 Cash-Expert will be transferred from WHH Beni to Nobili to oversee the distribution. Community Mobiliser will support the registration and distribution. In summary, the planned activities will cover water supply for for 1 month, improve sanitation/hygiene situation for 1,000 HH and distribute 35 USD/household for 6.300 Households.

The project targets IDPs which are living with host families or in public spaces, such as schools, churches and market places. The total number of direct beneficiaries: 6300 Households * 6 (average HH size) = 37.800 beneficiaries. The total number of people benefiting from the different layers of the emergency water supply activities will be clearer.

After two years of insufficient rains and El Nina induced drought Zimbabwe is seeing significantly more rains than normal this season which is very likely linked to a mild La Nina phenomenon. Additionally, tropical Cyclone Dineo graduated into a tropical depression on the 16th ot February however lt still caused heavy precipitation in Bulawayo, Tsholotsho, Matobo, Kezi, Umzingwane, Bulilima, Gokwe South and Mberengwa districts causing riverine and flash flooding and subsequent destruction of livelihoods and properties. Gwayi river in Matebeleland North burst is banks which culminated in the inundation of homes and schools infrastructure causing considerable damage to property and livelihoods. GoZ declared state of disaster on 1 of March 2017 due to the flooding arid seeks international support to respond also particularly with regard to rehabilitation of infrastructure. WHH has been providing response already under the standing PCA with UNICEF.
The project will contribute to reduction in the negative impact of the floods on affected families. And hence the outcome will be improved coping mechanisms for the families affected by floods.
Project targets 1,200 HHs in Tsholotsho district (app. 50% women). 1HH = 5 persons

Unprecedented flooding, triggered by heavy rains as a result of remnants of Typhoon Lionrock, in north-eastern DPRK: "Areas in the Tumen River floodplain and its tributaries are acutely impacted with the counties of Musan, Yonsa, Hoeryong, and Onsong in North Harngyong province particularly severely affected." Emergency aid will rehabilitate buildings and other structures; affected people will be able to rapidly recover. It is expected that during the corning months, the combined approach of all organizations will secure livelihoods.
Enable affected households to concentrate on quickly rebuilding their sources of livelihoods.

The number of disabled persons is based on the 2008 census indicating 5.9% male and 6.3% female people of the total population. This includes people with visual and hearing impairments, locomotor disability, mental disability, speech and intellectual disability. We will assess if special needs are required for these households, and if so, of what nature. We will ensure that the most vulnerable households, containing pregnant and lactating women, children under 5 years old, and those consisting only of the elderly, will have preferential access to the kitchen, hygiene, and shelter kits. The remaining kits will be distributed to the population-at-large on a needs basis.

A tropical depression had brought heavy rain to the northwest and eastern parts of Madagascar for a period of seven days from the 19th to 23rd January, 2020. For the Alaotra region the rains continued until the 29th January, 2020. As a result of the flooding, a number of water sources, mainly wells, have been contaminated. Many of the impacted households, particularly economically vulnerable households, are already deprived of basic foods due to lack of accessibility and availability. Should an emergency intervention not be carried out, the risk from diseases and food insecurity are highly likely. In fact, WHH through this project will support vulnerable communities to enable them to meet their basic needs.

The overall objective of the Alaotra Flood Response Project is to contribute to the efforts of humanitarian and governmental actors assisting flood-affected vulnerable group. The intervention will enable the target households to recover within an convenient period of time so that they can regain their capacity and return to their normal lives. At the end of the operation, the results to be achieved are as follows: R1: Improvement of the beneficiaries' access to basic food R2: Reduction of the risk of contamination of water-related illnesses R3: Contribution to the improvement of the rebound capacity of affected and vulnerable communities Activities for each result: R1: A1: Selection of beneficiaries according to pre-established targeting criteria A2: To carry out an unconditional cash distribution for the benefit of the vulnerable while taking into account in advance the conditions of availability and accessibility of food products at the local level. A3: Creation of a temporary work opportunity through cash for work by prioritizing the sectors of intervention beforehand. R2: A1: Distribution of WASH kits to beneficiaries in a timely manner including water treatment products. A2: Identify the main sources of safe and accessible drinking water for the community for sanitation purposes A3: Sanitation of water sources through cash for work A4: Strengthen the dissemination of educational messages and continuous awareness raising for the actions to be taken in case of flooding, particularly in the field of WASH. R3 : Objectively verifiable indicators I1: At the end of the intervention, 100% of the target communities received timely assistance while taking into account the gender approach. I2: At the end of intervention, At the end of the intervention, 100% of the target communities were among the most vulnerable and needy communities. I3: At the end of the intervention, the allocated funds have been definitively and transparently spent on the project's objective.

WHH will target vulnerable households: - Households dependent on a daily income resource - Households deprived of their usual income resource - Households with low or insignificant food stocks - Households with problems of access to basic food for a fairly long period of time due to the lack of availability of labour as a main source of income. - Households affected by and affected by the flooding - Households that take longer to bounce back from the shock. The calculation of the number of beneficiaries is based on the results of studies on the Household Economy Analyses carried out in the area of this investment zone in 2018. At the end of this study, the proportion of socio-economic classes is distributed as follows: - The category of very poor covers 25% of the households in the zone. - The poor class category covers 38% of the households in the area. - The middle class category covers 23% of the households in the area. - The category for the wealthy class covers 14% of households in the area. As mentioned in the previous explanation, the beneficiaries of the project will be the economically vulnerable categories of households including the very poor and poor classes. For the target areas, the response will be focused on the six most impacted communes in Amparafaravola district. This gives us a total number of 1116 households i.e. 5580 persons with an average size of 5 persons per household.

title_narrative: START - Emergency WASH response in Budiriro and Glenview/Harare
description_narrative: The hygienic conditions in the affected areas in Budiriro and Glenview arc insufficient and chaotic. People neither have access to safe drinking water nor clean water for personal hygiene and cooking. Spread of water-borne diseases like typhoid fever is of very high risk. There is low use of household water treatment. The food sold in their areas is likely to contain typhoid bacteria. Sewage leaks occur and may be contaminating boreholes, Solid waste is not being collected and has formed dumps in open spaces. Typhoid in high density suburbs likely to spread further to other areas. Provision of NFI, namely soap and aqua tabs for three months arc the prinrary need. Furthermore, sensitizing and awareness rising of the population together with hygiene training is essential at this point; this includes mobilization, orientation and training of community health volunteers for response as well as provision of IEC material.

The project will contribute to reduction in morbidity and mortality due to typhoid diseases in Budiriro and Glen View minimize the risk of further spreading of Typhoid fever and other water-borne diseases in Harare. The outcome will be a significant decrease (80%) in the number of new suspected Tvphoid cases and reduced morbidity and mortality from typhoid and other water borne diseases in Glenview and Budiriro district of Harare.

The project will target 15,000 HHs (app. 75,000 people) in Budiriro and Glenview suburbs with NFI kits (soap and aquatabs/waterguard) tor 3 months. 20 boreholes will be repaired and fitted with in line chlorinators. 30,000 people will receive a hygiene message reminding them of the dangers of typhoid and how to avoid contracting the disease as well as what to do if they suspect they have contracted it.

title_narrative: Strengthening the preparedness of local communities/authorities for natural disasters, esp. flooding in the Zeravshan valley/Tajikistan in summer 2017
description_narrative: Tajikistan is prone to natural disasters, e.g. floods, earthquakes, landslides, mudflows, avalanches, droughts, and heavy snowfalls. Its mountainous terrain, coupled with the specific geological and hydrological conditions, translates into a high degrees of vulnerability towards climate change. At the same time, Tajikistan‘s deteriorating infrastructure has increased the population‘s vulnerability to extreme weather events and seismic risks. With most assets, including irrigation channels, river embankments, roads, bridges, and dams, built in the Soviet era, infrastructure maintenance remains weak due to limited financial resources and lack of knowledge by the government. Existing mudflow drainage systems along the villages are destroyed or slatted over the years, which when rapidly filled increase the risk of human casualties and physical damages. The costs of foreseen mudflows can be assessed much higher than for social and physical preparedness measures. With clear evidence of increased risk, combined with existing vulnerabilities in the most remote regions of Tajikistan, the Start Network voted in support of activating the Fund in anticipation of flooding and landslides.

- The negative impact of currently forecasted flooding/mudflows for the local population (human tools/destroyed infrastructure) will substantially be decreased and the resilience of the population towards disasters will be strengthened in the longer term. - The strengthened capacities of the local authorities and the better interaction between the local authorities and the local population will reduce the economic and human loss in the long term and can be copied to other areas at risk in the Zerafshan valley.

The pre-selected villages have been chosen upon strong request from the zonal CoES as there already smaller mudflows appeared. In total, the project will cover app. 2000 households with nearly 10.000 people. The whole community in the pre-selected high risk villages will benefit through the envisaged project activities like protecting infrastructure, capacity building including drills/simulation exercises, maintenance of EWSs etc. The beneficiaries are calculated on the basis of number of households with five members.

The project aims to lessen the immediate effects of drought on agropastoral households in Ranérou and Kanel and prevent worsening nutrition. It focuses on two main actions: providing anticipatory cash assistance to vulnerable families to meet essential food needs and avoid harmful coping strategies, and protecting the nutrition of young children and pregnant or breastfeeding women through community malnutrition screening, improved referrals, and promotion of good feeding practices. Targeting the areas hit hardest by low rainfall, the project relies on strong community engagement and local coordination to deliver a rapid, integrated response. Overall, it seeks to reduce livelihood losses, prevent acute malnutrition, and strengthen household resilience before the next lean season.

The project aims to provide a rapid, proactive response to food and nutritional insecurity. It aims to prepare the populations most likely to be affected by the lean season by providing them with financial and nutritional assistance.

title_narrative: Strengthening Drought Resilience in Zimbabwe: A Collaborative Approach to Anticipatory Actions in Beitbridge, Gwanda, Masvingo, Matobo, and Mwenezi
description_narrative: The project’s readiness activities are designed to ensure that Mwenezi communities, stakeholders, and systems are prepared to act quickly and effectively when forecasted risks emerge. The main objectives are to strengthen preparedness capacities through training, SOPs, financing mechanisms, and improved coordination; validate and update the Anticipatory Action Plan (AAP) with clear triggers such as rainfall anomalies, river levels, and food price changes; pre-position resources and partnerships with suppliers, communities, and authorities; and enhance community readiness through knowledge, communication tools, and tailored preparedness plans.The project will begin by updating and finalizing the AAP with local stakeholders to ensure its relevance. Activation activities will then address critical needs in water access, livestock health, and agricultural sustainability. At least two high-yield boreholes will be drilled or rehabilitated and fitted with solar technology, supported by water point committees, pump minder training, and conservation awareness. To protect livelihoods, 3,000 beneficiaries (750 households) will receive supplementary feed and veterinary services, alongside training in sustainable livestock management. For food security, the project will support 100 households in poultry and gardens, and provide small grain seed to 250 households, coupled with training in climate-smart agriculture. These actions will diversify incomes, sustain food production, and strengthen resilience.

The project will support coordination of partners within the sphere of anticipatory actions such as the anticipation hub for a harmonized implementation. With this grant, the participating organizations and other stakeholders will engage in consultative workshops to use the available forecast with support from the Ministry of water and environment, and office of the prime minister to engage communities timely before hazard onset. Developed plans will monitor available forecast and risk information, pre-agree thresholds for taking action, establish processes based on these thresholds for raising timely alerts, and identify, with communities, appropriate anticipatory actions. During the same consultative meetings, we will find out why some of the districts and their extension staff don't disseminate information to the persons usually affected so that  context specific means of dissemination are included in the plan.

title_narrative: Start Network Local Humanitarian Leadership Program
description_narrative: Start Network will tackle Policy Objective 3: A more equal dialogue among all partners throughout the humanitarian delivery chain about cooperation and the sharing of capacity and risks, facilitating increased local leadership; and Policy Objective 2: Increasingly, in response to crises caused by people as well, anticipatory humanitarian action is undertaken, reducing the upward pressure on humanitarian needs.
recipient_country_narrative: Multi-country humanitarian leadership program implemented in countries with Start Network LNNGO members, focusing on strengthening local humanitarian capacity, enhancing access to funding, and developing anticipatory action tools adapted to specific country contexts.

fields.Org Description:
Latinobarómetro Corporation is a non-profit NGO based in Santiago, Chile, and is solely responsible for the production and publication of the data.
Latinobarómetro Corporation researches the development of democracy and economies as well as societies, using indicators of opinion, attitudes, behaviour and values. Its results are used by social and political actors, international organizations, governments and the media.
The executive director of the study is Marta Lagos.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Spanish Agency for International Development Cooperation (AECID)
Global Affairs Canada (GAC) / Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development
fields.Agency Data Portal: Project Browser  International assistance projects funded by Global Affairs Canada https://w05.international.gc.ca/projectbrowser-banqueprojets/

fields.Agency/Department Name: International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (IDEA)
Development Bank of Latin America and the Caribbean (CAF)

fields.Project Description: Latinobarómetro is an annual public opinion survey that involves approximately 20,000 interviews in 18 Latin American countries, representing more than 600 million inhabitants. Some of the most relevant sections of the Latinobarómetro for freedom of expression and media development are "Democracy" and "Media, Internet and Social Media." Key topics include activities people like to do on the internet, perceptions of the use of private data for commercial purposes, and preferred social media platforms. The survey data is provided by Corporación Latinobarómetro.

fields.Project Description: The Latinobarómetro Online Analysis Platform enables users to explore and analyze data directly in their browser, without the need to download files or register. The platform is powered by JDSurvey, an analysis tool developed by JD Systems (Madrid), which is also responsible for maintaining the Latinobarómetro Data Archive.

fields.Org Description: Collaboration is Data2X’s guiding principle and signature way of working. This reflects our core strength: our convening power based on the trust we have earned from government, private sector, civil society, and academic partners. In the coming years, Data2X will play an even more active facilitator role, mobilizing stakeholders around a cooperative global approach to fill gender data gaps.

fields.Project Description: Data2X is a global partnership dedicated to advancing gender-responsive data systems. The organization develops research, advocacy, and tools to enhance data on women and girls, including initiatives focused on capacity strengthening and the provision of innovation grants.

name: IPC: Integrated Food Security Phase Classification

fields.Org Full Name: IPC: Integrated Food Security Phase Classification
fields.Org Description: The IPC global partnership is comprised of 19 organizations and inter-governmental institutions including Action Against Hunger (AAH), CARE International, Comité Permanent Inter-Etats de Lutte Contre la Sécheresse au Sahel (Permanent Interstate Committee for Drought Control in the Sahel) (CILSS), Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWS NET), the Global Food Security Cluster, the Global Nutrition Cluster, Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), Joint Research Centre (JRC) of the European Commission, Oxford Committee for Famine Relief (Oxfam), Southern African Development Community (SADC), Save the Children, Sistema de la Integración Centroamericana (Central American Integration System) (SICA), World Food Programme (WFP), United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), the World Bank, the Wolrd Health Organization (WHO), UNDP and IFPRI.

It enables users to download resource data for offline IPC analyses dating back to 2017. All national population figures are derived from official country population estimates, while IPC estimates are those published in country IPC reports.

fields.Project Description: IPC Infographics provide regularly updated visual summaries of acute food insecurity and malnutrition across crisis-affected countries. Drawing on IPC analytical processes, these snapshots translate complex assessments into accessible, country-specific insights used by policymakers, humanitarian actors, and early warning systems to monitor hunger trends and guide response planning.

fields.Org Description: The Pacific Community (SPC) is the principal scientific and technical organisation in the Pacific region, proudly supporting development since 1947. We are an international development organisation owned and governed by our 27 country and territory members. The Pacific Community supports sustainable development by applying a people-centred approach to science, research and technology across all of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). We serve our members by interweaving and harnessing the nexus of climate, ocean, land, culture, rights and good governance; through trusted partnerships; investing in Pacific people; and understanding Pacific contexts.

fields.Project Description: DisasterAWARE is a global platform that provides real-time hazard alerts, dashboards, and geospatial tools to support disaster preparedness and early warning. The platform integrates predictive models and hazard tracking using data from global datasets, enabling comprehensive monitoring and response to potential disasters.
This regional platform delivers open-access dashboards, geospatial tools, and statistics to support Pacific states with governance, climate resilience, and disaster response planning.

fields.Org Description: The United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) is the leading global authority on the environment. UNEP’s mission is to inspire, inform, and enable nations and peoples to improve their quality of life without compromising that of future generations.

fields.Project/Product Name: UN Environment Programme World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC)
fields.Project Description: UNEP-WCMC is a global science-policy interface that provides open-access datasets and tools on biodiversity, ecosystem services, and conservation strategies. Its data platforms support environmental reporting, climate resilience, and natural capital planning.

fields.Org Description: ACAPS, which originally stood for the "Assessment Capacities Project," is an independent, non-governmental organization that provides humanitarian information and analysis to support better-informed decision-making in crisis situations. It offers data and analysis on global humanitarian crises to organizations like the UN, humanitarian responders, and donors, with the goal of improving aid delivery and efficiency. ACAPS provides global analysis, and works with other organizations to improve evidence-based decision-making in humanitarian response.

fields.Agency/Department Name: Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO)
Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC)
Global Affairs Canada (GAC) / Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development

fields.Project Description: The INFORM Severity Index is an improved method for analyzing the severity of humanitarian crises on a global scale. It aims to enhance the management of humanitarian crises by providing decision-makers with a comparable and reliable summary of information regarding the severity of such crises. This information is updated monthly and is applicable worldwide. Since 2016, INFORM partners have been developing the INFORM Severity Index to complement the widely used INFORM Risk Index.
The Global Humanitarian Access Overview is ACAPS’ twice-yearly assessment of the barriers that prevent aid from reaching people in crisis and people in crisis from receiving assistance.

The Risk Radar is a forward-looking analytical tool developed by ACAPS to identify countries and contexts where the humanitarian situation is likely to deteriorate significantly over the next six months. This tool integrates the monitoring of hundreds of crises, evaluates key drivers and triggers, and applies a systematic risk-analysis methodology—assessing both impact and probability—to highlight areas where urgent attention and preparedness may be required.

fields.Org Description: The University of Minnesota provides extensive data services and projects through various centers, including the Minnesota Research Data Center (MnRDC), which provides researchers secure access to non-public data from the U.S. Census Bureau and other government agencies. Their data services also encompass data infrastructure assessment, record linkage, machine learning, innovative data capture, and data access and preservation. The IPUMS Center for Data Integration is a prominent provider of census and survey data globally, further showcasing the University's commitment to data integration and research.

fields.Project Description: IPUMS provides harmonized, high-quality census and survey data from over 100 countries. Available through an open-access platform, its datasets enable global research on health, population trends, labor, and development outcomes.

name: UNITAR: UN Institute for Training and Research

fields.Org Full Name: UNITAR: UN Institute for Training and Research
fields.Org Description: UNITAR focuses on building capacity in the use of data for evidence-based decision-making, particularly in developing countries. They organize workshops and develop toolkits on governance for data ecosystems, with a special emphasis on supporting the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). UNITAR also helps strengthen statistical training at national and local levels, promotes access to statistical learning for data producers, enables the use of new data sources like citizen data, and enhances the effective use of data by policymakers and stakeholders through statistical literacy initiatives.

fields.Project/Product Name: Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS)
fields.Project Description: The Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS) is a cooperation framework between the United Nations, the European Commission, and disaster managers worldwide. Its purpose is to improve alerts, facilitate information exchange, and enhance coordination during the initial phase following major sudden-onset disasters.

fields.Org Description: IOM’s work is guided by a commitment to upholding the dignity, safety, and protection of individuals affected by crises, even in the most challenging response contexts worldwide. All activities are designed to respect the rights and needs of people in vulnerable situations, ensuring that humanitarian assistance is delivered with sensitivity, impartiality, and a focus on safeguarding those at risk. IOM prioritizes ethical standards and best practices to foster environments where affected populations are treated with respect and their well-being is central to every intervention.

fields.Project Description: The DTM IDP Baseline Assessment provides a census-style snapshot of displaced populations, documenting where IDPs, returnees, and migrants are located at administrative levels, along with population counts and basic demographic characteristics. It establishes the authoritative “who and where” baseline for displacement contexts.

DTM Site and Settlement Assessments provide granular, site-level data on displacement locations such as camps and informal settlements, including population figures, shelter conditions, service availability, and protection risks to guide operational responses.

The International Organization for Migration’s Global Data Institute introduces PRIMARI, an ambitious initiative designed to enhance understanding of global mobility by consolidating sub-national displacement data with migration insights. This project aims to create a composite dataset covering up to 60 countries, utilizing the extensive data resources of the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM). PRIMARI is distinguished by its dedication to integrating diverse data streams into a single, accessible, and actionable dataset, supported by a comprehensive metadata repository to ensure data transparency and integrity.

DTM Flow Monitoring captures near-real-time data on population movements through key transit, entry, and exit points. It tracks volumes, directions, traveler profiles, reasons for movement, and intended destinations to understand mobility dynamics and emerging displacement routes.

DTM Returnee Monitoring documents the locations, numbers, and basic characteristics of populations returning to areas of origin after displacement. It supports analysis of return trends, reintegration conditions, and risks of secondary displacement.
The Migration Data Portal serves as a unique access point to timely, comprehensive migration statistics and reliable information about migration data on a global scale.

The Global Crisis Response Platform (GCRP) is a data and analytics platform that aggregates global risk indicators, country profiles, and dashboards to support early-warning, crisis preparedness, and financing decisions across development and humanitarian systems.

The Emergency Tracking Tool (ETT) is a rapid, event-triggered DTM mechanism that delivers near-real-time updates on sudden displacement caused by conflict or disasters, enabling immediate situational awareness during the first hours and days of a crisis.

DTM Service Mapping systematically maps the location, functionality, and accessibility of services and facilities—such as health, WASH, education, and humanitarian services—within displacement-affected areas to identify coverage gaps and support referrals.

fields.Project/Product Name: Humanitarian Data Science and Ethics Group (DSEG)
fields.Project Description: The Humanitarian Data Science and Ethics Group (DSEG) is a community of practice dedicated to advancing ethical, responsible, and inclusive data science within humanitarian contexts. The group supports the development and implementation of standards, tools, and guidance that prioritize protection principles and data accountability.

name: UNESCAP: United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific

fields.Org Full Name: UNESCAP: United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific
fields.Org Description: UNESCAP leverages data and statistics to address key development challenges in the Asia-Pacific region, providing member states with results-oriented projects, technical assistance, and capacity building. They work across various areas, including macroeconomic policy, poverty reduction, trade, environment, disaster risk reduction, and social development. UNESCAP promotes the use of data for evidence-based decision-making and fosters regional cooperation on transboundary issues, utilizing rigorous analysis and peer learning to inform policy dialogues and recommendations.
The mission of the Water Point Data Exchange (WPdx) is to unlock the potential of water point data to improve rural water services through evidence-based decision-making.

fields.Project Description: The Water Point Data Exchange (WPDx) platform is a global open data system that compiles and standardizes information on water point locations and characteristics from multiple countries. Hosted by the Global Water Challenge, it provides a critical repository for improving water service delivery by offering insights into functionality, service levels, and infrastructure gaps. WPDx data has been used by governments, NGOs, and development partners to enhance resource allocation, plan maintenance, and track progress toward water access goals, contributing to SDG 6.

fields.Org Description: The Partnership in Statistics for Development in the 21st Century (PARIS21) aims to improve the production, quality, availability, and use of statistics for informed decision making for sustainable development. It was established in 1999 by the United Nations, the European Commission, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), the International Monetary Fund, and the World Bank as a response to the need for accurate and reliable data to achieve and track progress toward development goals.

fields.Project Description: An online learning platform that offers training, MOOCs, and webinars focused on statistical capacity building and data system strengthening to support evidence-based policymaking.

ADAPT assists governments in assessing their statistical capacity, planning national data strategies, and making cost-effective investments in data infrastructure. It supports Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) tracking and capacity development in low- and middle-income countries.

fields.Project/Product Name: Guidelines for National Strategy for the Development of Statistics (NSDS)
fields.Project Description: The Guidelines for National Strategy for the Development of Statistics (NSDS) by PARIS21 provide structured guidance and tools to assist countries in designing national statistics strategies, aligning donor support, and integrating data systems for sustainable development planning.
An analytical platform that tracks country-level data system development and SDG readiness, providing dashboards and indicators to support the alignment of donor assistance with national priorities.

This is a global platform that tracks investments in national statistical systems. It offers open-access monitoring of resource flows, donor commitments, and financing gaps related to data for development.

fields.Org Description: The University of Oxford supports researchers and students with a suite of data services, primarily through the Bodleian Data Service, which offers access to statistics and data for secondary use. Oxford also provides research data management services for storing, publishing, and preserving research data outputs. Their Data Reporting, Architecture and Modelling (DRAM) team within IT Services offers comprehensive support for data management, analysis, and reporting, guided by the University IT Strategic Plan and Data Strategy.

fields.Project Description: The global Multidimensional Poverty Index (global MPI) is an annual international measure of acute multidimensional poverty that covers over 100 developing countries. It complements traditional monetary poverty measures by capturing the acute, overlapping deprivations in health, education, and living standards that people in poverty experience. The global MPI is computed by the Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative (OPHI) in partnership with the Human Development Report Office of the United Nations Development Programme.

title_narrative: Development of Triple Artemisinin-based Combination Therapies
description_narrative: The goal of the Development of Triple Artemisinin-based Combination Therapies (DeTACT) project is to provide a solution using currently available antimalarials to contain multidrug-resistant Plasmodium falciparum malaria in the Greater Mekong Sub region, and to prevent the spread or emergence of resistance in India, Africa, and beyond. DeTACT aims to provide evidence from clinical, market and community-based research in support of a global change in policy to allow large-scale deployment of triple artemisinin-based combination therapies (TACTs) for the treatment of uncomplicated Plasmodium falciparum malaria. Switching from artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) to TACTs could be one of the last available options using currently available drugs to treat multidrug-resistant falciparum malaria and prevent or delay it from spreading or emerging in areas where it is not yet present. The project is divided into seven work packages: (1) Develop two co-packaged TACTs for uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria. (2) Using these products, conduct randomised, controlled, non-inferiority trials in 13 sites in 8 African countries and 4 Asian countries to provide evidence of safety, tolerability, and efficacy of the TACTs. (3) Mathematical modelling to assess the potential of TACTs to delay the emergence and further spread of antimalarial drug resistance and the costs and benefits of introducing TACTs in countries with different levels of drug resistance, malaria transmission rates, and adherence to treatment guidelines. (4) Analyse the conceptual ethical aspects and conduct an empirical ethics/social science study addressing the ethical aspects of a change to TACTs in the African paediatric patient population.  (5) A market positioning assessment based on interviews and focus group discussions with stakeholders ranging from end users to national and regional policy makers, to address the barriers and strategies to overcome these, and acceptability of changing to TACTs in Asia and Africa, which present different epidemiological settings. (6) Effective communication of the design of the study and evidence generated in order to engage with key stakeholders at an early stage.(7) Conduct a meta-analysis on harmonised individual patient-level data to compare the efficacy, safety, tolerability of TACTs versus ACTs in the general study population and in sub-groups (e.g., malnourished or undernourished children).

title_narrative: NIHR Global Health Research Cohort Academic Development Award - GHR CADA 2023
sector_narrative: GHR CADA funding is committed in conjunction with the Global Health Research Unit project. This workshop funding will go towards the emerging digital epidemiology practices to reinforce the GHRU project.
description_narrative: The NIHR GHR Cohort Academic Development Award (GHR CADA) scheme offers NIHR GHR Programme Training Leads (or Directors/Principle investigators (PIs) where there is no training lead in place) an opportunity to tailor a programme of activities to meet the academic training and career development needs of the cohort of NIHR GHR Academy members in their NIHR GHR Programme awards (primarily focussed on those who are LMIC based) and, where training needs align, with other NIHR GHR Programme awards.Individuals can apply to the GHR CADA scheme for up to £30,000 to undertake a programme of activities. Applications are light-touch and will be assessed in an open competition. Funding can include training course fees, invited speaker or facilitator costs, accommodation, travel, subsistence and any other reasonable expenses, for example internet connectivity costs incurred during the activities.Following completion of a GHR CADA award, the awardee is expected to be able to show evidence of:Completion of the programme of activities proposed in the applicationDevelopment of new research or technical skills/techniques within the cohortIncreased academic career development of the cohortInvolvement in collaborative relationships and increased networks.Evidence of the above will be sought by the NIHR through the GHR CADA final report.These guidance notes are intended to help completion of an application for the NIHR GHR CADA, Round 2 (2022). The NIHR Academy office can be contacted with any eligibility queries. Please contact the NIHR with any eligibility queries (ghrtp@nihr.ac.uk).
recipient_country_narrative: The GHR CADA funding will be wholly received by the University of Oxford in conjunction with the global health research unit (GHRU) project. The funding will provide a financial basis for a workshop that will be ran by CGPS for the wider GHRU team. This includes our collaborators from Colombia (Corporación colombiana de investigación agropecuaria - AGROSAVIA), Nigeria (University of Ibadan), India (Kempegowda Institute of Medical Sciences - KIMS), and the Philippines (Research Institute for Tropical Medicine - RITM).

description_narrative: Young Lives is a unique, innovative, longitudinal mixed methods study following the lives of 12,000 children in Ethiopia, India (in the states of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana), Peru and Vietnam, and is recognised internationally as one of the only major longitudinal studies taking a holistic approach to children living in poverty. Over the course of the study, Young Lives has been providing high-quality empirical evidence to better understand the drivers and impacts of child poverty, and to inform policy and programme design aimed at achieving the Sustainable Development Goals' (SDG's) target for children, adolescents and youth.

sector_narrative: AMR is a global threat to public health and new technologies and integrated understanding ofinformation on a local and global scale are required. Enhancing local decision making by providinghigh resolution data that can enhance treatment strategies to the individual is key to improvinginfection control. Placing individuals and their data in the context of regional and national interpretationcan aid understanding of transmission, pathogen population dynamics and public health risk.Ultimately, enhancing real time linkage of data at multiple geographic scales will provide us with aglobally aware data landscape and enhance our ability to spot the emergence and spread of newthreats and lead to intelligent deployment of interventions and the monitoring of their impact. WholeGenome Sequencing (WGS) is a technology increasingly embraced within translational public healthcommunities and offers the ability to provide information at an individual level, as well as at a regional,national and international scale due to its digital nature.Barriers to uptake of WGS are broad, practical and political, eg technology rollout, implementation andembedding in current practice as well as supply chains and reagent availability. Much progress isbeing made in technical support for practical implementation. However, a remaining major bottleneckis the rapid and routine linkage of data and interpretation to provide the greatest value to datagenerators at a local level, as well as the routine combination of data aggregated at a regional, nationaland international level.Here, we build upon work within the NIHR Global Health Research Unit on genomic surveillance ofAMR focussed on technical support for practical rollout of WGS and expand and enhance throughlinkage with regional institutions such as WHO to deliver regional capacity building. In addition, weaddress the increasing emphasis and need for local data science and engineering to transform thedata landscape within local and regional hubs for linking clinical and epidemiological data to genomics.We focus on operationalising methods and tools to deliver a data landscape for local and national, andultimately international monitoring of genomic trends in AMR linked to relevant clinical andepidemiological data for enhancing infection control and taking decisive action to curb the threat ofAMR;
description_narrative: Understanding and mitigating resistance to effective treatment is a cornerstone of our fight against  infectious diseases. Antimicrobial resistant (AMR) bacterial infections are increasingly predicted  to have catastrophic impact on global health and wellbeing. To better respond to this growing crisis, we need the highest quality insight into how, where and when AMR emerges and the ability  to monitor its progression so that we can understand whether our mitigation efforts are effective at a local, national and international level. We have previously implemented capacity for Whole Genome Sequencing (WGS) at key  reference sites, embedded in nascent or existing national surveillance networks in Nigeria, India,  Colombia and The Philippines and shown the potential to enhance surveillance through outbreak  detection and monitoring of resistant populations. Saving lives demands rapid delivery of the right  data to the right decision makers. Transforming the data landscape to operationalise the use of  intelligent surveillance is key to moving from public health research to public health  implementation. Here we will: - Deliver a data and reporting landscape for WGS-enhanced surveillance. - Leapfrog a surveillance network in Nigeria to spot and stop outbreaks - Deliver stakeholder specific reporting pathways in The Philippines - Monitor the impact of interventions in India - Bring together surveillance for OneHealth in Colombia - Share and implement the above across Countries - Develop regional centres of excellence to drive international policy. We will leave a legacy of engineering, data science and data driven surveillance enhanced through  the intelligent use of WGS. Effectively maximising the value of surveillance data to drive policy at  local, national and international levels will profoundly impact public health strategies for mitigating  the impact of antimicrobial resistant infections
